**Laozi Textual Collation and Annotation by Zhu Qianzhi**

**Preface to the Tang Dynasty Yizhou Longxingguan Stele Edition of the *Daodejing***

Qian Daxin remarked: According to the commentary of Heshang Gong, the text beginning with "The Dao that can be spoken" constitutes the *Dao Jing* (Book of the Way), Volume One, while the text beginning with "Supreme virtue is not virtuous" constitutes the *De Jing* (Book of Virtue/Power), Volume Two. Chao Yuezhi’s postscript to Wang Bi’s commentary states that Wang did not divide the text into *Dao* and *De* sections, thus preserving an ancient convention. However, Lu Deming’s *Explanations of Texts and Pronunciations* (*Jingdian Shiwen*) explicitly follows Fu Si’s (Wang Bi’s) edition, titling it "Dao Jing, Volume One" and "De Jing, Volume Two," identical to Heshang Gong’s arrangement. Chao’s claim of antiquity likely stems from a Song dynasty transcription, lacking proper verification.

Among the five stele editions of the *Daodejing* in my collection, only the Emperor Minghuang’s imperial commentary and this edition divide the text into *Dao Jing* and *De Jing*, a structure consistent with Han and Wei dynasty editions. This stele, carved in the early Tang, contains numerous variant characters distinct from other versions. For instance:
- "無" (wú) is written as "无" (wú),
- "愈" (yù) as "俞" (yú),
- "芸" (yún) as "云" (yún),
- "譽" (yù) as "豫" (yù),
- "荒" (huāng) as "忙" (máng),
- "佐" (zuǒ) as "作" (zuò),
- "" (xī) as "翕" (xī),

all adhering to ancient script forms.

Further examples include:
- Where other editions read "故能蔽不新成" (*hence it can obscure and not renew*), the stele reads "能蔽復成" (*can obscure and renew*).
- After "Where the army has camped, brambles grow," the stele omits the lines "After a great war, there must be famine years."
- After "The supreme general stands on the right," the stele omits "This is to position him according to funeral rites."
- The passage "Only by recognizing illness as illness does one avoid illness; the sage is not ill because he recognizes illness as illness, thus avoiding illness" appears on the stele simply as: "Thus the sage is not ill, for he recognizes illness as illness, and so avoids illness."

Such variants far surpass other editions. These few examples suffice to demonstrate the value of ancient steles.

Wu Yi stated: The division of the *Laozi* into *Dao Jing* (Volume One) and *De Jing* (Volume Two) aligns with ancient editions. Later, Lu You (Fangweng) noted in his postscript: "Chao claimed that Wang Bi’s *Laozi* did not separate *Dao* and *De* into upper and lower sections, preserving an ancient form. Yet this edition has long since been divided." Thus, even by the Song dynasty, Wang Bi’s definitive edition was already lost.

The *Lunyu Shu* (Commentary on the *Analects*) by Xing Bing cites the *De Jing*: "The net of heaven is vast; though its mesh is wide, nothing escapes." This serves as one piece of evidence.

Examining the *Hanshu* (Book of Han) annotations:
- Yan Shigu, in the *Biography of Wei Bao*, quotes the *Dao Jing*: "In a state of chaos and confusion, loyal ministers emerge."
- In the *Biography of Tian Heng*, he cites the *De Jing*: "Nobility takes humility as its root; the high takes the low as its foundation. Thus lords and kings call themselves 'orphaned,' 'widowed,' and 'destitute.'"
- In the *Biography of Emperor Yuan of Chu*, he quotes the *De Jing*: "Knowing contentment avoids disgrace."
- In the *Biography of Yan Zhu*, he notes: "This is what Laozi meant by 'Where the army camps, brambles grow.'" Yan Shigu comments: "This is from the *Dao Jing*."
- In the *Biography of Yang Xiong*, "Those who value me are few," Yan Shigu notes: "The *De Jing* states, 'Those who know me are few; thus I am valued.'"
- In the *Biographies of Harsh Officials*, Laozi’s words are cited: "Supreme virtue is not virtuous, thus it possesses virtue; lesser virtue does not lose virtue, thus it lacks virtue. When laws and decrees proliferate, thieves and bandits abound." Yan Shigu comments: "This is from the *De Jing*."
- "When inferior scholars hear the Dao, they laugh greatly," Yan Shigu notes: "This is from the *Dao Jing*."
- In the *Treatise on the Western Regions*, the annotation quotes the *De Jing*: "When the world follows the Dao, warhorses are retired to fertilize the fields."

All these citations divide the text into *Dao* and *De* sections, aligning with Lu Deming’s *Explanations of Texts and Pronunciations*, which titles them "Dao Jing Pronunciation and Meaning" and "De Jing Pronunciation and Meaning." Jia Gongyan’s commentary on the *Zhouli* (*Rites of Zhou*) also cites the *Dao Jing*: "The Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao," and subsequently references the *De Jing*: "Supreme virtue is not virtuous, thus it possesses virtue." Zhanghuai Taizi’s commentary on the *Hou Hanshu* (*Book of Later Han*), in the *Biography of Zhai Pu*, quotes the *Dao Jing*: "Fish cannot be removed from the spring."

These scholars, writing in the early Tang, uniformly attest to this division. The *Mengzhen Ke Stele* states: "Examining the *Dao Jing*, compassion is its treasure." Such evidence must derive from Jin and Song dynasty editions, confirming the division in this stele as historically grounded.

Wang Chang remarked: The stele’s upper volume is titled *Laozi Dao Jing* and the lower *Laozi De Jing*, clearly separating *Dao* and *De* without conflation. Thus, Emperor Xuanzong’s commentary follows this ancient structure. Dong Qian’s *Catalogue of Collected Books* erroneously claims that Xuanzong’s commentary first reorganized the text into the *Daodejing*, grouping *Dao*-related passages in the upper volume and *De*-related passages in the lower. This is incorrect.

Wu Yun stated: The *Sui Shu Jingji Zhi* (*Bibliographic Treatise of the Sui History*) records the *Daodejing* in two volumes with Wang Bi’s commentary. Chao Yuezhi and Xiong Kezhong’s postscripts both assert that the text was not divided into *Dao* and *De* sections, yet the current *Explanations of Texts and Pronunciations* clearly separates it into two volumes. Some suspect this division was added by later editors. However, Xing Bing’s *Lunyu Shu* cites the *De Jing* ("The net of heaven is vast..."), and Yan Shigu’s *Hanshu* annotations frequently reference the *Dao Jing* and *De Jing* as distinct. Thus, the division did not originate with Lu Deming. This stele’s inscription of the *De Jing* is well-founded.

Sun Yirang noted: The *Laozi*’s eighty-one chapters are divided into *Dao Jing* (upper) and *De Jing* (lower).

The *Heshang Gong* version, the Wang Bi annotated edition recorded in the *Explanations of Texts and Pronunciations*, the Tang-era Fu Yi collated edition in the *Daoist Canon*, and the Tang Emperor Xuanzong’s annotated stele edition all align in this regard. The *Hongming Ji*’s *Mouzi’s Treatise on Resolving Doubts* states: “The principles are rectified in thirty-seven clauses, which also incorporate the thirty-seven chapters of the *Dao Jing* from the teachings of Laozi.” Thus, as early as the Han dynasty, this text was already divided into the *Dao Jing* and *De Jing*, with the *Dao Jing* comprising thirty-seven chapters and the *De Jing* forty-four—matching precisely the modern edition. The extant Wang Bi commentary, derived from the Song-era collation by Chao Yuezhi, does not separate the *Dao* and *De* sections. While this may be coherent in meaning, it does not reflect the original form of the Han and Tang texts.

**Chapter One**
Hong Yixuan remarked: The Wang Fusi (Wang Bi) edition of the *Daodejing* in circulation today uniformly includes chapter divisions. Though this edition does not record the total number of chapters, each chapter is demarcated by an empty space. Some divisions differ from the modern Wang Bi edition: for instance, in the current version, “The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible” through “it is the predecessor of the Emperor” forms three chapters; “Heaven and earth are not humane” through “it is better to abide in the center” forms four; and “The valley spirit never dies” through “its use is never exhausted” forms six—whereas this edition combines them into one. The lines “Thus, being is the benefit, non-being is the use” are attached to Chapter Twelve in the modern Wang edition, but here, the word “thus” is omitted, and the two lines are placed at the beginning of the following chapter. The lines “Heaviness is the root of lightness; stillness is the ruler of restlessness” appear in Chapter Twenty-Six in the modern edition but are appended to the end of the preceding chapter here. Lu Deming’s *Pronunciations and Meanings of the Laozi* has already been altered by later hands in its chapter divisions, and it is regrettable that this edition cannot be compared against it.

**The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao;**
**The name that can be named is not the eternal name.**

Yu Zhengxie observed: In these two lines by Laozi, the terms “Dao” and “name” differ from their usage elsewhere. Here, “Dao” refers to speech, and “name” to writing. The *Wenzi*’s *Essence and Sincerity* states: “The name that can be named is not the eternal name; inscribed on bamboo and silk, carved in metal and stone, these are but its coarse manifestations.” The *Superior Righteousness* chapter says: “Reciting the books of the former kings is not as good as hearing their words; hearing their words is not as good as grasping their meaning. Thus, the name that can be named is not the eternal name.” The *Superior Ritual* chapter states: “The laws and measures of the former kings undergo change, hence ‘the name that can be named is not the eternal name.’” The *Huainanzi*’s *Original Dao* chapter declares: “The perfected person seals their mouth and silences their discourse, yet none in the world recognize the value of their silence. Thus, the Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao; the name that can be named is not the eternal name.”

Inscribed on bamboo and silk, carved in metal and stone—what can be transmitted to others is but its coarse form. Scholars of later ages, though learned and widely informed, are not immune to confusion.

The *Miu Cheng Xun* states: “That the Dao has chapters and defined forms is not its ultimate expression.” The *Dao Ying Xun* records: “Duke Huan was reading in the hall when Wheelwright Bian said, ‘What remains is but the dregs.’ Thus Laozi says: ‘The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao; the name that can be named is not the eternal name.’” All these take Laozi’s “Dao” as discourse and “name” as written words.

Yan Zhi notes: Yu’s interpretation is correct. Laozi composed his five thousand characters precisely to set forth the intent behind his words. For “Dao” is the general term for transformation. It shifts with the times, responding to things with change; though mutable, there is that within it which does not change—this is what is called “constant.”

From early commentators on Laozi onward, many have held that the Dao cannot be spoken. Gao You’s commentary on the *Huainanzi*’s *Fan Lun Xun* says: “The eternal Dao is deep, hidden, and obscure—it cannot be spoken.” The spurious *Guan Yinzi* expands this, claiming that “what cannot be spoken is the Dao.” In truth, Laozi’s book itself declares that “nothing is the function of the Dao, while something is its benefit”—it is not that the Dao cannot be spoken. He speaks of “beautiful words,” of “words having a ruler,” of “correct words seeming contradictory,” of “my words being very easy to know and very easy to practice”—all these are spoken, all can be expressed and named.

Yet commentators, fixating on one aspect, take “constant” to mean unchanging and immutable. What can be spoken and named is subject to change, while what cannot be spoken or named is beyond change (Lin Xiyi). Thus, the Dao that can be spoken is deemed unspeakable, and the name that can be named is deemed unnameable. They fail to grasp that Laozi’s Dao is ceaselessly shifting, flowing through the six directions—there is no eternally unchanging Dao, nor any eternally unchanging name. Therefore, in engaging the world, one has no fixed mind, “taking the hearts of the common people as one’s heart” (Chapter 49). In responding to things, one “establishes them in constant non-being” (*Zhuangzi*, “Under Heaven”), for words can be constantly non-existent or constantly existent, not clinging to old constancy. Not clinging to old constancy, it is called “not constant.” Yet in constant being and constant non-being, it is said: “Returning to the root is called constancy” (Chapter 16), “Knowing harmony is called constancy” (Chapter 55)—the constant is the inconstant.

Day gives way to night, death to life; resting in the proper time and following the natural course, one moves with the times. As Zhuangzi says: “Life and death are fate, like the constant alternation of night and day—this is Heaven.” The Dao of Heaven and Earth endures without cease; the four seasons transform yet achieve lasting completion. If it were unchanging and immutable, how could there be anything called “constant”? Thus it is said: “The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao; the name that can be named is not the eternal name.”

“No-name” is the beginning of Heaven and Earth; “name” is the mother of the myriad things. Yan Kejun notes: “‘No-name’—most versions write ‘無’; the following instances follow this pattern. ‘The beginning of Heaven and Earth’—the *Yu Zhu* commentary matches this. The *He Shang Gong* and Wang Bi versions write ‘the beginning of Heaven and Earth,’ and the following line also includes the word ‘之.’” Wei Jiasun says: Yan’s collation note states: “Most versions write ‘無’; the following instances follow this pattern.” For the line “act without acting,” the collation note is the same. This edition of the *Dao De Jing* consistently writes “無” in the *Dao Jing*; in the *De Jing*, it writes “無” before “act without acting” and “無” thereafter. This line should read: “The *Dao Jing* follows this pattern.” Luo Zhenyu says: The Jinglong and Dunhuang versions write “無” throughout, as does the *Yu Zhu* stone edition. The two “之” characters are absent in the Jinglong, *Yu Zhu*, and Dunhuang versions but present in the *He Shang Gong* version.

Yan Zhi notes: The *Jing Dian Shi Wen*, Volume 2, *Zhou Yi Yin Yi*, states: “‘無’ is pronounced *wu*; this character appears throughout the *Yi*. The *Shuo Wen* says: ‘An archaic character for *wu*, connected to *yuan*, signifying the Dao of emptiness and nothingness. Wang Yu explains that Heaven curves to the northwest, forming *wu*.’ The vulgar form is ‘旡,’ which is incorrect. ‘旡’ is pronounced *ji* and appears in characters like ‘既.’ Laozi writes ‘無,’ consistent with the *Yi*.” Wang Bi, Fu Yi, and Fan Yingyuan’s versions all include the word “之.” Fan’s version writes “萬” as “万.” “No-name is the beginning of Heaven and Earth”—the *Shiji*, *Biographies of Diviners*, quotes it as “No-name is the beginning of the myriad things.” Wang Bi’s commentary states: “All things begin from nothing, so before form and name exist, it is the beginning of the myriad things.” This seems to treat both lines as referring to “myriad things,” which is incorrect.

Note that “beginning” (*shi*) and “mother” (*mu*) have distinct meanings. The *Shuo Wen* says: “‘Beginning’ (*shi*) is the first stage of a woman.” “Mother” (*mu*) depicts a child in the womb—one interpretation is that it shows a child nursing. This distinction between the two states of named and nameless carries profound significance. Before Heaven and Earth arose, all was undifferentiated chaos, like a maiden’s first innocence, pure and unadorned. Chapter 25 of the text says: “There is a thing formed in chaos, born before Heaven and Earth.” Chapter 40 states: “Being arises from non-being.” This is the nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth. “The myriad things of the world are born from being”—being engenders ceaseless generation. Chapter 42 says: “The Dao gives birth to one, one gives birth to two, two gives birth to three, three gives birth to the myriad things.”

This is the named mother of the myriad things. The *Zhuangzi*’s “On the Equality of Things” also states: “Heaven and Earth were born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one”—both instances juxtapose the terms “Heaven and Earth” and “the myriad things.” “Ever without, to observe its mystery; ever with, to observe its boundary.”

Fan Yingyuan says: The ancient editions, along with those of Heshang Gong, Wang Bi, Li Ruoyu, and Zhang Junxiang, all include the word *gu* (故, “thus”) before “ever without.” He further cites the *Yinbian* (音辩), which states: “‘Ever without’ and ‘ever with’ should be read as a single phrase.” Wang Yinglin says: The practice of punctuating after “with” (*you*, 有) and “without” (*wu*, 無) in the first chapter began with Wang Jiefu. Yan Kejun says: The imperial commentary follows this same punctuation. In the editions of Heshang Gong and Wang Bi, the word *yi* (以, “by”) appears before “observe” in both clauses, but Luo Zhenyu notes that the three Dunhuang manuscripts all omit *gu* and the two instances of *yi*. Additionally, “boundary” (*jiao*, 徼) is written as *jiao* (皦) in the Dunhuang texts. Yu Yue says: The *Daodejing* stele engraved in the second year of Jinglong (708 CE) in Yizhou lacks both instances of *yi*, and this should be followed. Sima Wengong and Wang Jinggong both punctuate after “without,” which is also correct. Yi Shunding says: The *Zhuangzi*’s “Tianxia” chapter states: “Laozi heard of its teachings and delighted in them, establishing them upon ‘ever without and with’ (*chang wu you*, 常無有).” Here, “ever without” and “ever with” are treated as a single phrase, just as in this chapter—this usage already appears in the *Zhuangzi*.

Qian Zhi notes: The imperial commentary, along with the editions of Xing Xuan, Jingfu, Qingyang, Lou Zheng, Panxi, Gu Huan, Peng Si, and Gao Di, all omit *gu*. For “boundary” (*jiao*), the editions of Fu Yi and Fan Yingyuan agree with the stele, but the Dunhuang version’s *jiao* (皦) should be adopted. In Chapter 14, “its upper part is not *jiao* (皦),” the Jinglong stele also writes it as *jiao*, which is correct. The *Yiqiejing Yinyi* (一切經音義), Volume 84, cites the *Shuowen*: “‘*Jiao* (徼)’ is written as ‘to patrol’ (*xun*), meaning to intercept.” Here, the sense of interception is irrelevant. Volumes 79 and 83 of the same work cite the *Shuowen*: “‘*Jiao* (皦)’ is composed of *ri* (日, sun) and its phonetic, though the two Xu editions omit it.” Tian Qian says: According to Hui Lin’s citation of the *Pipang* (埤倉), “it means ‘bright’ (*ming*),” and the *Yunhui* (韻會) also defines it as “bright,” though without specifying the source. The *Book of Songs* says, “as bright as the *jiao* sun,” and the *Shi Zhuan* (詩傳) explains: “*Jiao* means ‘radiant’ (*guang*).” The ancient edition of the *Shuowen* originally included the character *jiao*, but later generations sometimes borrowed *jiao* (皎) in its place. *Jiao* (皎) refers to the whiteness of the moon, as in the *Book of Songs* line, “the moon emerges, *jiao* bright.” Alternatively, they borrowed *jiao* (皦), which denotes the whiteness of white jade, as in the *Analects*’ “*jiao* as if.” Each character has its own semantic domain. In “as bright as the *jiao* sun,” *jiao* (皦) is firmly associated with *ri* (日, sun), not *bai* (白, white).

The text reads: “Ever without, observe its mystery.” “Mystery” (*miao*) refers to the subtle and minute, as Xun Yue’s *Shenjian* says: “What is profoundly subtle is called *miao*.” “Ever with, observe its *jiao* (皦)”—“*jiao*” here means “radiance” (*guangming*), forming a parallel with “mystery.” The implication is that what is manifest in principle is called *jiao*. These two emerge from the same source but have different names.

Qian Zhi notes: Chen Jingyuan’s *Cangshi Zuanwei* punctuates after “these two are the same” (*ci liang zhe tong*). Yan Fu says: The pause should come after “same,” for all things derive from the same. However, “emerge from the same” (*tong chu*) and “have different names” (*yi ming*) form a parallel structure, so punctuating after “same” is incorrect. Jiang Xichang says: The twelve characters following “these two are the same” are absent in Fan Yingyuan’s edition. Qian Zhi notes: The *Xugu Yizong Shu* edition of Fan’s text includes these twelve characters; Jiang’s emendation is mistaken. Chapter 40 states: “The myriad things of the world are born from being, and being arises from non-being.” Here, “these two” refer to being and non-being. Being and non-being have different names, yet the Dao unites them as one. “Both are called the profound. Profound and yet more profound—gateway to all mysteries.”

Zhang Heng says: “The profound (*xuan*) is the formless kind, the root of spontaneity. It acts at the Great Beginning, and nothing precedes it. It embraces virtue and power, enveloping Heaven and Earth, containing and regulating primordial *qi*, bestowing without form.” Yang Xiong says: “The profound is what is dark and vast, pervading the myriad kinds without manifesting form.” Both interpretations derive from this passage.

**Phonology**
Li Daochun says: “The phrasing of this text often harmonizes in rhyme.” Deng Tingzhen says: “Many works among the Masters employ rhymed prose, but none so densely as the *Laozi*. Apart from the *Book of Changes* and the *Book of Songs*, it is the most ancient.” Liu Shipei says: “To study the divisions of ancient rhyme, one must examine rhymed texts from the Zhou dynasty. Among Zhou works, aside from the *Book of Changes* and the *Li Sao*, none are as purely rhymed as the *Laozi*.” Today, we take Jiang Yougao’s *Laozi Yun Du* as the primary reference, supplemented by Wu Yu’s *Yun Bu*, Gu Yanwu’s *Tang Yun Zheng*, Jiang Yong’s *Guyun Biaozhun*, Yao Wentian’s *Guyin Xie*, Deng Tingzhen’s *Shuangyanzhai Biji* (Volume 3), and Li Gengyun’s *Bingzhu Bian*, to trace the ancient rhymes of the text, seeking patterns in its phrases and characters.

Moreover, Liu Shipei, Xi Dong, Chen Zhu, and Bernhard Karlgren’s *A Study of Rhymes in the Laozi* (*The Poetical Parts in Lao-Tsi*) present many conjectural theories on the ancient phonology of the *Laozi*, some of which are tenable. I have occasionally appended my own views, and thus it becomes evident that the five thousand characters of the text largely conform to phonetic harmony, forming a resplendent composition. Once the principles of rhyme are clarified, the beauty of its philosophical poetry becomes apparent.

Below, I shall examine the text chapter by chapter. For this chapter, Jiang Yougao’s *Laozi Yun Du* identifies the following rhymes:
*Dao* (道) rhymes with *Dao* (道) in the *you* group;
*ming* (名) rhymes with *ming* (名) in the *geng* group;
*shi* (始) rhymes with *mu* (母) in the *zhi* group (*mu* read as *mǎnyǐ* in fanqie);
*miao* (妙) rhymes with *jiao* (徼) in the *xiao* group (*jiao* in the departing tone);
*xuan* (玄) rhymes with *men* (门) in a mixed *wen-zhen* rhyme (*xuan* read as *hújūn* in fanqie).

Qian Zhi’s note: *Xuan* (玄) belongs to the *zhen* group, while *men* (门) belongs to the *wen* group; the *wen* and *zhen* groups share rhymes.
Yao Wentian concurs, except for *xuan* and *men*.
Karlgren, however, argues that *tong* (同) and *ming* (名) form a rhyme, which is incorrect.
Deng Tingzhen also errs in claiming that *Dao* (道) and *Dao* (道), as well as *ming* (名) and *ming* (名), do not rhyme.

The *Jinglong Stele* version of this chapter contains fifty-four characters, matching the Dunhuang manuscript. The *Heshang Gong* version (Song dynasty edition), Wang Bi’s version (from the *Guyi Congshu*), Fu Yi’s version (from the *Jingxun Tang*), and Fan Yingyuan’s version (from the *Xugu Guyishu*) all contain fifty-nine characters. Yan Kejun observes: “A single character’s space follows the phrase *zhong miao zhi men* (众妙之门) to mark the division of chapters, though the imperial commentary does not include this space. The *Heshang Gong* version titles the preceding section *‘Tidao Di Yi’* (体道第一), while Wang Bi titles it *‘Chapter One.’* This version lacks such headings, and subsequent chapters follow this convention.” My own note: The *Laozi* originally comprised two scrolls, upper and lower; later generations divided it into chapters, resulting in variations of fifty-five, sixty-four, sixty-eight, seventy-two, or eighty-one chapters. Though the stele version does not record the number of chapters, each is separated by a blank space, aligning roughly with the divisions in the *Heshang Gong*, Wang Bi, Fu, and Fan versions. Thus, I adopt the chapter divisions as transmitted in these received texts. This chapter is titled *‘Dao Ke Dao Zhang Di Yi’* (道可道章第一) in Fan Yingyuan’s version. Chapter Two follows.

All under heaven know beauty as beauty—this is already ugliness;
All know goodness as goodness—this is already not goodness.

[Ma Xulun’s note: The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying Xun* quotes the latter line as “All under heaven know goodness as goodness—this is already not goodness.” Peng Song observes: “The *Dazhen* and *Qingyuan* editions both include ‘under heaven’ before ‘all know goodness as goodness.’” Fan Yingyuan’s edition concurs, with Fan’s commentary noting: “Ancient edition.” The *Lunyu Jijie Yishu* (9) quotes “all know” as “take to know.” The *Guangming* and Zhao Mengfu editions render the final “已” as “矣,” while Li Daochun’s edition changes the first “已” to “矣.” Su Zhe’s and Dong Sijing’s editions replace both “已” with “矣.” “已” and “矣” were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Shuowen* (5) states: “矣 is a word marking completion, composed of 矢 and its phonetic.” The character was also written as “已.”]

Thus:
Being and non-being give birth to one another;
Difficulty and ease complete one another;
Long and short shape one another;
High and low incline toward one another;
Tones and voices harmonize with one another;
Before and after follow one another.

[Ma Xulun’s note: The Dunhuang manuscript, Suizhou stele, and Gu Huan’s edition omit the word “thus.” In the six instances of “相,” the *Guangming*, *Jingfu*, *Qingyang*, *Panxi*, *Louzheng*, *Shitang*, Peng Song’s, Fu Yi’s, Fan Yingyuan’s, Gao Pi’s, and Zhao Mengfu’s editions, along with the *Hou Hanshu*’s commentary on Zhu Mu’s biography, all include the particle “之,” whereas Wang Bi’s and Heshang Gong’s editions omit it. Li Daochun remarks: “Adding ‘之’ to the six phrases from ‘Being and non-being give birth to one another’ onward is incorrect.” Yan Kejun notes: “‘Shape one another’—Wang Bi renders this as ‘compare one another,’ as recorded in the *Shiwen*.” Ma Xulun’s note: The reading “shape one another” is correct. Bi Yuan states: “Wang Bi’s ‘compare’ and Lu Deming’s ‘compare’ are both incorrect. The character ‘较’ did not exist in antiquity; the original text rhymes ‘shape’ with ‘incline,’ so ‘compare’ is clearly unsuitable.” Liu Shipei argues: “The *Wenzi* reads: ‘Long and short do not shape one another.’ The *Huainanzi*’s *Qi Su Xun* states: ‘Short and long shape one another.’ It is likely that Laozi’s original text also used ‘shape,’ rhyming with ‘birth,’ ‘complete,’ and ‘incline.’ ‘Compare’ was a later gloss, explaining ‘shape’; scribes then replaced ‘shape’ with ‘compare.’” Note: The *Huainanzi*’s *Qi Su Xun* reads: “Thus high and low incline toward one another, short and long shape one another,” including two instances of “也.” “Long” was altered to “修” to avoid the taboo of the father’s name. Ma Xulun states: “‘Compare’—all editions render this as ‘shape.’ The *Shuowen* records the ancient form of ‘荆’ as ‘○,’ so the ancient form of ‘形’ may also have been written with ‘○.’ The ‘爻’ component in ‘爻’ resembles the ‘爻’ in the ‘○’ form. Perhaps Laozi originally wrote ‘○,’ which was corrupted in transmission to ‘爻’; readers, finding it unintelligible, added the ‘车’ component to form ‘○.’ Later, ‘较’ became standard while ‘○’ fell out of use, resulting in the character ‘较.’”]

Tones and voices harmonize with one another;
Before and after follow one another.

[Ma Xulun’s note: “Before”—the Dunhuang manuscript renders this as “先,” as do the Suizhou stele, Gu Huan’s, and Qiang Siqi’s editions. Jiang Xichang observes: “Gu Huan’s commentary in the *Cheng* edition reads ‘what comes first and what comes after,’ indicating that ‘before’ was originally ‘先.’ Qiang Siqi’s commentary states: ‘The later is seen through the earlier; the earlier is illuminated by the later.’ This also uses ‘先.’ Laozi’s text consistently pairs ‘先’ and ‘后,’ so this instance should not differ. Examples include Chapter 7: ‘Thus the sage places himself last and finds himself first’; Chapter 66: ‘To lead the people, one must place oneself behind them’; and Chapter 67: ‘Abandoning the last to grasp the first.’”]

Therefore, the sage abides in non-action and practices the teaching without words.

[Ma Xulun’s note: The Suizhou stele includes the character “治” after “人,” as does the Dunhuang manuscript. Cheng Xuanying’s commentary states: “Thus it is said, ‘Therefore the sage governs.’” The *Qunshu Zhiyao* (34) omits “治.”]

The myriad things arise yet do not decline;
[Bi Yuan notes: Heshang Gong and Wang Bi both read: “The myriad things arise therein yet do not decline.” Lu Xisheng and the *Taiping Yulan* omit the word “therein.” Luo Zhenyu observes: The Jinglong, imperial commentary, and Jingfu editions all omit “therein.” Ma Xulun’s note: The Suizhou stele and Fu Yi’s edition also omit “therein.” Furthermore, “do not decline” is rendered as “do not initiate” in the Suizhou stele, Dunhuang manuscript, Fu Yi’s, and Fan Yingyuan’s editions. Fan Yingyuan states: “Wang Bi and Yang Fu follow the ancient edition.” Thus, Fan’s Wang Bi edition also reads “do not initiate.” Yi Shunding argues: The commentary in Wang Bi’s Chapter 17, which reads: “The great man, being above, dwells in non-action and practices the teaching without words; the myriad things arise therein yet do not initiate,” fully quotes this chapter’s text, proving that Wang Bi’s edition read “do not initiate,” though it included an additional “therein” compared to Fu Yi’s edition. Ma Xulun’s note: The reading “do not initiate” is correct and should be adopted as the standard. Bi Yuan states: “‘Initiate’ and ‘decline’ share the same sound, leading to this variation; Fu Yi’s interpretation is superior.” Lao Jian remarks: “The *Shuowen* records the seal script of ‘○’ as ‘,’ derived from 台. The *Xia Song Guwen Sisheng Yun* cites the stone classics’ ‘词’ as ‘○,’ and the ancient *Xiaojing*’s ‘始’ as ‘○.’ The ancient forms of these two characters were originally similar.”]

Here follows the translation:

---

Now, examining the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s “Valuing Impartiality” chapter, it states: “Heaven and Earth are vast indeed; they give life yet do not treat as their children, bring to completion yet do not possess. The myriad things all receive their benefit yet none know whence it begins.” The “Examining Distinctions” chapter further says: “Perfect in relation to the myriad things yet not controlling them, bestowing blessings upon the world yet none know whence it originates.” These passages both derive from this chapter of the *Laozi*, and the interpretation of “beginning” (*shi*) is superior.

“Giving life yet not possessing, acting yet not relying”—
Luo Zhenyu notes: “‘Giving life yet not possessing’ is absent in the Dunhuang manuscript.”
Ma Xulun observes: The Suizhou stele edition also omits this line. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* (Volume 34) cites the same as this stone inscription.

“Success is not dwelled upon.”
“Only by not dwelling does it not depart.”

Yan Kejun states: The imperial commentary and Wang Bi’s edition read “success achieved and not dwelled upon,” while Heshang Gong’s version has “success achieved yet not dwelled upon.”
Luo Zhenyu notes: The Jingfu edition reads “success achieved and not dwelled upon,” while the Dunhuang manuscript has “success achieved and not abiding.” Furthermore, “only by not dwelling,” in the Jinglong and imperial commentaries, “not” (*bu*) replaces “not” (*fu*), while the Dunhuang manuscript reads “not abiding.”
Ma Shulun remarks: Wang Bi’s commentary states, “Following things in their use, success arises from them, hence it is not dwelled upon.” Thus, Wang originally wrote “not dwelled upon.” The current “not” (*bu*) rendered as “not” (*fu*) may have been altered by later hands following Heshang Gong’s version.
Jiang Xichang observes: The *Huainanzi*’s “Responding to the Dao” chapter and the *Book of Later Han*’s annotation to the biography of Zhu Jun both cite “not” (*fu*) as “not” (*bu*). The *Yi Jing*’s *Xici* commentary’s *Zhengyi* quotes “yet not dwelled upon” as “not dwelled upon.” Qiang Ben’s *Yan* commentary reads: “Only by not daring to rest in dwelling,” where Yan’s “not” (*fu*) is “not” (*bu*). Qiang Ben’s citation of Cheng Xuanying’s subcommentary on the sutra text reads “success achieved and not abiding,” indicating Cheng wrote “success achieved and not abiding.” Ancient editions uniformly render “not” (*fu*) as “not” (*bu*). In Chapter 24, “Thus the person of the Dao does not abide”; in Chapter 38, “Not dwelling in its meagerness, not dwelling in its splendor”; and in Chapter 77, “Success achieved yet not abiding”—“not dwelling” (*bu ju*) or “not abiding” (*bu chu*) may be used interchangeably, as “dwelling” (*ju*) and “abiding” (*chu*) are largely synonymous. However, “not” (*fu*) is consistently rendered as “not” (*bu*). Comparing editions of the *Laozi* confirms that the original text was thus.

The *Lunheng*’s “Naturalness” chapter states: “Thus the greatness of non-action is evident. Originally not seeking success, yet success is established; originally not seeking fame, yet fame is achieved.” This precisely echoes this chapter’s “Only by not dwelling does it not depart.”

For all things under heaven, nothing exists without its counterpart; where there is contradiction, there is advancement. Thus, where there is beauty, a yet more beautiful contends with it, and beauty as beauty ceases to be beautiful. Where there is goodness, a yet greater goodness contends with it, and goodness as goodness ceases to be good. Therefore, being and non-being form a pair: the myriad things under heaven are born of being, and being is born of non-being—this is the mutual arising of being and non-being. Difficulty and ease form a pair: difficulty is made manifest by ease, and ease is made evident by difficulty. Without difficulty, there would be no way to know ease; without ease, there would be no way to know difficulty—this is the mutual completion of difficulty and ease. Long and short form a pair: an inch is short compared to a foot, and a foot is long compared to an inch. Without length, there would be no way to clarify shortness; without shortness, there would be no way to perceive length—this is the mutual shaping of long and short. High and low form a pair: mountains collapse into valleys, and valleys subside into mountains. Without mountains, there would be no way to perceive valleys; without valleys, there would be no way to know mountains—this is the mutual inclining of high and low. Sound and tone form a pair: joy and sorrow, lament and resentment arise differently. Without sorrow, there would be no way to know joy; without joy, there would be no way to know sorrow—this is the mutual harmony of sound and tone. Before and after form a pair: the former is seen by the latter, and the latter is made clear by the former. Without the latter, there would be no way to know the former; without the former, there would be no way to know the latter—this is the mutual following of before and after (following Yan Junping’s interpretation).

From this perspective, all things under heaven are nowhere without contradiction, and nowhere are they not in mutual opposition, each acting in their own way. Only those without intention, who follow nature, do not seek success or fame, but govern by relying on things as they are. “Abiding in the affairs of non-action, practicing the teaching without words,” they penetrate deeply the principle of the myriad things’ mutual opposition and completion, waxing and waning, advancing with the times. The myriad things arise, yet I do not initiate; what I enact does not burden me with traces. Success achieved and affairs completed, I withdraw from my position. It cannot be deemed beautiful, hence it cannot be deemed ugly; it cannot be deemed first, hence it cannot be deemed last. Standing prior to opposition is called not dwelling; transcending the six realms of being and non-being is called not possessing. Possessing yet not possessing, things cannot precede it; dwelling in non-dwelling, it thus does not depart.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhyme scheme, according to Jiang Yong’s reading:
*Sheng* (生), *cheng* (成), *xing* (形), *qing* (倾) rhyme (in the *geng* 耕 rhyme group);
*he* (和), *sui* (随) rhyme (in the *ge* 歌 rhyme group; *sui* is read as *xu he* 徐禾);
*shi* (事), *jiao* (教), *ci* (辞), *you* (有), *shi* (恃) rhyme (merging the *zhi* 之 and *xiao* 宵 rhyme groups; *jiao* follows the *xieyin ji* 协音记, *ci* is in the departing tone, *you* is read as *yi* 以);
*ju* (居), *ju* (居), *qu* (去) rhyme (in the *yu* 鱼 rhyme group; *qu* is in the level tone).

Yao Wentian and Deng Tingzhen concur, though they do not address *shi* (事) and *jiao* (教). Chen Zhu further pairs *yi* (已) with *yi* (已) as rhymes.

Qian Zhi notes: In the Dunhuang, Suizhou, Fu, and Fan editions, *ci* (辞) appears as *shi* (始), while in the Dunhuang edition, *ju* (居) is written as *chu* (处). Karlgren reads *shi* (始) as rhyming with *shi* (事), *jiao* (教), *you* (有), and *shi* (恃), and *chu* (处) as rhyming with *qu* (去). Moreover, *jiao* (教) belongs to the *xiao* (宵) rhyme group, while *shi* (事), *ci* (辞), *you* (有), and *shi* (恃) belong to the *zhi* (之) group, merging *zhi* and *xiao* as a single rhyme.

Gu Yanwu states: *Sui* (随) in ancient pronunciation is *ju he* (句禾反), citing the *Laozi*’s “sounds and voices harmonize, front and rear follow” (*yin sheng xiang he, qian hou xiang sui* 音声相和，前后相随), where *he* (和) and *sui* (随) rhyme. Corroborating evidence includes the *Guanzi*’s *Baixin* chapter: “Without a leader, there is no harmony” (*ren bu chang bu he* 人不倡不和), and “Without beginning, there is no following” (*bu shi bu sui* 不始不随). The *Hanfeizi*’s *Jie Lao* states: “When great villainy arises, petty thieves follow; when great villainy leads, petty thieves harmonize” (*da jian zuo ze xiao dao sui, da jian chang ze xiao dao he* 大奸作则小盗随，大奸唱则小盗和), and “Thus when the *yu* leads, the *zhong* and *se* must follow; when the *yu* sings, all instruments harmonize” (*gu yu xian ze zhong se bi sui, yu chang ze zhu yue jie he* 故竽先则钟瑟必随，竽唱则诸乐皆和”) (*Tang Yun Zheng*, *Zhi* 5).

Jiang Yougao states: *Ci* (辞) is pronounced *si zi* (似兹切), but in ancient times it had a departing tone, as in the *Laozi*’s *Yangshen* chapter: “The myriad things arise yet do not decline” (*wan wu zuo yan er bu ci* 万物作焉而不辞), rhyming with *shi* (事) and *jiao* (教). He further notes: *Ju* (居) is pronounced *jiu yu* (九鱼切), but in ancient times it also had a departing tone and should be grouped with the *yu* (御) rhyme. In the *Laozi*’s *Yangshen* chapter, “Achieving merit yet not dwelling” (*gong cheng er bu ju* 功成而不居) rhymes with *qu* (去) (*Tang Yun Sisheng Zheng*, *Zhi* 7 and *Yu* 9).

The *Jinglong* stele edition contains seventy-eight characters; the Dunhuang edition, eighty-five; the Heshang, Wang Bi, and Fu Yi editions, eighty-eight; the Fan Yingyuan edition, ninety-seven. The Heshang edition titles this “Nurturing Life, II” (alternatively, “The Chapter of Beauty and Goodness”), the Wang Bi edition titles it “Chapter Two,” and the Fan edition titles it “When All Under Heaven Know, Chapter Two.”

**Chapter Three**
Do not exalt worthies, and the people will not contend;
Do not prize rare goods, and the people will not steal;
Do not display what is desirable, and the heart will not be disordered.

Yan Kejun states: In all editions, *shang* (上) appears as *shang* (尚). Luo Zhenyu notes: The Dunhuang edition reads *bu shang bao* (不上宝). Qian Zhi observes: *Shang* (上) is correct; *bao* (宝) is likely an error. *Shang* (上) and *shang* (尚) are interchangeable. The *Huainanzi*’s *Qi Su* chapter quotes the *Laozi*: “‘Do not exalt worthies’ means not luring fish into trees or sinking birds into the abyss” (*bu shang xian* 不上贤), also using *shang* (上), consistent with the *Jinglong*, Dunhuang, and Suizhou editions. The Suizhou edition writes *min* (民) as *ren* (人), as does the following clause.

Do not value hard-to-obtain goods, and the people will not steal.
Qian Zhi notes: The Heshang, Wang, Fu, and Fan editions all include *wei* (为) after *dao* (盗), while the Suizhou, Dunhuang, and *Yuzhu* editions omit it, as does this stele. The *Beitang Shuchao* (27) cites it as “Do not value goods, and the people will not steal” (*bu gui huo, shi min bu dao* 不贵货，使民不盗), also lacking *wei* (为).

Do not display what is desirable, and the heart will not be disordered.
Yan Kejun states: In Wang Bi’s edition, *shi* (使) is followed by *min* (民). Bi Yuan notes: The Heshang edition reads “and the heart will not be disordered” (*shi xin bu luan* 使心不乱), omitting *min* (民). The *Huainanzi* also omits it. Yi Shunding states: The *Jin Shu*’s biography of Wu Yinzhi reads: “Do not display what is desirable, and the heart will not be disordered” (*bu jian ke yu, shi xin bu luan* 不见可欲，使心不乱). The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on the *Dongjing Fu* and Shen Yue’s commentary on the *Zhongshan* poem both omit *min* (民). Wang Bing’s commentary on the *Suwen* (1) also omits it. Ji Yun states: The original and all editions lack *min* (民), except the *Yongle Dadian*, which includes it. According to Wang Bi’s commentary, “Thus what is desirable is not displayed” (*gu ke yu bu jian* 故可欲不见), following “risking life to steal” (*mo ming wei dao* 没命为盗), the text originally included *min* (民). Liu Shipei states: The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on the *Dongjing Fu* cites it as “and the heart will not be disordered” (*shi xin bu luan* 使心不乱), and Kong Yingda’s commentary on the *Yi*’s *Gen* hexagram also omits *min* (民), likely due to Tang-era taboo deletions. The ancient text actually included *min* (民), consistent with the two preceding instances.

Qian Zhi counters: Ji and Liu’s arguments are incorrect. Wang Bi’s commentary reads: “Breaking in, prying into chests, risking life to steal—thus when what is desirable is not displayed, the heart has nothing to disorder” (*chuan yu tan qie, mo ming er dao, gu ke yu bu jian, ze xin wu suo luan ye* 穿窬探箧，没命而盗，故可欲不见，则心无所乱也), showing Wang’s edition lacked *min* (民). The *Yongle Dadian* likely follows Wu Cheng’s edition in erroneously adding it. Liu claims the omission resulted from Tang-era taboo deletions, unaware that the ancient text lacked *min* (民). The *Qunshu Zhiyao* (34) also omits it. If this were related to taboos, why were the two preceding *min* (民) not also deleted? This is not a case of arbitrary deletion but of arbitrary addition. However, Wu Cheng had a basis: Chu Suiliang’s postscript to Wang Xizhi’s calligraphy (dated Zhenguan 15) reads “and the people’s hearts will not be disordered” (*min xin bu luan* 民心不乱), matching the Fu and Fan editions, indicating the error is long-standing. Though the Fu and Fan editions claim antiquity, they were altered by later hands, their wording often more verbose than other editions—this is one example.

The sage governs:
Yan Kejun states: All editions include *shi yi* (是以) before this clause, and Wang Bi’s edition adds *zhi* (之) after *ren* (人). Wu Yun notes: The Fu edition reads “The sage’s governance” (*sheng ren zhi zhi* 圣人之治) followed by *ye* (也); Li Daochun omits *zhi zhi* (之治). Qian Zhi observes: Including *zhi* (之) is correct.

Empty their hearts, fill their bellies, weaken their ambitions, strengthen their bones.
Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Shiwen* records *qiang* (强) as also written *qiang* (强).

The Dunhuang manuscript reads *qiang* (强). Qian Zhi observes: The Lou Zheng edition also reads *qiang* (强). Furthermore, *Qunshu Zhiyao*, juan 34, cites: “Thus the sage’s governance constantly keeps the people without knowledge and without desire,” omitting the four phrases “empty their hearts, fill their bellies, weaken their ambitions, strengthen their bones.”

Constantly keep the people without knowledge and without desire.
Yan Kejun states: “Constantly keep the people” (*chang shi min* 常使民) appears as “keep people” (*shi ren* 使人) in the *Yu Zhu* edition. Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Yu Zhu* edition avoids the taboo by using *ren* (人). Qian Zhi observes: The Wang Xizhi edition omits *chang* (常), while the Suizhou stele edition omits *min* (民).

Let the knowing ones not dare to act, and there will be nothing left ungverned.
Yan Kejun states: “Let the knowing ones” (*shi zhi zhe* 使知者) includes the character *fu* (夫) after *shi* (使) in all editions. “Not dare to act” (*bu gan wei* 不敢为) is followed by the three characters *wei wu wei* (为无为) in all editions, and by the four characters *ye wei wu wei* (也为无为) in Wang Bi’s edition. Luo Zhenyu notes: *Zhi* (知) appears as *zhi* (智) in modern editions; the *Shiwen* lists the two characters *zhi zhe* (知者) and glosses *zhi* (智), indicating that Wang Bi’s edition originally read *zhi* (知). The Jinglong, *Yu Zhu*, and Dunhuang editions also read *zhi* (知). Moreover, the Jinglong, *Yu Zhu*, Dunhuang, and Jingfu editions all omit *ye* (也) after *wei* (为). Qian Zhi observes: According to Luo’s facsimile of the *Zhen Song Tang Cang Xirui Miji Congcan* collation of the Dunhuang manuscript, *bu* (不) appears after *gan* (敢), an omission in Luo’s *Kaoyi*. The Suizhou stele edition also reads *bu gan bu wei ye* (不敢不为也).

Qiang Siqi cites Cheng Xuanying’s commentary: “Having already relinquished both desire and non-desire, one further fears that those without desire may become attached to the view of emptiness, taking non-desire as the Dao. Thus, ‘not daring not to act’ (*bu gan bu wei* 不敢不为) is to dispel non-desire. One fears clinging to this non-action, hence the subsequent ‘not daring’ (*bu gan* 不敢).” Cheng’s commentary also originally read *bu gan bu wei* (不敢不为). Only Gu’s edition of Cheng’s commentary reads “thus, ‘not daring to act’ (*bu gan wei* 不敢为) is to dispel non-desire,” omitting this *bu* (不). Now, *bu gan* (不敢) and *bu wei* (不为) are two distinct matters, corresponding to the earlier “without knowledge, without desire” (*wu zhi, wu yu* 无知、无欲). The phrase should be punctuated after *bu gan* (不敢).

In Chapter 30 of the text, “not by seizing strength” (*bu yi qu qiang* 不以取强), all editions include *gan* (敢) after *bu* (不), but *gan* (敢) is a superfluous character. However, in Chapter 67, “I dare not act as the first in the world” (*bu gan wei tian xia xian* 不敢为天下先); in Chapter 69, “I dare not act as the host but act as the guest, dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot” (*wu bu gan wei zhu er wei ke, bu gan jin cun er tui chi* 吾不敢为主而为客，不敢进寸而退尺); and in Chapter 73, “Being brave in not daring brings life” (*yong yu bu gan ze huo* 勇于不敢则活), *bu gan* (不敢) and *bu wei* (不为) are paired, indicating that Gu’s edition of Cheng’s commentary contains errors of omission in the base text. Laozi’s original meaning is this: constantly keep the general populace without knowledge and without desire, and constantly keep the few who know from daring to act or acting. In this way, there will be spontaneous transformation through tranquility, and nothing will remain ungoverned.

Furthermore, *bu gan* (不敢) and *bu wei* (不为) constitute “governing by not governing” (*bu zhi zhi zhi* 不治治之). The *Lunheng*, in its “Naturalness” chapter, states: “When Qu Boyu governed Wei, Zigong sent someone to ask him, ‘How do you govern Wei?’ He replied, ‘I govern it by not governing.’ This ‘governing by not governing’ is the Dao of non-action.” This meaning derives from Laozi. Laozi’s intent is that the highest governance is no governance. What the world calls governance—exalting the worthy causes the people to contend; prizing rare goods causes the people to steal; displaying what is desirable disturbs their hearts. Now, if one reverses this, so that the people see no one to exalt, no goods to prize, and nothing to desire, then they will return to simplicity and preserve purity. Constantly keeping the people without knowledge and without desire, they will naturally become tranquil, neither contending nor stealing nor disordering. This is why the knowing ones dare not act. In an age of perfect virtue, the ruler is like the tip of a branch, and the people are like wild deer—chewing their food in joy, drumming their bellies in play. This is the ancient era of non-action, where the people transform themselves, soaring in spontaneity, and nothing remains ungoverned.

**[Phonology]**
In this chapter, Jiang Yong’s *Yun Du* finds no rhyme. Karlgren takes *fu* (腹), *gu* (骨), and *yu* (欲) as rhyming, as does Chen Zhu. Chen further takes *zhi* (治) as rhyming with them, stating: “This is likely a shift in the sound of *ge* (歌).” Qian Zhi observes: Wang Niansun’s *Mao Shi Qun Jing Chu Ci Gu Yun Pu* places *yu* (欲) and *fu* (腹) in the *you* (幽) rhyme group, citing the *Yue Ji*: “The noble person delights in attaining the Dao” (*jun zi le de qi dao* 君子乐得其道), where *dao* (道) and *yu* (欲) rhyme. In the fourth stanza of the *Shijing*’s “Liao’e,” *ju* (鞫), *xu* (蓄), *yu* (育), *fu* (复), and *fu* (腹) rhyme. In the *Chu Ci*’s “Tian Wen,” *yu* (育) and *fu* (腹) rhyme.

Qian Zhi further observes: *xian* (贤) and *zheng* (争) rhyme. Kong Guangsen’s *Shi Sheng Lei*, in the second section on yang sounds, lists the character *jian* (坚) under the twentieth entry, stating: “In the *Xing Wei* (行苇): ‘The sturdy bows are already firm (*jian* 坚), the four arrows are already balanced, the arrows are already released in order, and the guests are arranged by worthiness (*xian* 贤).’ The character *jian* (坚) is derived from *○*, which is the ancient form of *xian* (贤). Today, in the seventeenth division of the *zhen* (真) rhyme, there is the character *xian* (礥), which is the correct pronunciation of *xian* (贤).” He further lists *xian* (贤), stating: “In the *Bei Shan* (北山): ‘The great officers are not equal, and I alone am worthy (*xian* 贤) in my tasks.’ See *jian* (坚) above.” Now, *xian* (贤) and *zheng* (争) are phonetically close; the old Indian translation of *xian dou* (贤豆) serves as collateral evidence. Wang Niansun’s *Gu Yun Pu* places *xian* (贤) in the *zhen* (真) rhyme group alongside *jian* (坚), while *zheng* (争, pronounced *zhen* 真) is in the *geng* (耕) group. This serves as evidence for the interrhyming of *zhen* (真) and *geng* (耕).

The Jinglong stele edition contains 57 characters; the Dunhuang edition, 58; the Heshang edition, 66; the Wang Bi edition, 67; the Fu edition, 68; and the Fan edition, 69.

The *Heshang* edition titles this "Pacifying the People, Third," the *Wang* edition titles it "Chapter Three," and the *Fan* edition titles it "The Chapter on Not Exalting the Worthy, Third."

**Chapter Four**
The Dao is empty (*chong*), yet its use is inexhaustible.
Yan Qian notes: “*Chong* (冲) appears as *zhong* (盅) in Fu Yi’s edition. *Zhong* is the ancient form of *chong*.” The *Shuowen* under the *min* (皿) radical states: “*Zhong*: a vessel’s emptiness. *Laozi* says, ‘The Dao is empty (*zhong*) and thus used.’” Guo Zhongshu’s *Han Jian* (上之二) cites the character *chong* (冲), quoting the ancient *Laozi* as ○.
Bi Yuan says: “The *Shuowen Jiezi* cites this text as *zhong*, while all other editions read *chong*. The *Huainanzi* also reads *chong*, but both are incorrect.” For emptiness within a vessel is called *zhong*; being empty, it holds things. Thus, the *Zhuangzi*’s “Responding to Emperors” states: “Great emptiness (*zhong*) is invincible.”
Yan Kejun says: “‘Inexhaustible over time’ (*jiu bu ying*)—other editions read ‘perhaps inexhaustible’ (*huo bu ying*).” Luo Zhenyu says: The Jinglong stele reads *jiu* (久), while the Dunhuang edition reads *you* (又), a corruption of *jiu*. Yu Yue says: “‘The Dao is empty (*zhong*) and thus used’—*zhong* means emptiness, directly opposing *ying* (盈, fullness). *Chong* is a borrowed character.” In Chapter 45, “Great fullness seems empty (*chong*),” *chong* should also be written as *zhong*.
He further notes: “‘Perhaps inexhaustible’ (*huo bu ying*)—the Tang Jinglong stele reads ‘inexhaustible over time’ (*jiu bu ying*). Emptiness that remains inexhaustible over time is true emptiness (*zhong*), far superior to modern editions.” The *Heshang Gong* commentary states: “*Huo* means ‘constant.’” To gloss *huo* as “constant” is unattested in antiquity; the *Heshang* edition likely originally read *jiu*.
Yan Qian notes: The reading *jiu* is correct. The *Taiping Yulan* (322) quotes the *Mozi*: “One who skillfully maintains victory weakens the strong, hence *Laozi* says, ‘The Dao is empty (*chong*) and thus used, yet it is not full (*you bu ying*).’” *You bu ying* (有弗盈) means *you bu ying* (又不盈). Jia Changchao’s *Qun Jing Yin Bian* states: “*You* means *you* (又). Wang Bi’s commentary reads: ‘Thus it is empty and used, yet again not full (*you fu bu ying*).’” This shows the *Wang* edition also reads *you*, not *huo*. *You*, *you*, and *jiu* were interchangeable in antiquity.
Ma Xulun says: “The *Mozi* quotes it as *you*, the *Heshang* as *huo*, and the Yizhou edition as *jiu*—these four characters were interchangeable in antiquity. *You* (又), *you* (有), and *huo* (或) were mutually interchangeable, as seen in the *Jingzhuan Shici*. In meaning, *jiu* is superior. *You* (又), *you* (有), and *jiu* (久) are also interchangeable. The *Zhuangzi*’s ‘Perfect Joy’ reads: ‘Man *you* (又) returns to the mechanism.’ The *Liezi*’s ‘Heaven’s Endowment’ reads *jiu* (久) for *you*. The *Liezi*’s ‘Heaven’s Endowment’ states: ‘The spirit is heaven’s *jiu* (久).’ Yin Jingshun and Chen Jingyuan’s *Shiwen* note: ‘*Jiu* is pronounced *you* and originally written *you* (又).’ The *Hanshu*’s ‘Yang Wangsun’ says: ‘The spirit is heaven’s *you* (有).’ This is drawn from the same passage, serving as further evidence. The sounds of *you* (又), *jiu* (久), and *you* (有) all belong to the same phonetic category.”
Yan Qian notes: In Fu Yi’s edition, *ying* (盈) appears as *man* (满). Lu Deming says: “*Ying* is also written *man* in some editions.” *Ying* and *man* share the same meaning. The *Yiqie Jing Yinyi* (13) cites the *Shuowen*: “*Ying* means ‘a vessel full.’” The two Xu editions read “full vessel.” Tian Qian says: “Under the *shui* (水) radical, *yi* (溢) is defined as ‘a vessel full.’ A full vessel is *yi*, which is also *ying*. Thus, under *man* (满), it states: ‘*Ying* means overflowing.’ The gloss is quite clear.” This confirms that *ying* and *man* are interchangeable, though the original text should read *ying*.
Ma Xulun says: “The character *man* in other editions appears as *ying* because, as Xun Yue says: ‘To avoid the taboo on *ying*, it was changed to *man*.’ Emperor Hui of Han was named *Ying*, so the character was altered to *man* in deference. Thus, *ying* is the original form.” Profound indeed!

"The myriad things take it as their ancestor."

Yan Kejun says: “‘Profound indeed!’—the *Yu zhu* edition reads ‘abyssal-like,’ the *Heshang Gong* edition reads ‘abyssal-like indeed,’ and Wang Bi’s edition reads ‘abyssal ah, like.’ For ‘the myriad things take it as their ancestor,’ the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi editions include the word *zhi* (‘of’) after *wu* (‘things’).”

Luo Zhenyu says: The Dunhuang manuscript reads, “abyssal-like, the ancestor of the myriad things.”

Qian Zhi notes: The *Shi wen* gives “abyssal ○,” adding: “The *Heshang Gong* edition reads *hu* (‘indeed’).” Bi Yuan says: “○ is the ancient form of the character *xi* (‘ah’).” Lu Wenchang says: “‘○’ in modern editions is uniformly written as *xi* (‘ah’).”

Furthermore, the editions of Fu Yi and Fan Yingyuan read: “abyssal ah, like the ancestor of the myriad things.” In Fan’s edition, the character *wan* (‘myriad’) is consistently written as its variant form. The *Yu pian* states: “‘万’ is the vulgar form of ‘萬,’ meaning ten thousand.” This single example shows that Fan’s edition preserves many ancient glosses and also retains vulgar characters.

It is also noted that *shen* (‘profound’) and *yuan* (‘abyssal’) share the same meaning. The *Yu pian* defines *yuan* as “water still and deep.” The *Xiao Er Ya Guang yu* states: “‘Abyssal’ means ‘deep.’” Lao Jian says: “The *Jinglong* edition reads ‘profound indeed, the ancestor of the myriad things.’ This was likely changed from *yuan* (‘abyssal’) to *shen* (‘profound’) to avoid a Tang taboo.”

"Blunt its sharpness, untie its tangles, harmonize its brilliance, and unite with its dust."

Yu Yue remarks: According to the *Shiwen*, the Heshang Gong edition writes *fen* (‘tangled’) as *fen* (‘fragrant’); yet the character *fen* (‘fragrant’) carries no meaning here. This line also appears in Chapter 56, where Heshang Gong annotates: “‘Tangled’ means knotted resentment.” ... In that chapter, he comments: “‘Tangled’ means unceasing knotted resentment.” The annotations are largely identical. Thus, the Heshang edition’s *fen* (‘fragrant’) should be read as *fen* (‘resentment’). If taken literally, the gloss’s meaning of “knotted resentment” becomes unintelligible. ... Wang Bi’s edition of Chapter 56 writes *jie qi fen* (‘untie its divisions’), with the note: “Eliminate the source of contention.” Here, too, *fen* is read as *fen* (‘resentment’). Gu Huan’s edition correctly writes *fen* (‘resentment’), which is the proper character, while *fen* (‘fragrant’) and *fen* (‘tangled’) are both loan characters.

Takeuchi Yoshio states: “‘Untie its tangles’ appears in Heshang Gong’s edition as *fen* (‘fragrant’).” He notes that *fen* (‘fragrant’) should be *fen* (‘resentment’). This line appears in Chapter 4 and again in Chapter 56. In the old manuscript of the Heshang Gong edition, the latter chapter writes *fen* (‘resentment’), while this chapter writes *fen* (‘tangled’). Wang Bi’s edition of Chapter 56 writes *fen* (‘divisions’), but his annotation reveals that *fen* (‘divisions’) is a corruption of *fen* (‘resentment’). This chapter aligns with the old manuscript of the Heshang Gong edition, and both Wang Bi’s and Heshang Gong’s editions share the same character. By the time of the *Jinglong* stele and the Dunhuang manuscript, *fen* (‘tangled’) in this chapter was revised to *fen* (‘resentment’), restoring the loan character to its proper form.

Tan Xian observes: Chapter 56 also includes the four lines “Blunt its sharpness...,” suggesting a possible interpolation. “Abiding in stillness, it seems ever-present.”

Yan Kejun notes: Heshang Gong’s edition reads *zhan xi si ruo cun* (‘still, it seems as if present’), while Wang Bi’s edition reads *zhan xi si huo cun* (‘still, it seems perhaps present’).

Luo Zhenyu states: Both the *Jinglong* and *Imperial Commentary* editions read *zhan chang cun* (‘still, ever-present’), while the Dunhuang edition reads *zhan si chang cun* (‘still, it seems ever-present’).

Takeuchi Yoshio adds: The Dunhuang edition of this line reads *zhan ran chang cun* (‘still and ever-present’), while the Suzhou edition reads *zhan si chang cun* (‘still, it seems ever-present’).

Wang Chang remarks: The Xingzhou edition includes the character *zhi* (‘it’) after *shui* (‘who’) in the following line.

Qian Zhi notes: The Fu and Fan editions match Wang Bi’s version. The Xingzhou edition was once thought to be the Suzhou edition, but this is now known to be incorrect. In Chapter 14, the line “This is called the indistinct and evanescent” is recorded by Wang Chang as identical across all editions, though the Xingzhou edition omits it. However, the Suzhou edition does include it, writing *shi wei hu huang* (‘This is called indistinct and evanescent’), providing further evidence.

The character *zhan* (‘still’), as defined in the *Shuowen*, means “submerged.” The *Xiao Er Ya Guang Yu* states: “‘Submerged’ means ‘nonexistent.’” Here, “still and ever-present” describes its empty numinosity, unobscured—seemingly nonexistent yet truly present.

“Whose child am I? The ancestor of the Divine Sovereign.”

Yan Kejun states: “‘Whose child’ is rendered as ‘whose child’ (*shui zhi zi*) in the Heshang Gong and Wang Bi versions.” Jiao Hong notes: “‘Whose child’ (*shui zhi zi*) is absent in Chen Bixu’s Sima edition.” Luo Zhenyu observes: “The Jinglong, Imperial Commentary, and Dunhuang versions all omit the character *zhi* (‘whose’).” Qian Zhiji comments: The Muromachi edition includes *qi* (‘its’) before *shui* (‘who’) and *zhi* (‘whose’) after it. However, the omission of *zhi* is correct. The *Guang Ya*’s *Shi Yan* states: “‘Child’ (*zi*) means ‘resembles’ (*si*).” Thus, “I know not whose child” (*wu bu zhi shui zi*) means “I know not whom it resembles,” and the meaning is complete. This passage asks: Is it spirit? Is it sovereign? The one this world calls the master of life and death—yet the Dao alone precedes it. The Dao dwells in the realm of doubt and semblance, as if one knew not whose child it is; yet it is self-so and self-rooted, existing before heaven and earth and enduring since antiquity.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhymes, according to Jiang Yong: *fen* (纷), *chen* (尘), *cun* (存), and *xian* (先) rhyme (Wen rhyme group; *xian* read as *si yin*). Yao Wentian and Deng Tingzhen concur. Deng notes: “‘*Xian*’ was anciently read like ‘*shen*.’” Qian Zhiji adds: *zhong* (盅), *ying* (盈), and *zong* (宗) also rhyme. Xi Di, Chen Zhu, and Bernhard Karlgren agree. Yao Nai states: “‘The Dao is empty’ (*dao chong*) forms a phrase, rhyming with *zong* (宗), signifying the Dao’s essence as utterly empty.” Xi Di notes: *zhong* (盅), *ying* (盈), and *zong* (宗) rhyme. The shift between Dong and Geng rhyme groups is seen elsewhere, as in Chapter 24, where *gong* (功) rhymes with *ming* (明), and in the *Zhuangzi*’s “In You” chapter, where *chong* (虫) rhymes with *qing* (情), *cheng* (成), and *ming* (鸣). Further, *fen* (纷), *chen* (尘), and *xian* (先) rhyme. The *Huangdi Neijing Suwen*’s “Eight Rectifications’ Spiritual Clarity” chapter rhymes *xian* (先) with *shen* (神) and *cun* (存), while the *Chu Ci*’s “Summons of the Soul” rhymes *xian* (先) with *fen* (纷) and *chen* (陈). Qian Daxin states: The *Shuowen* reads *chong* (冲) like *dong* (动). The *Book of Documents*’ “I am but a youth” (*yu wei chong ren*) is glossed in the *Shi Wen* as *zhi zhong* (直忠反). Anciently, *zhi* (直) was read like *te* (特), so *chong zi* (冲子) is akin to *dong zi* (动子). Qian Zhiji further notes: “Ever-present in stillness” (*zhan chang cun*)—the Heshang Gong and Wang Bi versions include *xi* (兮) after *zhan* (湛). The particle *xi* is most common in the *Chu Ci*, and the *Laozi* already marks its beginning. Kong Guangsen’s *Shi Sheng Lei* (7) states: “‘*Xi*’ appears in the *Tang* rhyme group under twelve *qi*, but its ancient pronunciation lacks firm evidence. Yet the *Tai Shi*’s ‘*duan duan yi*’ is cited in the *Great Learning* as ‘*duan duan xi*’, suggesting *xi* and *yi* share sound and meaning. *Yi* was anciently read as *e* (阿), so *xi* should likewise be read as *e*.”

The Jinglong stele version contains thirty-seven characters and is not divided into chapters.

The Heshang Gong, Wang Bi, and Fu Yi versions contain forty-two characters; the Fan Yingyuan version, forty-three; and the Dunhuang version, thirty-nine. (Takeuchi’s edition states “thirty-seven characters,” but it is actually thirty-nine. Luo’s scroll annotation reads “forty-nine characters,” where “four” is a miswriting of “three.”) Heshang Gong titles it “Chapter Four: No Source,” Wang Bi titles it “Chapter Four,” and Fan Yingyuan titles it “Chapter Four: The Dao’s Impulse.”

---

Chapter Five
Heaven and earth are not humane,
Treating the myriad things as *chugou*;
The sage is not humane,
Treating the hundred clans as *chugou*.

Yan Kejun notes: “○○” are variant characters.
Luo Zhenyu states: The Jinglong and Guangming editions write “○,” while the Dunhuang edition writes “○,” both variant forms of *chu* (刍).
Qian Zhiji observes: The Heshang Gong, Wang Bi, Fu Yi, and Fan versions all write *chugou* (刍狗). See *Shiwen* and *Qunshu Zhiyao*.

Li Wenzhong (zi Jian) states: “‘*Chu* (刍),’ as per the *Shuowen*, means ‘to cut grass,’ depicting the form of bundled grass. The Suizhou edition writes *chu* as ‘二屮,’ which is the character *cao* (草). The common addition of ‘grass’ is incorrect.”
Liu Shipei notes: *Chugou* refers to objects used in ancient sacrificial rites. The *Huainanzi*’s *Qi Su Xun* states: “It is like the initial completion of *chugou* or earthen dragons: adorned with blue and yellow, draped in fine silk, bound with vermilion threads, the spirit-mediums in ceremonial dress, the grand officers in full regalia, to send them off and welcome them back. Yet once used, they become mere clods of earth and bundles of grass—who would value them?” Gao You’s commentary: “*Chugou* are straw dogs made of bundled grass, used to seek blessings and atone for transgressions.” The *Shuo Shan Xun* says: “The sage employs things as if binding *chugou* with vermilion threads,” and further: “*Chugou* are treated with reverence to seek blessings.” Gao’s commentary: “By honoring the spirit of *chugou*, one obtains blessings.” Thus, in ancient sacrifices, *chugou* were universally used to seek blessings. They are straw dogs made of bundled grass, akin to straw effigies—objects used at first but discarded afterward. Laozi’s meaning here is that heaven and earth treat the myriad things, and the sage treats the hundred clans, as things first used and then abandoned, hence the analogy to *chugou* to condemn their lack of humanity.
Qian Zhiji notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Gui Gong* chapter cites the same two lines from Laozi in Gao You’s commentary. The *Zhuangzi*’s *Gengsang Chu* chapter states: “Perfect humanity has no partiality,” the *Qi Wu Lun* states: “Great humanity is not humane,” and the *Tian Yun* chapter states: “Before *chugou* are displayed, they are stored in fine baskets, wrapped in embroidered cloth, and the spirit-mediums fast and purify themselves to present them. Once displayed, passersby trample their heads and spines, while gatherers of fuel take them to burn.” All these passages derive from this.

Between heaven and earth, it is like a bellows. Yan Kejun notes: "蘥" in the *Yu zhu* edition appears as "橐钥"; the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions lack the particle "乎." Qian Zhiji notes: Wang Bi’s commentary states, "‘橐’ is a push-bellows; ‘钥’ is a musical pipe." Sun Yirang says: "According to the *Yiqie jing yinyi*, the *Dongguan Hanji* writes ‘排,’ while Wang Bi’s commentary uses ‘,’ both pronounced *pibai*, referring to the device used by smiths to blow fire and make it blaze. Another entry (vol. 12) states, ‘排筒,’ where the *Dongguan Hanji* reads ‘因水作排,’ and Wang Bi’s commentary explains, ‘橐 is a bag.’ (The *Yupian*’s *○* section defines ‘’ as ‘a bellows for blowing fire.’) Based on Xuanying’s account, the Wang Bi commentary he saw rendered ‘排橐’ as ‘bag,’ whereas modern editions and Lu Deming’s *Shiwen* both write ‘排橐’ (*Shiwen* notes: ‘排, *fubai*’—the same sound as *pibai*. ‘排橐’ also appears in the *Huainanzi*’s *Benjing xun* with Gao You’s commentary). The character ‘排’ aligns with the *Hanji*, suggesting that Wang Bi’s commentary may have existed in two versions during the Tang dynasty." (Modern editions of Wang Bi’s commentary do not separate the *Dao* and *Virtue* chapters, differing from the *Shiwen* version. Furthermore, the *Bianzheng lun* by Shi Falin cites commentary on the chapter "Man models himself on earth, earth on heaven," which diverges from modern editions—additional evidence that Wang Bi’s commentary circulated in variant versions during the Tang.)

The interpretation of *yue* as a musical pipe aligns with Cheng Xuanying’s view ("钥 is a panpipe") but differs from Wu Cheng’s explanation of *tuoyue*. Wu Cheng states: "‘橐钥’ refers to the device used in smelting to blow air and intensify the fire. The outer casing that encloses it is the *tuo* (bellows); the inner mechanism that fans the air is the *yue* (pipe). That heaven and earth resemble a *tuoyue* means the *tuo* symbolizes the great void, embodying the all-encompassing and pervasive body, while the *yue* symbolizes primordial *qi*, manifesting the dynamic and flowing function." Wu’s interpretation is more compelling.

Empty yet inexhaustible, moving and ever producing. Yan Kejun notes: Wang Bi and Gu Huan write "不掘." "俞出" appears as "愈出" in most editions. Qian Zhiji notes: The Fu and Fan editions also write "俞." Luo Zhenyu says: The modern Wang Bi edition writes "屈," consistent with the *Jinglong*, *Yu zhu*, and *Jingfu* editions. The *Shiwen* includes the variant "掘," indicating Wang Bi’s original text used "掘." The *Shiwen* further notes: "The *Heshang Gong* edition writes *qu* (屈), while Gu writes *jue* (掘)." Qian Zhiji notes: The correct reading is "屈." Wang Bi’s commentary states, "Thus empty yet not exhaustibly bent," confirming that Wang Bi’s original text used "屈," as does the Fan edition. The Fu edition writes "诎" for "屈." Lao Jian says: "According to the *Shuowen*, ‘屈’ means tailless, extended to denote anything short, hence the sense of exhaustion. ‘诎’ means bent, the original character for ‘bending and straightening.’ *Jue* (掘) and *hu* (搰) gloss each other. The *Shiwen* cites Gu’s note ‘like exhaustion,’ treating it as a loan for *qu* (屈). The Fu edition’s ‘诎’ misinterprets it as bending and straightening, which is incorrect. This character should be ‘屈,’ glossed as exhaustion, pronounced *jue*." Bi Yuan says: "俞" appears as "愈" in all editions. However, the ancient character for ‘愈’ did not exist; it is likely a substitution for ‘俞.’ All editions are incorrect."

Too many words lead to frequent exhaustion; it is better to abide in the center.

Qian’s note: Takeuchi Yoshio states: "The Dun and Sui editions both write ‘loyalty’ (忠)." The fragmentary Dunhuang manuscript of the *Heshang* edition held in the Bibliothèque nationale de France reads "abide in loyalty" (守忠), matching the Sui Prefecture stele. However, the character "loyalty" (忠) lacks semantic coherence here. The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying Xun* quotes the preceding two lines as "abide in the center" (守中), which is correct. Furthermore, the phrase "many words" (多言) appears as "much learning" (多聞) in the Sui Prefecture stele, and the *Wenzi*’s *Daoyuan* chapter likewise cites it as "much learning." In his *Chengshu*, Qiang Ben glosses: "‘Much learning’ means broad and ample; ‘frequent exhaustion’ refers to excessive speech." This is merely a forced interpretation based on the Sui edition.

Qian further notes: Regarding the "center" (中) in "abide in the center," Zhang Binglin’s *Wenshi* 7 states: "‘Center’ originally referred to documents such as registers. Thus, the *Chun Guan*’s *Tianfu* states: ‘For all offices, prefectures, districts, and towns, the *zhizhong* receives and stores them.’ Zheng Sinong comments: ‘*Zhizhong* refers to the essential records of administrative duties.’ The *Qiu Guan*’s *Xiao Sikou* states: ‘Using the three deliberations, they judge the *zhong* of the people’s lawsuits; at year’s end, they order the officials to tally the concluded cases and present the *zhong* to the *Tianfu*.’ The *Liji*’s *Liyi* states: ‘Relying on famous mountains, they present the *zhong* to Heaven.’ Presenting the *zhong* is like ascending the *zhong*, meaning they offer registers of the people’s numbers and the essentials of governance. The *Yaodian*’s ‘truly grasp its center’ refers to holding the charts and registers." The "abide in the center" in this chapter carries the same meaning, akin to managing tallies.

Luo Yunxian states: "‘Center’ is also a tally. Governing does not lie in excessive speech but in upholding the legal tally to assist the world—this is the meaning of ‘non-action.’"

**[Phonology]**
For this chapter, Jiang Yong’s *Yun Du* reads: *qu* (屈) and *chu* (出) as rhymes (both in the *zhi* group), while *qiong* (穷) and *zhong* (中) rhyme (both in the *zhong* group). All scholars concur. Kong Guangsen’s *Shisheng Lei* 5, in the yang tone’s *dong* category, cites the *Analects*: "The celestial reckoning is in your person; truly grasp its center. If the Four Seas suffer exhaustion, Heaven’s emolument will forever end." The *Daodejing*’s *Daojing* states: "Many words lead to frequent exhaustion; it is better to abide in the center." The *Dejing* states: "Great fullness resembles emptiness; its use is inexhaustible." The *Zhuangzi* states: "I have come and gone, yet know not its end; I wander in vastness, where great knowledge enters yet knows not its exhaustion." The *Guanzi* states: "Promote what is beautiful to observe its end; discard what is detested and surely calculate its exhaustion." Generally, the shared rhymes do not extend beyond the three characters *zhong* (中), *zhong* (终), and *qiong* (穷), demonstrating the narrowness of the *dong* rhyme, which cannot be loosely conflated with *dong* or *zhong*.

Qian’s note: The *Zhuangzi*’s *Qiwulun* states: "The pivot begins to grasp its ring’s center to respond to the inexhaustible," also rhyming *zhong* (中) and *qiong* (穷). Moreover, in the *Daodejing*, the characters preceding *zhong* (中) and *qiong* (穷)—*shu* (数) and *shou* (守)—also rhyme with each other, forming a "rhyme above the rhyme." This follows Ma Xulun’s explanation, as seen in the postface to the *Mao Shi Zheng Yun*.

The forty-four characters of the Jinglong stele are presented without chapter divisions, matching the Dunhuang version. The He, Wang, Fu, and Fan editions contain forty-five characters. The He Shang text titles this "Vacuity and Function, Chapter Five," the Wang edition titles it "Chapter Five," and the Fan edition titles it "Heaven and Earth Are Not Humane, Chapter Five."

**Chapter Six**
"The valley spirit does not die;
This is called the mysterious female."

Bi Yuan notes: Lu Deming states, "In the He Shang text, *gu* (谷) is written as *yu* (浴), with the gloss: '*Yu* means to nourish.'" The Later Han stele inscription by Chen Xiang (Bian Shao) for Laozi also writes it as "*yu* spirit," aligning with the He Shang version. Yu Yue comments: The character *yu* (浴) truly lacks the meaning of nourishment. In the He Shang text, *yu* should be read as *gu* (谷). The *Book of Songs* in the "Xiao Bian," "Liao E," and "Si Yue" sections all state: "None among the people do not *gu*." Mao’s commentary consistently glosses *gu* as "to nourish." *Gu* (谷) is also interchangeable with *gu* (谷). The *Erya*’s "Explanation of Heaven" states: "The east wind is called *gu* wind." The *Shi Jing* commentary by Sun Yan cites: "*Gu* is spoken of as *gu*; *gu* means to generate, and generation is also nourishment." The version Wang Bi relied upon writes *gu* (谷), which is a loan character for *gu* (谷). The ancient He Shang text writes *yu* (浴), which is a variant of *gu* (谷). Hong Yixuan states: According to the *Explanation of Characters*, the He Shang text writes *yu* (浴). The *Book of Changes* states, "The noble person restrains anger and suppresses desires," where Meng Xi’s version writes *yu* (浴). Both *gu* (谷) and *yu* (浴) are loan characters for *yu* (欲). *Mencius*’ "Jinxin, Part Two" states: "To nourish the mind, nothing is better than reducing desires." Thus, it is by desire that the spirit does not die. The *Liexian Zhuan* records: Rongcheng Gong excelled in the arts of supplementation and guiding, drawing essence from the mysterious female. Its essential teaching is that the valley spirit does not die—it is the preservation of life and the nourishment of qi. This aligns with the same meaning. Xu Zi states: According to the He Shang commentary, *gu* is glossed as nourishment, so it should be *gu* (谷). Mao’s commentary on the *Book of Songs*, Zheng’s annotations, and the *Guangya*’s "Explanation of Terms" all state: "*Gu* means to nourish." This is because *gu* (谷) and *gu* (谷) are interchangeable, a phonetic loan. The *Book of Documents*’ "Canon of Yao" states, "The western dwelling is called Meigu," while the *Rites of Zhou*’s "Feng Ren" commentary writes, "The western measurement is called Liugu." This is what the *Da Dai Li Ji* refers to as "the autumn sacrifice at Liugu." The *Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as "Liugu." In the *Zhuangzi*, "Zang and Gu herd sheep," Cui Zhuan’s version writes "Zang and Gu herd sheep," serving as evidence. Furthermore, the *Explanation of Characters* states: "*Gu* is written as *yu* in the He Shang text, with the gloss: '*Yu* means to nourish.'" This differs from the current version. Hong Kuo’s *Lishi* records the Laozi inscription: "Some have *yu* spirit does not die." Thus, the ancient version originally wrote *yu* (浴). *Gu* (谷) is a loan for *gu* (谷), and *yu* (浴) is in turn a loan for *gu* (谷).

Qian’s note: Writing "*gu* spirit" is correct. Modern Song editions and the Daozang He Shang text all write *gu* (谷), not *yu* (浴). The *Liezi*’s "Tian Rui" chapter cites the *Book of the Yellow Emperor*: "The valley spirit does not die; this is called the mysterious female." Yu Jianwu’s poem states: "Discussing the Dao ceases at the valley spirit." Yu Xin’s poem states: "In vacuity, nourish the valley spirit." The Later Han’s Gao Yifang’s *Qing Jie* states: "When wisdom and thought are utterly exhausted, the valley spirit endures ceaselessly." Fan Yingyuan states: "The two characters *gu* and *shen*, according to Fu Yi, mean 'profound and penetrating.'" All read *gu shen* as a compound. However, in the *Laozi*, *gu* and *shen* are in fact opposed. Chapter Thirty-Nine states: "The spirit obtains the One and becomes numinous; the valley obtains the One and becomes full," serving as evidence. Sima Guang states: "It is called *gu* because it is empty within; it is called *shen* because it is unfathomable. Heaven and earth have limits, but the Dao is limitless, hence it is said not to die." Yan Fu states: "Because it is empty, it is called *gu*; because it responds endlessly, it is called *shen*; because it is inexhaustible and ever-emerging, it is said not to die. These three are all virtues of the Dao." Thus, reading *gu* and *shen* as a compound is mistaken.

"The gate of the mysterious female
Is the root of heaven and earth."

Yan Kejun states: The He Shang and Wang Bi texts include the character *zhi* (之) before *men* (门) and *shi wei* (是谓) before *tian di* (天地). Qian’s note: The Suizhou, Dunhuang, and Imperial Commentary editions are identical to this stele.

"Vague and elusive, it seems to endure;
In its use, it is not exhausted."

Qian’s note: *Mianmian* (绵绵) is written as *mianmian* (绵绵) in all other editions. Cheng Xuanying states: "*Mianmian* describes something subtle and unbroken." *Mian* (绵) is a vulgar character. The *Yu Pian* states: "*Mian* is new silk floss, entangling, unceasing. Now written as *mian* (绵)." The *Five Classics Textual Criticism* states: "Writing *mian* (绵) is erroneous." Furthermore, after *mianmian* (绵绵), the Jingfu edition includes the character *xi* (兮), and the Shitang edition includes *hu* (乎). The character *qin* (勤) is written as *qin* (懃) in Takeuchi’s collated edition. Hong Yixuan states: *Qin* (勤) is interchangeable with *qin* (廑). Li Shan’s commentary on the *Wen Xuan*’s "Changyang Fu" cites the *Gu Jin Zi Gu*: "*Qin* is the modern *qin* (勤)." Jin Zhuo’s commentary on the *Book of Han*’s "Annals of Emperor Wen" states: "*Qin* is the ancient *qin* (勤)." The *Shuowen* states: "*Qin* means slight and inferior." This describes its qi as *mianmian*, seemingly enduring, and in its use, not weak or diminished.
