chunks.original_text: 德有上下，其无为一也。 以其不失德，故虽无为之中，而仍有以为。 谦之案：马说是也。 六十三章曰：「为无为。 」无为而有以为也。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 谦之案：上文以「无为」为主，分别「无以为」与「有以为」； 上德「无以为」，下德「有以为」。 此文以「为之」为主，分别「无以为」与「有以为」； 上仁「无以为」，上义「有以为」。 范本同此，傅本「上义」作「下义」，误。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 毕沅曰：「仍」，王弼作「扔」。 案说文解字：「仍，因也。 」扔亦因也，夏时有扔氏是此字。 谦之案：御注、遂州、邢玄、景福、庆阳、磻溪、楼正诸石本，严遵、傅奕、柰卷、室町、顾、彭诸本，皆作「仍」，范本作「扔」，作「扔」是也。 广雅曰：「扔，引也。 」，广韵曰：「扔，强牵引也。 」「扔」与「仍」音义同，但「扔」字从手，与攘臂之义合。 范曰：「揎袖出臂曰攘。 『扔』字，王弼与古本同，世本作『仍』，今从古本。 」 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 刘师培曰：案韩非解老篇云：「故曰：『失道而后失德，失德而后失仁，失仁而后失义，失义而后失礼。 』」据此文观之，则王本、河上本均脱四「失」字。 马叙伦曰：后汉书崔骃传注引无四字，朱穆传注引有。 辅行记一之三引更有「失礼而后智，失智而后信」两句，然各本及庄子知北游篇引并同此，又譣义亦不当有此两句及四「失」字。 夫礼者，忠信之薄，而乱之首。 严可均曰：「忠信之薄」，御注作「之簿」，下「不处其薄」亦然。 罗振玉曰：「首」下，景福本有「也」字。 谦之案：傅、范本、室町本亦有「也」字。 李翘曰：「庄子知北游篇引云『礼者道之华而乱之首也』，误合下为一句。 」 宋翔凤曰：老子着书以明黄帝自然之治，即礼运篇所谓「大道之行」，故先道德而后仁义。 孔子定六经，明禹、汤、文、武、周公之道，即礼运所谓「大道既隐，天下为家」，故中明仁义礼知，以救斯世。 故黄、老之学与孔子之传，相为表者也。 又曰：「夫礼者忠信之薄而乱之首也」，按此言世风之日漓也，道德仁义递降，而以礼为治民。 三千三百皆所以约束整齐其民，由忠信之既薄，而礼为治国之首。 乱，治也。 老子言礼，故孔子问礼。 谦之案：宋说辨矣，然未明学术源流，以「乱」训「治」。 证之经文六十四章「治之于未乱」，则「治」「乱」对文，此处不应独训「治」。 老子盖知礼而反礼者也，故曰：「处其厚，不处其薄。 」 前识者，道之华，而愚之始。 谦之案：韩非解老作「前识者，道之华也，而愚之首也」。 「前识」二字，严遵本作「前职」，注：「预设然也。 」据注知「职」为误字。 「愚之始」，傅本「始」作「首」，王弼注「道之华而愚之首」，是王本当亦作「首」。 范、柰卷作「始」。 又礼记曲礼正义引云：「礼者忠信之薄，道德之华，争愚之始。 」 易顺鼎曰：按所引「道」下有「德」字，「愚」上有「争」字。 窃谓「愚」当作「遇」，即书盘庚「暂遇奸宄」之「遇」，又即淮南「偶○智故」之「偶」。 吕氏春秋勿躬篇「幽诡愚险之言」，王氏经义述闻以为「愚」即「遇」。

「Virtue has its gradations above and below, yet its essence as *Wuwei* is singular. Though it does not lose its virtue, within the realm of *Wuwei*, there remains still a means of action. **Qian Zhi** notes: Mǎ’s reasoning is correct.

Chapter sixty-three states: *“Wuwei is done.”* It means *Wuwei* yet there is still a means of action. *“Shàngrén wéizhī ér wú yǐwéi”* (上仁为之而无以为), *“shàngyì wéizhī ér yǒu yǐwéi”* (上义为之而有以为). **Qian Zhi** notes: The preceding text takes *“wúwéi”* (无为) as its core, distinguishing *“wú yǐwéi”* (无以为) and *“yǒu yǐwéi”* (有以为); *Shàngdé* (上德) has *“wú yǐwéi”*, while *Xiàdé* (下德) has *“yǒu yǐwéi”*. This passage takes *“wéizhī”* (为之) as its core, distinguishing *“wú yǐwéi”* and *“yǒu yǐwéi”*; *Shàngrén* (上仁) has *“wú yǐwéi”*, while *Shàngyì* (上义) has *“yǒu yǐwéi”*.

The *Fàn* edition aligns with this, but the *Fù* edition changes *“shàngyì”* (上义) to *“xiàyì”* (下义), which is incorrect. *“Shànglǐ wéizhī ér mò zhī yìng”* (上礼为之而莫之应), then *“rǎng bì ér céng zhī”* (则攘臂而仍之). **Bì Qián** states: *“Céng”* (仍), the *Wáng Bì* edition renders as *“rēng”* (扔). **Qian Zhi** notes: The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) defines *“céng”* (仍) as *“to follow or persist”*. *“Rēng”* (扔) also means *“to persist”* or *“to follow”*, as seen in the *“Rēng Shì”* (扔氏) of the *Xià Shí* (夏时). **Qian Zhi** notes: The editions from *Yùzhù* (御注), *Suìzhōu* (遂州), *Xíng Xuán* (邢玄), *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pánxī* (磻溪), and *Lóuzhèng* (楼正) stone texts, as well as the copies by *Yán Zūn* (严遵), *Fù Yì* (傅奕), *Nài Juàn* (柰卷), *Shìtáng* (室町), *Gù* (顾), and *Péng* (彭), all render *“céng”* (仍). The *Fàn* edition renders *“rēng”* (扔), which is correct. The *Guǎng Yǎ* (广雅) states: *“Rēng”* (扔) means *“to pull or drag”*, and the *Guǎng Yùn* (广韵) defines it as *“to forcefully pull or drag”*. *“Rēng”* (扔) and *“céng”* (仍) share the same pronunciation and meaning, but *“rēng”* (扔) carries the radical *“shǒu”* (手, hand), aligning better with *“rǎng bì”* (攘臂, roll up one’s sleeves).

**Fàn** states: *“Rǎng bì”* (攘臂)—to roll up one’s sleeves and step forward—is *“rǎng”* (攘). *“Rēng”* (扔) is the same as the *Wáng Bì* edition and the ancient texts; the world’s editions render *“céng”* (仍). Now we follow the ancient texts.

Thus, one loses the *Dao* and then falls to virtue, loses virtue and then falls to *rén* (仁, benevolence), loses benevolence and then falls to *yì* (义, righteousness), loses righteousness and then falls to *lǐ* (礼, propriety). **Liú Shīpéi** states: The *Hán Fēizǐ* (韩非子) commentary on *Lǎozǐ* (老子) reads: *“Thus it is said: ‘One loses the *Dao* and then falls to losing virtue, loses virtue and then falls to losing benevolence, loses benevolence and then falls to losing righteousness, loses righteousness and then falls to losing propriety.’”* Observing this text, the *Wáng* (王) and *Héshàng* (河上) editions have omitted the four *“shī”* (失, lose) characters.

**Mǎ Xùlún** states: The *Hòuhànshū* (后汉书) commentary on *Cuī Jǐng* (崔骃) omits these four characters, while the commentary on *Zhū Mù* (朱穆) includes them. The *“Fǔxíng Jì”* (辅行记) in its third volume cites even more: *“失礼而后智，失智而后信”* (失义而后失礼, lose propriety and then falls to wisdom; lose wisdom and then falls to trustworthiness), but all editions and the *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子) *“Zhīběi Yóu”* (知北游) chapter’s citation match this passage. The *“jiān yì”* (譣义, variant reading) is also inappropriate, as these two additional sentences and the four *“shī”* (失) characters do not fit.

**“Lǐ”** (礼, propriety), as the thin veneer of *zhōngxīn* (忠信, loyalty and trustworthiness), is the origin of disorder. **Yán Kějūn** states: *“Zhōngxīn zhī bó”* (忠信之薄, the thinness of loyalty and trustworthiness), the *Yùzhù* (御注) renders as *“zhī bù”* (之簿). The same applies to *“bù chǔ qí bó”* (不处其薄, not dwelling in its thinness). **Luó Zhènyù** states: *“Shǒu”* (首, origin), the *Jǐngfú* (景福) edition adds *“yě”* (也, also).

**Qian Zhi** notes: The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions, as well as the *Shìtáng* (室町) edition, also include *“yě”* (也). **Lǐ Qiào** states: The *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子) *“Zhīběi Yóu”* (知北游) chapter’s citation reads *“Lǐ zhě, dào zhī huà ér luàn zhī shǒu yě”* (礼者，道之华而乱之首也, propriety is the adornment of the *Dao* and the origin of disorder), mistakenly merging the two sentences into one.

**Sòng Xiángfèng** states: The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) wrote this to elucidate the natural governance of the *Huángdì* (黄帝, Yellow Emperor), akin to the *“Lǐyùn”* (礼运) passage *“Dàdào zhī xíng”* (大道之行, the great *Dao* in action). Thus, it prioritizes *dào* (道, *Dao*/Way) and *dé* (德, virtue/power), followed by *rén* (仁, benevolence) and *yì* (义, righteousness). *Kǒngzǐ* (孔子, Confucius) established the *Liùjīng* (六经, Six Classics), expounding upon the *Dao* of *Yǔ* (禹, Yu), *Tāng* (汤, Tang), *Wén* (文, King Wen), *Wǔ* (武, King Wu), and *Zhōugōng* (周公, Duke Zhou), akin to the *“Lǐyùn”* passage *“Dàdào jì yǐn, tiānxià wéi jiā”* (大道既隐，天下为家, the great *Dao* having hidden, the world becomes a family). Thus, the middle part clarifies *rén* (仁), *yì* (义), *lǐ* (礼), and *zhī* (知, wisdom), to rescue this age.

Hence, the teachings of *Huáng* (黄, Yellow) and *Lǎo* (老, *Lǎozǐ*) complement those of *Kǒngzǐ* (孔子, Confucius). Moreover, he states: *“Lǐ zhě, zhōngxīn zhī bó ér luàn zhī shǒu yě”* (礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首也, propriety is the thin veneer of loyalty and trustworthiness and the origin of disorder), indicating that as social customs decay, the *Dao*, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness descend in order, and propriety becomes the means of governing the people. *Luàn* (乱) here means *treatment* or *regulation*. The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) spoke of *lǐ* (礼, propriety), hence *Kǒngzǐ* (孔子, Confucius) inquired about it.

**Qian Zhi** notes: Sòng’s argument is well-reasoned, yet it fails to clarify the source of the teachings, interpreting *“luàn”* (乱) as *“treatment”* or *“regulation”*. Referencing the *Lǐjì* (礼记) *“Lǐyùn”* (礼运) Chapter sixty-four *“Zhì zhī yú wèi luàn”* (治之于未乱, govern before disorder arises), *“zhì”* (治) and *“luàn”* (乱) are paired terms, so *“luàn”* (乱) here should not be interpreted alone as *“treatment”*.

The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) knew that *lǐ* (礼, propriety) was a superficial adornment of the *Dao* and the beginning of folly, thus he said: *“Chǔ qí hòu, bù chǔ qí bó”* (处其厚，不处其薄, dwell in its thickness, not in its thinness). *“Qiánzhì zhě, dào zhī huà ér yú zhī shǐ”* (前识者，道之华，而愚之始, wisdom is the adornment of the *Dao* and the origin of folly). **Qian Zhi** notes: The *Hán Fēizǐ* (韩非子) commentary on *Lǎozǐ* (老子) reads *“Qiánzhì zhě, dào zhī huà yě, ér yú zhī shǒu yě”* (前识者，道之华也，而愚之首也, wisdom is the adornment of the *Dao* and the origin of folly).

The characters *“qiánzhì”* (前识) are rendered *“qiánzhí”* (前职) by *Yán Zūn* (严遵), with the annotation *“preparatory and orderly”*. Based on the annotation, *“zhí”* (职) is a miswritten character. *“Yú zhī shǐ”* (愚之始, the origin of folly), the *Fù* (傅) edition changes *“shǐ”* (始) to *“shǒu”* (首), and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) annotates *“dào zhī huà ér yú zhī shǒu”* (道之华而愚之首, the adornment of the *Dao* and the origin of folly), indicating that the *Wáng* (王) edition also renders *“shǒu”* (首). The *Fàn* (范) and *Nài Juàn* (柰卷) editions render *“shǐ”* (始).

The *“Lǐjì”* (礼记) *“Qū Lǐ”* (曲礼) *“Zhèngyì”* (正义) annotation cites: *“Lǐ zhě, zhōngxīn zhī bó, dào dé zhī huà, zhēng yú zhī shǐ”* (礼者忠信之薄，道德之华，争愚之始, propriety is the thinness of loyalty and trustworthiness, the adornment of virtue and *Dao*, and the beginning of folly in contention). **Yì Shùndǐng** states: The cited text has *“dào”* (道) followed by *“dé”* (德), and *“zhēng”* (争) before *“yú”* (愚). I propose *“yú”* (愚) should be *“yù”* (遇, encounter), as in *“Shuō Pángēng”* (盘庚) *“zàn yù jiānmiè”* (暂遇奸宄, temporarily encountering deceitful and wicked people) and *“Huáinán”* (淮南) *“ǒu yù zhìgù”* (偶○智故, occasionally encountering wisdom). chunks.original_text: 「愚」、「遇」古字通用，知此书亦然矣。 愚之始，即邪伪之始也。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华。 故去彼取此。 严可均曰：河上作「处其厚不居其薄，处其实不居其华」。 王弼亦然。 谦之案：诸河上本有异同。 一河上本下两句并作「居」，室町本、傅、范本四句皆作「处」，孙盛老子疑问反训引同。 范应元曰：「韩非、严遵同古本。 一本下两句『处』作『居』。 」毕沅曰：「王符潜夫论作『不居其薄』，与王弼本同。 朱穆崇厚论引上二句作『处』，下二句作『居』。 」又「故去彼取此」，严本无「故」字，淮南道应训引此句同此石。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读无韵。 奚侗：首、始韵，薄、华韵。 李赓芸曰：按薄与华韵，首与始韵。 古读华如敷。 公羊哀四年「蒲社灾」，谷梁、左氏皆作「亳社」。 礼记郊特牲「薄社北牖」，释文云：「本又作亳。 」是「蒲」即「亳」之证也。 邓廷桢曰：薄、华为韵。 华古音读若荂，鱼、虞部字。 薄从溥声，则鱼、虞部之入声也。 右景龙碑一百二十九字，敦煌本，河、王本同，傅本一百三十一字，范本一百三十三字。 河上题「论德第三十八」，王本题「三十八章」，范本题「上德不德章第三十八」。 三十九章 昔之得一者：天得一以清，地得一以宁， 谦之案：「宁」字，绩语堂碑录因避清帝讳改为「宁」，今据原碑文改正，下同。 神得一以灵，谷得一以盈，万物得一以生， 严可均曰：「万物」，各本作「万物」。 罗振玉曰：敦煌戊本无此句。 谦之案：景福本、范本「万」亦作「万」。 又陈碧虚曰：「严君平本无『万物得之以生』，并下文『万物无以生将恐灭』十四字。 」 侯王得一以为天下正。 严可均曰：「天下正」，御注、王弼作「下贞」。 范应元曰：贞，正也。 王弼、郭云同古本。 一本「贞」作「正」，亦后人避讳也。 河上本作「侯王」。 谦之案：傅、范本、柰卷作「王侯」，群书治要、孙盛老子疑问反讯、晋书裴楷传、书钞一四九引并作「贞」，严遵、河上、顾欢、景福、楼正、庆阳、磻溪、室町及玉篇「一」字下引均作「正」，遂州本作「政」。 中都四子本此句作「以天下为正」。 王念孙曰：河上本「贞」作「正」，注云：「为天下平正。 」念孙案：尔雅曰：「正，长也。 」吕氏春秋君守篇「可以为天下正」，高注曰：「正，主也。 」「为天下正」，犹洪范言「为天下主」耳。 下文「天无以清」，「地无以宁」，即承上文「天得一以清，地得一以宁」言之。 又云「侯王无以贵高」，「贵高」二字正承「为天下正」言之，是「正」为君长之义，非平正之义也。 王弼本「正」作「贞」，借字耳。 东条一堂曰：「为天下贞」，按「贞」一本作「正」，与注乖。 下同。 贞观政要刑法第三十一引亦作「正」。 彭耜曰：「诸本贞作正，避庙讳。 」 易顺鼎曰：「贞」或作「正」，古字通用。 王氏读书杂志谓此「贞」为借字，似未尽然。 易「贞胜者也」，韩注引老子曰：「王侯得一以为天下贞。 」王弼周易略例：「制天下之动者，贞夫一者也。 」邢注引老子亦作「贞」。 文选王元长曲水诗序注引亦作「贞」。 是「贞」为本字。 劳健曰：「侯王得一以为天下贞」，「贞」字景龙、景福作「正」，开元、傅、范与诸王本皆作「贞」。
chunks.translated_text:
「愚」 and 「遇」 were interchangeable in ancient usage—this text follows that tradition as well. **The beginning of foolishness is the beginning of deceit.** Thus, the true gentleman dwells in substance, not in adornment; he rests in reality, not in superficiality. Therefore, he rejects the latter and embraces the former.

**Yán Kějūn** notes: The *Héshàng* text reads, *“dwell in substance, not in superficiality; rest in reality, not in adornment.”* **Wáng Bì** concurs. **Qiān Zhī** observes: The *Héshàng* manuscripts vary—some render both latter clauses with *“reside”* (居), while the *Shitōchō*, *Fù*, and *Fàn* versions use *“dwell”* (处) in all four clauses. **Sūn Shèng’s** *Old and New Doubts on Laozi* also follows this pattern. **Fàn Yìngyuán** states: *“Hán Fēi* and *Yán Zhūn* align with the ancient text, though one variant renders the latter clauses with *“reside”* (居).* **Bì Yàn** remarks: *Wáng Fú’s* *Hidden Talents* reads *“not reside in superficiality,”* matching *Wáng Bì’s* version. **Zhū Mù’s** *Exalting Thickness* cites the first two clauses with *“dwell”* (处) and the latter two with *“reside”* (居).

Furthermore, *“therefore, he rejects the latter and embraces the former”*—**Yán Zhūn’s** text omits *“therefore”* (故). The *Huáinán* *Dàoyìng* commentary cites this sentence identically.

---
**[Phonology & Rhyme]**
This chapter lacks rhyme in *Jiāng Shì’s* readings. **Xí Dòng** notes: *“Chief/beginning”* (首/始) and *“thin/adornment”* (薄/华) form rhymes. **Lǐ Qióngyún** confirms: *“Thin”* (薄) and *“adornment”* (华) rhyme, as do *“chief”* (首) and *“beginning”* (始). In ancient pronunciation, *“adornment”* (华) was pronounced like *“spread”* (敷). The *Gōngyáng* *Āi* *Sìnián* records *“Púshè zāi”* (蒲社灾), while *Gǔliáng* and *Zuǒshì* render it *“Bìshè”* (亳社). The *Lǐjì* *Jiāotèshēng* *“Bóshè běi yǒu”* (薄社北牖) has the *Shìwén* annotation: *“Also written as ‘Bì’ (亳).”* This confirms *“Pú”* (蒲) as an alternate for *“Bì”* (亳). **Dèng Tíngzhēn** states: *“Thin”* (薄) and *“adornment”* (华) form a rhyme. *“Adornment”* (华) in ancient pronunciation was akin to *“lín”* (荂), belonging to the *Yú* (鱼) and *Yú* (虞) phonetic groups. *“Thin”* (薄), derived from *“pǔ”* (溥), thus belongs to the *Yú* (鱼) and *Yú* (虞) entering tones.

---
The *Jìnglóng* stele contains **129 characters** (consistent in *Dūnhuáng*, *Hé*, and *Wáng* manuscripts), while the *Fù* version has **131** and the *Fàn* version **133**. The *Héshàng* heading reads *“Chapter 38: On Virtue”* (论德第三十八), the *Wáng* version *“Chapter 38”* (三十八章), and the *Fàn* version *“Chapter 38: On the Supreme Virtue Not Being Virtue”* (上德不德章第三十八).

---
**Chapter 39: Those of old who attained the One**
Heaven, having attained the One, became clear;
Earth, having attained the One, became tranquil;
The *Spirit* (*shén*), having attained the One, became responsive;
The valleys, having attained the One, became full;
All things, having attained the One, came to life;
**Qiān Zhī** notes: The character *“宁”* (ning) in the *Jìfú* stele was altered to *“宁”* (also ning) to avoid the Qing emperor’s taboo; here, it is restored to the original *“宁”* (as in tranquility), consistent with the stele’s text below.

**Yán Kějūn** states: *“All things”* (万物) is the standard reading. **Luó Zhènyù** notes: The *Dūnhuáng* *Wù* manuscript omits this sentence. **Qiān Zhī** observes: The *Jìngfú* and *Fàn* versions also render *“万”* (wàn) as *“万”* (wàn). Additionally, **Chén Bìxū** asserts: *“Yán Jūnping’s* text lacks *“All things, having attained the One, came to life”* (万物得一以生) and the following *“All things, without the One, would perish”* (万物无以生将恐灭), totaling **14 characters** omitted.

The sovereigns and lords, having attained the One, **established rectitude for the world** (*wéi tiānxià zhèng*).
**Yán Kějūn** notes: The *Yùzhù* and *Wáng Bì* versions render *“下贞”* (xiàzhēn, “below as the true”). **Fàn Yìngyuán** explains: *“Zhēn”* (贞) means *“zhèng”* (正, rectitude). *Wáng Bì* and *Guō* follow the ancient text, though one variant renders *“zhēn”* (贞) as *“zhèng”* (正), likely due to taboo avoidance. The *Héshàng* version reads *“sovereigns and lords”* (侯王). **Qiān Zhī** observes: The *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Nài* manuscripts, as well as *Qúnshū Zhìyào*, **Sūn Shèng’s** *Old and New Doubts on Laozi*, the *Jìnshū* *Kǎi’ài* biography, and *Shūcháo* **149** all render it *“zhēn”* (贞). **Yán Zhūn**, *Héshàng*, *Gùhuān*, *Jìngfú*, *Lóuzhèng*, *Qìngyáng*, *Pányuān*, *Shitōchō*, and *Yùpiàn* under the *“一”* (yī) radical all cite *“zhèng”* (正), while the *Zhuōzhōu* version renders it *“zhèng”* (政). The *Zhōngdū Sìzǐ* manuscript reads *“with the world as rectitude”* (以天下为正). **Wáng Niánsūn** argues: The *Héshàng* version renders *“zhēn”* (贞) as *“zhèng”* (正), with the annotation *“to make the world orderly.”* **Niánsūn** further notes: The *Ěryá* states *“zhèng”* (正) means *“long”* (长). The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* *“Jūnshǒu”* (君守) passage *“can establish rectitude for the world”* (可以为天下正), with **Gāo Yáng’s** annotation *“zhèng”* (正) meaning *“master”* (主). *“To establish rectitude for the world”* (为天下正) is akin to the *Hóngfàn* statement *“to be master over the world”* (为天下主). The subsequent lines *“Heaven, without the One, would not be clear”* (天无以清) and *“Earth, without the One, would not be tranquil”* (地无以宁) echo the earlier *“Heaven, having attained the One, became clear”* (天得一以清) and *“Earth, having attained the One, became tranquil”* (地得一以宁). Further, *“sovereigns and lords, without the One, would not be noble and exalted”* (侯王无以贵高) directly follows *“to establish rectitude for the world”* (为天下正), proving *“zhèng”* (正) carries the meaning *“sovereign/master,”* not *“orderly.”* **Wáng Bì’s** version renders *“zhēn”* (贞), a borrowed character. **Dōngtiáo Yītáng** notes: *“To establish rectitude for the world”* (为天下贞) has a variant *“zhèng”* (正), conflicting with the annotation. The same applies below. The *Zhèngguān Zhèngyào* *“Xíngfǎ”* (刑法) **31** also renders it *“zhèng”* (正). **Péng Zhì** states: All manuscripts render *“zhēn”* (贞) as *“zhèng”* (正) to avoid taboo. **Yì Shùndǐng** notes: *“Zhēn”* (贞) and *“zhèng”* (正) were interchangeable in ancient usage. **Wángshì Shūshū Zházhì** claims *“zhēn”* (贞) is a borrowed character, though this is not entirely accurate. The *Yì* *“Zhēn shèng zhě yě”* (贞胜者也) cites Laozi: *“The sovereigns and lords, having attained the One, established rectitude for the world”* (王侯得一以为天下贞). **Wáng Bì’s** *Zhōuyì Lièlì* states: *“What governs all movement under Heaven is the One, established as true.”* **Xíng Yǐng’s** annotation on Laozi also renders it *“zhēn”* (贞). The *Wénxuǎn* *“Wáng Yuáncháng’s** *Qúshuǐ Shī Xù*” annotation likewise cites *“zhēn”* (贞). Thus, *“zhēn”* (贞) is the original character. **Láo Jiàn** notes: *“The sovereigns and lords, having attained the One, established rectitude for the world”* (侯王得一以为天下贞) renders *“zhēn”* (贞) as *“zhèng”* (正) in the *Jìnglóng* and *Jìngfú* versions, while the *Kāiyuán*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Zhūwáng* manuscripts retain *“zhēn”* (贞).

chunks.original_text: 范注：「贞，正也。 一本作正，后人避讳也。 」按道藏御注、御疏本原作「正」，疏云：「本或作贞字，贞即正也。 」开元石刻乃改从「贞」，范云「后人避讳」，非也。 又此章凡「侯王」字，傅、范亦作「王侯」，非也。 诸唐本、诸王本、河上本皆作「侯王」，与「贞」字自谐句中韵。 谦之案：作「贞」是也。 易系辞曰：「天下之动，贞夫一者也。 」又曰：「言致其一也。 」老子此章言「侯王得一以为天下贞」下，傅、范及释文下有「其致之一也」，与易义均合。 又柰卷及大阪图书馆旧钞本，均作「天下贞」，狩野直喜谓：「河上公本亦有作『贞』者，盖自宋刻避帝讳改『贞』作『正』。 」今证之以景龙碑文，知「贞」「正」二字古通用，而避讳之说亦非。 天无以清，将恐裂； 地无以宁，将恐发； 谦之案：碑文与罗卷此均作「无」，不作「无」，为变例。 武内法京敦乙本作「无」。 又庄子至乐篇：「天无为以之清，地无为以之宁。 」语意本此。 刘师培曰：「发」读为「废」。 说文：「废，屋顿也。 」淮南子览冥训「四极废」，高注：「废，顿也。 」左传定三年「废于炉炭」，杜注：「废，坠也。 」顿坠之义，与倾圮同。 恐发者，犹言将崩圮也，即地倾之义。 「发」为「废」字之省形。 蒋锡昌曰：刘说是。 庄子列御寇「先生既来，曾不发药乎」，释文：「发，司马本作废。 」列子黄帝篇引作「废」。 又缮性「非藏其智而不发也」，御览逸民部引作「废」。 左传哀十一年疏引竹书纪年云：「梁惠王废逢忌之薮以赐民。 」汉书地理志引作「发」。 均其证也。 「发」「废」双声，故可通用。 此言天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐废也。 神无以灵，将恐歇； 谷无以盈，将恐竭； 毕沅曰：「竭」，河上公、王弼并作「歇」，案应作「竭」。 谦之案：河上公、王弼并作「竭」，上句作「歇」，毕误校。 「歇」，说文：「息也。 一曰气越泄也。 」广雅释诂二：「歇，泄也。 」七发：「精神越泄，百病咸生。 」「竭」借为「渴」，「渴，尽也，从水，曼声。 」尔雅释诂：「涸，渴也。 」经传多以「竭」为之，是竭有涸尽之义。 周语「伊、洛竭而夏亡」，注：「涸也。 」淮南说林：「渊泉不能竭。 」本经：「竭泽而渔。 」河上注此：「言谷当有盈缩虚实，不可但欲盈满无已时，将恐枯竭不为谷。 」「竭」与「渴」同义，不必改字。 万物无以生，将恐灭； 罗振玉曰：敦煌本无此句。 侯王无以贵高，将恐蹶。 武内义雄曰：景、遂、敦三本「侯王」与上文合，下又同。 景、遂二本「贵高」，敦本无「高」字，然下文「贵高」并称，有「高」字是。 罗振玉曰：敦煌本「贞」下有「而」字。 谦之案：此句疑有误文。 诸河、王本、顾欢本、磻溪、景福、楼正、室町、柰卷句同此。 范本作「王侯无以为贞，将恐溪」，高翿作「侯王无以贞而贵高，将恐蹶」，傅奕作「王侯无以为贞而贵高，将恐溪」，彭耜，赵孟俯同傅本，惟「王侯」作「侯王」。 严遵同彭本，惟「无以为贞」作「无以为正」。 皆川愿老子绎解又与严遵同。 刘师培曰：案上文「天无以清」，「地无以宁」，「神无以灵」，「谷无以盈」，「万物无以生」，均承上「以清」、「以宁」、「以盈」、「以生」言，惟此句「无以贵高」与上「以为天下贞」不相应，疑「贵」即「贞」字之讹。
chunks.translated_text:
「Fàn Zhù’s annotation states: *“Zhēn (贞) is zhèng (正). One version originally had zhèng (正), but later scholars altered it to avoid taboo.”* According to the **Dàozàng** *Yùzhù* and *Yùshū* editions, the original text was *“zhèng”* (正), with the *shū* (疏) remarking: *“The original may have been written as ‘zhēn’ (贞), but zhēn (贞) is indeed zhèng (正).”* The **Kāiyuán** stone carving, however, later changed to *“zhēn”* (贞), and Fàn’s claim that *“later scholars altered it to avoid taboo”* is incorrect.

Again, in this chapter, whenever *“hóuwáng”* (侯王) appears, **Fù Yì** and **Fàn Zhù** render it as *“wáng hóu”* (王侯), which is incorrect. All **Táng** editions, **Róshàng Gōng**’s version, and the **Héshàng** edition retain *“hóuwáng”* (侯王), harmonizing with *“zhēn”* (贞) in the parallel rhyme structure of the passage. **Qiān Zhī** confirms: *“Zhēn (贞) is correct.”*

The *Yì Jìxù* states: *“All movement under Heaven is governed by establishing the One.”* It further says: *“This is to speak of attaining the One.”* In this passage of **Láozi**, *“hóuwáng dé yī wéi tiānxià zhēn”* (侯王得一以为天下贞), **Fù Yì**, **Fàn Zhù**, and the **Shìwén** annotation all include *“qí zhì zhī yī yě”* (其致之一也), aligning perfectly with the *Yì*’s meaning.

Moreover, the **Luó** manuscripts and the **Osaka Túshūguǎn**’s old transcribed copy both read *“tiānxià zhēn”* (天下贞). **Shòuyě Zhíxǐ** notes: *“Even **Róshàng Gōng**’s version originally had ‘zhēn’ (贞), but the **Sòng** editions altered ‘zhēn’ (贞) to ‘zhèng’ (正) to avoid taboo against the word ‘empire.’”* Now, verified by the **Jǐnglóng** stele text, we know *“zhēn”* (贞) and *“zhèng”* (正) were interchangeably used in antiquity, and the taboo-avoidance theory is also incorrect.

**Qiān Zhī** notes: The stele text and **Luó**’s version both read *“wú”* (无), not *“wú”* (无) with a dot, as a variant case.

**Wǔnèi Fǎjīng**’s *Dūnyǐ* edition renders it as *“wú”* (无) with a dot. Additionally, in **Zhuāngzi**’s *Zhìlè* chapter: *“The **Tian** (天) does not act yet attains clarity, the **Dì** (地) does not act yet attains tranquility.”* The meaning originates here.

**Liú Shīpèi** states: *“Fā (发) should be read as ‘fèi’ (废).”* The *Shuōwén* explains: *“Fèi (废), a house collapsing. One meaning: ‘fèi’ (废) as exhaustion.”* **Huáinánzǐ**’s *Lànmíng Xùn* uses *“sìjí fèi”* (四极废), with **Gāo Zhù** annotating: *“Fèi (废), exhaustion.”* The *Zhuǎnzǐng*’s *Dìng Sānnián* (定三年) uses *“fèi yú lú tàn”* (废于炉炭), with **Dù Zhù** explaining: *“Fèi (废), to fall.”* The meaning of exhaustion aligns with *“qīnghuī”* (倾圮). *“Jiāng tè fèi” (将恐发) is akin to saying *“jiāng tè bēnghuī”* (将崩圮), meaning the earth would collapse. *“Fā” (发) is the abbreviated form of *“fèi” (废).* **Jiǎng Xīchāng** agrees with **Liú Shīpèi**’s view. In **Zhuāngzi**’s *Lièyǔkòu* (列御寇), the annotation reads: *“Fā (发), Sīmǎ (司马) renders as ‘fèi’ (废).”* **Lièzǐ**’s *Huángdì* (黄帝) chapter cites it as *“fèi” (废).* The **Shìxìng** (缮性) text states: *“Not concealing one’s wisdom without letting it manifest”* (非藏其智而不发也), and the **Yùguǎn** (御览) *Yìmín* (逸民) section cites it as *“fèi” (废).* The *Zhuǎnzǐng*’s *Āi Shíyīnián* (哀十一年) annotation, quoting *Zhúshū Jìnián* (竹书纪年), states: *“Liáng Huìwáng fèi fèngjì zhī suǒ yǐ cì mín”* (梁惠王废逢忌之薮以赐民), while the **Hànshū** *Dìlǐ Zhì* (地理志) cites it as *“fā” (发).* These serve as further evidence. *“Fā” (发) and *“fèi” (废)* share the same initial consonant, hence their interchangeability.

This passage states: *“If the **Tian** (天) lacks clarity, it will fear collapse; if the **Dì** (地) lacks tranquility, it will fear exhaustion.”*

*“If the **Shén** (神) lacks vitality, it will fear cessation; if the **Gǔ** (谷) lacks fullness, it will fear depletion.”* **Bì Qián** remarks: *“Jié” (竭), **Róshàng Gōng** and **Wáng Bì** both render as *“xiē”* (歇), but it should be *“jié”* (竭).* **Qiān Zhī** confirms: *“**Róshàng Gōng** and **Wáng Bì** both render *“jié”* (竭), but the preceding sentence reads *“xiē”* (歇), indicating **Bì Qián**’s correction is erroneous.*

The *Shuōwén* defines *“xiē”* (歇) as *“rest” or “exhaustion of breath.”* **Guǎngyǎ**’s *Shìgǔ* (释诂) II explains: *“Xiē (歇), exhaustion.”* In the *Qīfā* (七发): *“When vital breath is exhausted, all diseases arise.”* *“Jié” (竭)* is borrowed as *“kě”* (渴), meaning *“exhaustion” (from water), with the sound ‘màn’ (曼).”* The *Ēryǎ* (尔雅) *Shìgǔ* (释诂) states: *“Gù (涸), exhaustion.”* Classical texts often use *“jié”* (竭) for this meaning, indicating *“jié”* (竭) carries the sense of *“gù”* (涸) and *“jìn”* (尽). The *Zhōuyǔ* (周语) *“Yī, Luò jié ér Xià wáng”* (伊、洛竭而夏亡) is annotated as *“gù”* (涸). The **Huáinánzǐ** *Shuōlín* (说林) states: *“Deep springs cannot be exhausted.”* The **Běnjīng** (本经) says: *“Exhaust the marsh and fish.”* **Róshàng Gōng**’s annotation here reads: *“The **Gǔ** (谷) should have periods of fullness and emptiness, but if one only desires it to be perpetually full without limit, it will fear drying up and ceasing to be a marsh.”* *“Jié” (竭)* shares the same meaning as *“kě”* (渴), requiring no alteration.

*“If all things lack the means to flourish, they will fear annihilation.”* **Luó Zhènyù** notes: The **Dūnhuáng** edition omits this sentence.

*“If the **Hóuwáng** (侯王) lack the means to attain noble virtue, they will fear downfall.”* **Wǔnèi Yìxióng** observes: The **Jǐng** (景), **Suì** (遂), and **Dūn** (敦) three editions render *“Hóuwáng”* (侯王) consistently with the preceding text, and the latter part also aligns. The **Jǐng** (景) and **Suì** (遂) editions both have *“guì gāo”* (贵高), while the **Dūn** (敦) edition omits *“gāo”* (高); yet, the latter part refers to *“guì gāo”* (贵高) together, so *“gāo”* (高) should be retained. **Luó Zhènyù** notes: The **Dūnhuáng** edition has *“zhēn”* (贞) followed by *“ér”* (而). **Qiān Zhī** suggests: *“This sentence likely contains textual errors.”*

All **Héshàng** (河上), **Wáng** (王) editions, **Gùhuān** (顾欢) edition, **Pánxī** (磻溪), **Jǐngfú** (景福), **Lóuzhèng** (楼正), **Shìtóng** (室町), **Luó** (罗) manuscripts, and **Nǐjuàn** (柰卷) versions follow this reading. **Fàn Zhù**’s edition reads: *“Wáng hóu wú yǐ wéi zhēn, jiāng tè xī”* (王侯无以为贞，将恐溪). **Gāo Yì** (高翿) renders: *“Hóuwáng wú yǐ zhēn ér guì gāo, jiāng tè jué”* (侯王无以贞而贵高，将恐蹶). **Fù Yì** (傅奕) reads: *“Wáng hóu wú yǐ wéi zhēn ér guì gāo, jiāng tè xī”* (王侯无以为贞而贵高，将恐溪). **Péng Zhì** (彭耜) and **Zhào Méngfǔ** (赵孟俯) agree with **Fù Yì**’s edition, except *“Wáng hóu”* (王侯) is rendered as *“Hóuwáng”* (侯王). **Yán Zūn** (严遵) follows **Péng Zhì**’s version, but *“wú yǐ wéi zhēn”* (无以为贞) is rendered as *“wú yǐ wéi zhèng”* (无以为正). All align with **Chuān Yùn Láozi**’s *Yìjiě* (绎解) and **Yán Zūn**’s interpretation.

**Liú Shīpèi** argues: *“The preceding sentences—‘Tian wú yǐ qīng’ (天无以清), ‘Dì wú yǐ níng’ (地无以宁), ‘Shén wú yǐ líng’ (神无以灵), ‘Gǔ wú yǐ yíng’ (谷无以盈), ‘Wànwù wú yǐ shēng’ (万物无以生)—all follow the structure ‘wú yǐ [verb]’ (无以[动词]). However, this sentence ‘wú yǐ guì gāo’ (无以贵高) does not correspond with the preceding ‘wéi tiānxià zhēn’ (以为天下贞), suggesting ‘guì’ (贵) may be a corrupted form of ‘zhēn’ (贞).”*
chunks.overlap_context: ed as true.”* **Xíng Yǐng’s** annotation on Laozi also renders it *“zhēn”* (贞). The *Wénxuǎn* *“Wáng Yuáncháng’s** *Qúshuǐ Shī Xù*” annotation likewise cites *“zhēn”* (贞). Thus, *“zhēn”* (贞) is the original character. **Láo Jiàn** notes: *“The sovereigns and lords, having attained the One, established rectitude for the world”* (侯王得一以为天下贞) renders *“zhēn”* (贞) as *“zhèng”* (正) in the *Jìnglóng* and *Jìngfú* versions, while the *Kāiyuán*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Zhūwáng* manuscripts retain *“zhēn”* (贞).

chunks.original_text: 「贵」、「贞」形近，后人据此节王注有「清不足贵」诸文，遂改「贞」为「贵」，又疑「贵高」并文，与下「贵高」二语相应，遂于「贵」下增「高」字，实则「贵」当作「贞」，「高」乃衍文也。 易顺鼎曰：当作「侯王无以贞，将恐蹶」，「贞」误为「贵」。 后人见下文「贵以贱为本，高以下为基」二句，以为承上文而言，妄于「贵」下又加「高」字，遂致踵讹袭谬，而义理不可通矣。 谦之案：「将恐溪」，诸王本「溪」作「蹶」。 说文：「蹶，僵也，从足，厥声。 一曰跳也，亦读若。 」广韵：「蹶，失脚也，僵也，亦作溪。 」广雅释诂三：「溪，败也。 」吕览慎行「小人之行，不溪于山」，注：「溪踬颠顿也。 」荀子成相「国乃溪」，注：「颠覆也。 」「侯王无以贞，将恐溪」，言侯王无以为贞，将恐颠覆失其位也。 治要引作「溪」，夏竦古文四声韵卷五引古老子亦作「溪」。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 严可均曰：「高以下为基」，御注脱「为」字，河上「高」下有「必」字。 宇惠曰：齐策「贵以」「高以」上并有「虽」字。 谦之案：景福、室町、柰卷、顾欢诸本及淮南道应训、群书治要、意林引二「以」上均有「必」字。 淮南原道训：「是故贵者必以贱为号，而高者必以下为基。 」语亦本此。 是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂， 严可均曰：「不毂」，王弼作「不谷」。 河上云：「不毂，喻不能如车毂为众辐所凑。 」四十二章「不毂」亦然。 谦之案：「侯王」，傅、范作「王侯」，文选雪赋注引作「王公」。 「自谓」，景福本「谓」作「曰」，彭耜、范应元、赵孟俯、室町、柰卷及治要引作「称」。 易顺鼎曰：按「自谓」当作「自称」。 四十二章云：「人之所恶，唯孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 」则此亦必作「称」也。 淮南高注正作「称」，文选邱希范与陈伯之书注引此作「王侯自称孤、寡、不谷」，皆其证。 洪颐烜曰：德经「是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂」，案礼记曲礼「于内自称曰不谷」，郑注：「谷，善也。 」左氏僖四年传「岂不谷是为」，杜预注：「孤、寡、不毂，诸侯谦辞。 」字皆作「谷」。 列子天瑞篇「鹯之为布毂」，释文：「毂，本又作谷。 」此「毂」为「谷」之借字，河上注读为「车毂」之毂，失之。 徐鼒曰：老子法：本章「是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂」，河上章句云：「不毂，喻不能如车毂为众辐所凑。 」「道化」章「人之所恶，唯孤、寡、不毂，而王公以为称」，章句云：「孤、寡、不毂，不祥之名。 」鼒谓「不祥」说是，「不能如车毂」之说乃是望文生义，非古训也。 「毂」与「谷」通。 诗正月「蔌蔌方有谷」，后汉书蔡邕传作「速速方毂」。 列子天瑞篇「鹯之为布毂」，释文云：「本又作谷。 」吕览观表篇「卫右宰谷臣」，文选刘孝标广绝交论注作「毂臣」。 盖音近假借之字也。 按「毂」之言善也，郑注曲礼用之，言己之不善，谦词也。 又「谷」之言禄也，高诱注淮南人间训用之，犹言不禄也，亦谦词也。 又王弼本亦作「谷」。 谦之案：孤、寡、不谷，谦辞是也。 吕览君守篇「君名孤、寡，而不可障壅」，高注：「孤、寡，人君之谦辞也。 」碑本「不谷」作「不毂」，「毂」，此借为「谷」。
chunks.translated_text:
「Guì」 and 「zhēn」 share similar forms; later scholars, noting the passage in Wang Bi’s commentary—*"qīng bùzú guì"* (清不足贵)—altered 「zhēn」 to 「guì». Suspecting that 「guì gāo」 (贵高) was a redundant phrase, they further added 「gāo」 (高) beneath 「guì」 (贵) to align with the subsequent 「guì gāo」 (贵高). Yet in truth, 「guì」 (贵) should read as 「zhēn」 (贞), while 「gāo」 (高) is a superfluous insertion.

Yì Shùndǐng (易顺鼎) argues: It should read *“Hóuwáng wú yǐ zhēn, jiāng kǒng jué”* (侯王无以贞，将恐蹶), with 「zhēn」 (贞) mistakenly taken as 「guì」 (贵). Later scholars, seeing the following lines *“guì yǐ jiàn wéi běn, gāo yǐ xià wéi jī”* (贵以贱为本，高以下为基), assumed they followed the preceding text and arbitrarily added 「gāo」 (高) beneath 「guì」 (贵), thereby perpetuating the error and rendering the meaning incoherent.

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes: *“Jiāng kǒng xī”* (将恐溪) is rendered as *“jiāng kǒng jué”* (将恐蹶) in the **Zhūwáng** (诸王) edition. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) defines *“jué”* (蹶) as *“jiāng”* (僵, stiff), from the foot radical with the phonetic *guì* (厥). It also states: *“One reading: tiào”* (跳, leap), also pronounced as *“xī”* (溪). The *Guǎngyùn* (广韵) defines *“jué”* (蹶) as *“shī jiǎo”* (失脚, stumble) or *“jiāng”* (僵, stiff), also written as *“xī”* (溪). The *Guǎngyá Shìgǔ* (广雅释诂) explains *“xī”* (溪) as *“bài”* (败, ruin). In *Lǚshì* (吕览) *Shènháng* (慎行), *“xiǎorén zhī xíng, bù xī yú shān”* (小人之行，不溪于山), the commentary reads: *“Xī”* (溪) means *“tīng zhì diān dùn”* (踬踬颠顿, stumbling and falling). In *Xúnzǐ* (荀子) *Chéngxiàng* (成相), *“guó nǎi xī”* (国乃溪), the commentary states: *“Diānfù”* (颠覆, overturn). Thus *“Hóuwáng wú yǐ zhēn, jiāng kǒng xī”* (侯王无以贞，将恐溪) means: *“If lords and kings lack integrity (zhēn), they risk ruin and losing their position.”* The *Húnán Dàoshàng Xuányì* (淮南道应训) and *Qúnshū Zhìyào* (群书治要) both cite *“xī”* (溪), while *Xià Jùn* (夏竦) in *Gǔwén Sìshēngyùn* (古文四声韵) and *Gǔ Lǎozǐ* (古老子) also use *“xī”* (溪).

Hence, *“guì yǐ jiàn wéi běn, gāo yǐ xià wéi jī”* (贵以贱为本，高以下为基). **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes that the imperial commentary omits the *“wéi”* (为) beneath *“gāo”* (高), while the **Héshàng** (河上) version includes *“bì”* (必) beneath *“gāo”* (高). **Yǔ Huì** (宇惠) observes that in *Qíshì* (齐策), *“guì yǐ”* (贵以) and *“gāo yǐ”* (高以) are both preceded by *“suī”* (虽). **Qián Zhī** (谦之) further notes that in editions like *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Shìtōng* (室町), *Nǎijuǎn* (柰卷), *Gùhuān* (顾欢), as well as in *Húnán Dàoshàng Xuányì* (淮南道应训) and *Qúnshū Zhìyào* (群书治要), the *“yǐ”* (以) is preceded by *“bì”* (必). The *Húnán Yuándào Xuàn* (淮南原道训) states: *“Shìgù guìzhě bì yǐ jiàn wéi hào, ér gāozhě bì yǐ xià wéi jī”* (是故贵者必以贱为号，而高者必以下为基), which aligns with this passage.

Thus, *“Hóuwáng zì wèi gū, guǎ, bù gǔ”* (侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂). **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes that **Wáng Bì** (王弼) renders *“bù gǔ”* (不毂) as *“bù gǔ”* (不谷). The **Héshàng** (河上) commentary explains: *“Bù gǔ”* (不毂) signifies *“bù néng rú chē gǔ wéi zhòng fú suǒ còu”* (不能如车毂为众辐所凑, unable to serve as the hub for all spokes). The same term appears in Chapter 42. **Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes that *“Hóuwáng”* (侯王) is rendered as *“Wánghóu”* (王侯) in the **Fù** (傅) and **Fàn** (范) editions, while the *Wénxuàn Xuěfù* (文选雪赋) annotation cites it as *“Wánggōng”* (王公). The term *“zì wèi”* (自谓) is rendered as *“wèi”* (谓) in the *Jǐngfú* (景福) edition, and as *“chēng”* (称) in the **Péng Zhì** (彭耜), **Fàn Yìngyuán** (范应元), **Zhào Méngfǔ** (赵孟俯), *Shìtōng* (室町), *Nǎijuǎn* (柰卷), and *Zhìyào* (治要) versions. **Yì Shùndǐng** (易顺鼎) argues that *“zì wèi”* (自谓) should read *“zì chēng”* (自称). In Chapter 42, it states: *“Rén zhī suǒ wù, wéi gū, guǎ, bù gǔ, ér wánggōng wéi chēng”* (人之所恶，唯孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称). Thus, this passage must also read *“chēng”* (称). The *Húnán Gāo Zhù* (淮南高注) correctly uses *“chēng”* (称), and the *Wénxuàn Qiū Xīfàn yǔ Chén Bózī shū* (文选邱希范与陈伯之书) annotation cites it as *“Wánghóu zì chēng gū, guǎ, bù gǔ”* (王侯自称孤、寡、不谷), serving as further evidence.

**Hóng Yìxuǎn** (洪颐烜) notes: In the *Déjīng* (德经), *“Shìyǐ hóuwáng zì wèi gū, guǎ, bù gǔ”* (是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂), while the *Lǐjì Qūlǐ* (礼记曲礼) states *“Yú nèi zì chēng yuē bù gǔ”* (于内自称曰不谷), with **Zhèng Xùn** (郑玄) commenting: *“Gǔ”* (谷), meaning *“shàn”* (善, good). In the *Zuǒshī Lìsìnián Zhuan* (左氏僖四年传), *“Qǐ bù gǔ shì wéi”* (岂不谷是为), **Dù Yǔ** (杜预) annotates: *“Gū, guǎ, bù gǔ, zhūhóu qiáncí”* (孤、寡、不毂，诸侯谦辞). The character is consistently written as *“gǔ”* (谷). In *Lièzǐ Tiānrú Piān* (列子天瑞篇), *“yuān zhī wéi bù gǔ”* (鹯之为布毂), the *Shìwén* (释文) states: *“Gǔ”* (毂) is also written as *“gǔ”* (谷). **Héshàng** (河上) mistakenly reads *“gǔ”* (毂) as *“chē gǔ”* (车毂, wheel hub).

**Xú Dǐ** (徐鼒) argues: According to the *Lǎozǐ Fǎ* (老子法), in this chapter *“Shìyǐ hóuwáng zì wèi gū, guǎ, bù gǔ”* (是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不毂), the **Héshàng Zhāngjù** (河上章句) states: *“Bù gǔ”* (不毂) *“yù shì bù néng rú chē gǔ wéi zhòng fú suǒ còu”* (喻不能如车毂为众辐所凑). The *Hou Han Shu* biography of **Cài Yōng** (后汉书蔡邕传) reads *“sùsù fāng gǔ”* (速速方毂), with the annotation: *“Gǔ”* (毂) means *“lù”* (禄). Since *“gǔ”* (谷) also means *“lù”* (禄), it is clear that *“bù gǔ”* (不毂) is the same as *“bù gǔ”* (不谷). Though *“gǔ”* (谷) is glossed as *“lù”* (禄), *“bù gǔ”* (不谷) does not carry the exact meaning of *“bù lù”* (unblessed). This is a regional dialect, akin to *“pú”* (仆, servant).

**Zhāng Bǐnglín** (章炳麟) states:
*“Zì chēng yuē pú”* (自称曰仆), originally meaning *“chénpú”* (臣仆, subject-servant), also carries the connotation of *“duǎn”* (short, humble). When nobles refer to themselves as *“bù gǔ”* (不谷), *“bù gǔ”* (不谷) is a phonetic fusion of *“pú”* (仆). The *Húnán Rénjiān Xuàn* (淮南人间训) annotation reads: *“Bù gǔ, bù lù yě”* (不谷，不禄也), but this is an instance of *“wàng wén shēng xuàn”* (望文生训, etymological fallacy). The ancients would not have used *“bù lù”* (unblessed) to refer to themselves in death. Further discussion is found in *Xīn Fāngyán* (新方言).

Is this then treating *“jiàn”* (贱, lowliness) as the foundation? **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) says: *“Fēi”* (非), with the original manuscripts reading *“fēi hū”* (非乎).

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes:
The phrase *“cǐ qí”* (此其) appears in the imperial annotations, **Xíng Xuàn** (邢玄), **Qìngyáng** (庆阳), **Pánxī** (磻溪), **Lóuzhèng** (楼正), **Jǐngfú** (景福), **Gù Huān** (顾欢), **Péng Zī** (彭耜), **Gāo Yì** (高翿), and **Zhào Méngfǔ** (赵孟俯), all matching this inscription. **Fù** (傅) and **Fàn** (范) read *“shì qí”* (是其), while **Yán Zūn** (严遵) reads *“wéi sī”* (唯斯). The **Zhūhé** (诸河) and **Wáng** (王) manuscripts read *“cǐ fēi”* (此非). **Fàn Yìngyuán** (范应元) states:
*“Wáng Bì”* (王弼) aligns with the ancient manuscripts, while **Héshànggōng** (河上公) reads *“cǐ fēi yǐ jiàn wéi běn yē, fēi hū”* (此非以贱为本邪，非乎). The current text follows the ancient manuscripts. Thus, **Fàn** (范) saw the **Wáng** (王) manuscript with *“fēi”* (非) as *“qí”* (其).

The character *“yē”* (耶), in the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) and **Yán Zūn** (严遵) manuscripts, is *“yǔ”* (与). **Gù Huān** (顾欢), **Fù** (傅), and **Fàn** (范) read *“yě”* (也). The **Suìzhōu** (遂州) manuscript matches this inscription. **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes:
*“Fēi”* (非) is written *“fēi yú”* (非欤) by **Fàn** (范), *“bēi hū”* (悲乎) by **Jǐngfú** (景福), and *“fēi yě”* (非也) in the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) manuscript. **Qián Zhī** (谦之) concludes: *“Zuò qí”* (作其) is correct. This passage employs Chu dialect. **Jiǎng Xīchāng** (蒋锡昌) states:
In the *Shǐjì* (史记) *Gāozǔ Jì* (高祖纪), *“qí yǐ pèi wéi nǐ tāngmù yì”* (其以沛为朕汤沐邑), the *Jíjiě* (集解) cites *Fēngsú Tōng* (风俗通): *“Qí”* (其) is a Chu word. Since **Lǎozǐ** (老子) was from Chu, he should use Chu dialect. In Chapter 58, *“qí wú zhèng”* (其无正) is equivalent to *“wú zhèng”* (无正). In Chapter 77, *“qí bù yù jiàn xián”* (其不欲见贤) is equivalent to *“bù yù jiàn xián”* (不欲见贤). *“Shì qí yǐ jiàn wéi běn yě, fēi yú”* (是其以贱为本也，非欤) is equivalent to *“shì yǐ jiàn wéi běn yě fēi yú”* (是以贱为本也非欤).

Thus, *“gù zhì shù chē wú chē”* (故致数车无车). **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes:
The imperial annotations and **Wáng Bì** (王弼) read *“shù yú wú yú”* (数舆无舆), while **Sū Língzhī** (苏灵芝) in the upper text writes *“yú”* (舆) as *“yǔ”* (与), an error. **Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes:
The two *“chē”* (车) characters appear in **Héshànggōng** (河上公), **Gù Huān** (顾欢), **Jǐngfú** (景福), **Shìmíng** (室町), and **Nǎijuǎn** (柰卷) manuscripts, matching this inscription. **Yán Zūn** (严遵) and **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) read *“yú”* (舆). **Yán** (严) writes *“zhì shù yú”* (致数舆) as *“zào yú yú”* (造舆于), with the **Dūn** (敦) manuscript ending the sentence with *“yě”* (也). The **Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ** (法京敦乙) manuscript writes the first *“chē”* (车) as *“yǔ”* (与) and the second as *“yù”* (誉), matching **Sū Língzhī** (苏灵芝) and the imperial annotations. The **Suìzhōu** (遂州), **Fù** (傅), and **Fàn** (范) manuscripts read *“yù”* (誉) for both. **Fàn Yìngyuán** (范应元) states:
*“Wáng Bì”* (王弼) aligns with the ancient manuscripts, while **Héshànggōng** (河上公) reads *“shù chē wú chē”* (数车无车). The current text follows the various **Wáng** (王) manuscripts reading *“yú”* (舆), while the **Dàozàng Wáng** (道藏王) manuscript and the **Dàozàng Sòng Zhāng Tàishǒu** (道藏宋张太守) collated *Sìjiā Zhù* (四家注) also cite **Wáng Bì** (王弼) as *“gù zhì shù yù, nǎi wú yù yě”* (故致数誉，乃无誉也).

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) concludes: *“Zuò yù”* (作誉) is correct. The two *“chē”* (车) or *“yú”* (舆) are both errors for *“yù”* (誉), as *“yù”* (誉) and *“yǔ”* (与) were interchangeable in ancient script. *“Yù”* (誉) was mistakenly written as *“yú”* (舆) or *“chē”* (车). **Sū Língzhī** (苏灵芝) and the **Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ** (法京敦乙) manuscripts are evidence of this.

The interpretation of *“shù chē wú chē”* (数车无车) varies. **Lǐ Dàochún** (李道纯) states:
*“Zhūjiā jiě bù tōng”* (诸家解不通), and I say: *“Shù chē zhī gè jiàn, wú yī míng chē zhě”* (数车之各件，无一名车者), metaphorically meaning *“wǒ shì yī shēn, wú yī míng wǒ yě”* (我是一身，无一名我也). **Chéng Xuányīng** (成玄英) says:
*“Yú”* (舆, vehicle) is *“chē”* (车), composed of *“xiāng”* (箱), *“fú”* (辐), *“gǔ”* (毂), and *“lèi”* (辋). Though named *“chē”* (车), in number it lacks substance. The five elements and four great directions are illusory—just as the body floats in emptiness, where shall nobility reside?

**Lǐ Zhì** (李贽) says:
*“Jīn fú lún, fú, gài, zhěn, héng, è, gǔ, xián"* (今夫轮、辐、盖、轸、衡、轭、毂、), when combined, form *“chē”* (车). Yet people see only these parts—when have they seen *“chē”* (车) itself? Yet it is called *“chē”* (车), not *“lún, fú, gài, zhěn, héng, è, gǔ, xián”* (轮、辐、盖、轸、衡、轭、毂、).

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes:
Both **Lǐ** (李) interpretations reflect Buddhist teachings, as evidenced by the extant Pali *Mìlán Wáng Wèn Jīng* (弥兰王问经) and the lost *Nàxiān Bīqiú Jīng* (那先比丘经) from the Eastern Jin dynasty. The text reads:

*“Nàxiān wèn Wáng: ‘Yán míng chē, hé suǒ wéi chē zhě? Zhóu wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Zhóu bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Lèi wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Lèi bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Fú wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Fú bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Gǔ wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Gǔ bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Yún wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Yún bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Káng wéi chē yě?’*
*Wáng yuē: ‘Káng bù wéi chē.’*
*Nàxiān yuē: ‘Gài wéi chē yě?’*

*The King said: ‘If they are not assembled as all the materials, that is not a chariot.’*
*Nàxiān said: ‘Is the *yīn shēng* (音声, sound) a chariot?’*
*The King said: ‘The sound is not a chariot.’*
*Nàxiān said: ‘What, then, is a chariot?’*
*The King fell silent and spoke no word.*

*Nàxiān said: ‘The Buddha taught this: when all the materials are assembled and used for a chariot, then it is a chariot. Humans are also like this. When the assembled parts—head, face, ears, nose, mouth, neck, shoulders, arms, bones and flesh, hands and feet, liver, entrails (*fǔ* 腑), heart, spleen, kidneys, intestines, stomach, complexion (*yán sè* 颜色), voice and sound (*shēng xiǎng* 声响), breathing, suffering and joy, good and evil—are assembled, that is called a human.’*
*The King said: ‘Excellent! Excellent!’*

Since the teachings of the Buddha entered China, there arose the saying of *"zhi shu yù wú yù"* (至誉无誉, "extreme praise without praise").

The terms *"zuò chē"* (作车, "to make a chariot") and *"zuò yù"* (作舆, "to make a carriage") may share some meaning, yet they are not the original words of *Laozi*—this is quite evident.

Gao Yandi said: *"Zhi yù wú yù"* (至誉无誉, "extreme praise without praise"). The *He Shang* (河上) version reads *"zhi shu yù wú yù"* (致数舆无舆), while Wang Bi’s (王弼) and *Huainanzi Dao Ying* (淮南子道应训) versions read *"zhi shu yù wú yù"* (致数舆无舆), all of which are strained interpretations that do not align with the original text.

The *Lu Shi* (陆氏) annotation explains the character *"yù"* (誉) as *"huì yù"* (毁誉, "praise and blame"). Thus, the original text should have been *"yù"* (誉).

From *"yù"* (誉) it was corrupted to *"yù"* (舆, "carriage"), and from *"yù"* (舆) to *"chē"* (车, "chariot"). Later scholars mistakenly believed the annotation was incorrect, but this is not the case.

In the *Zhuangzi* chapter *"Zhi Le"* (至乐, "Utmost Joy"), it states *"Zhi yù wú yù"* (至誉无誉, "extreme praise without praise"), followed by *"Tian wú wéi yǐ zhī qīng, dì wú wéi yǐ zhī níng"* (天无为以之清，地无为以之宁, "Heaven acts without action and thus is clear; Earth acts without action and thus is tranquil"). This clearly draws from the same passage, further confirming the original reading.

Luo Yunxian said: *"Yù"* (誉) means *"huì yù"* (毁誉, "praise and blame"). Wu Cheng’s (吴澄) version reads *"yù"* (舆) instead of *"yù"* (誉), and Jiao Shi’s (焦氏) *Kao Yi* (考异) notes that *"yù"* (舆) was originally *"yù"* (誉). It is evident that *"yù"* (誉) is the correct character for meaning.

I suspect the original text was *"zhi shu yǔ wú yǔ"* (致数与无与, "extreme calculation of giving without giving"), as *"yù"* (誉) and *"yǔ"* (与) were used interchangeably in ancient times (as in the *Zuo* commentary: *"yù"* or *"yǔ"*).

*"Shu"* (数) means *"counting"* or *"calculating"*—so *"zhi shu yù wú yù"* (致数誉无誉) means *"extreme calculation of praise without praise"*.

The *Houwang* (侯王, "feudal lords and kings") call themselves *"gū"* (孤, "lonely"), *"guǎ"* (寡, "few"), and *"bù gǔ"* (不谷, "not abundant"), which is *"not calculating praise"*, yet praise is still attributed to them. Thus, *"zhi shu yù wú yù"* (致数誉无誉) is clearly understood.

The *Huainanzi* passage *"Saying on Mountains"* (说山训) states: *"Qiú měi zé bù dé měi, bù qiú měi zé měi yǐ"* (求美则不得美，不求美则美矣, "If one seeks beauty, one does not attain beauty; if one does not seek beauty, beauty is attained"). The annotation reads: *"Xīn zì qiú měi zé bù dé měi míng yě, ér zì sǔn zé yǒu měi míng yě, gù Lǎozi yuē 'zhi shu yù wú yù'*"* (心自求美则不得美名也，而自损则有美名也，故老子曰『致数舆无舆』也。), though the text reads *"yù"* (舆), the explanation is about *"měi míng"* (美名, "good reputation"), confirming that it should be read as *"yù"* (誉).

This interpretation is quite insightful.

*"Bù yù liáng liáng rú yù, luò luò rú shí"* (不欲琭琭如玉，落落如石, "One does not desire the lustrous like jade, nor the firm like stone").

Yan Kejun said: *"Luò luò"* (落落) was rendered as *"luò luò"* (珞珞) in Wang Bi’s version.

Luo Zhentian noted that the *Dunhuang* (敦煌) version reads *"lù lù"* (禄禄) or *"luò luò"* (落落).

In my examination: *"Liáng liáng"* (琭琭) was written as *"lù lù"* (碌碌) in *Jingfu* (景福) version, and *"luò luò"* (落落) as *"shí"* (石, "stone") in *Yu zhu* (御注), *Sui zhou* (遂州), *Qing Xuan* (邢玄), *Qingyang* (庆阳), *Pan Xi* (磻溪), *Lou Zheng* (楼正), *Shiming* (室町), *Nan juan* (柰卷), *Yan Zun* (严遵), *He Shang* (河上), *Gu Huan* (顾欢), *Peng* (彭), *Fan* (范), and *Zhao* (赵) versions, while *Jingfu* (景福) rendered it as *"guò guò"* (硌硌). Fu Yi (傅奕) and Fan (范) versions also read *"ruò"* (若) for both *"rú"* (如) characters.

Bi Qian said: *"In ancient texts, there were no characters 'liáng' (琭), 'lù' (碌), or 'luò' (珞). 'Guò' (硌) should be corrected to 'luò' (落)."*

The *Guangyun* (广韵) states: *"Gōng děng lù lù"* (公等录录) as *"○○"*. The *Shuowen Jiezi* (说文解字) says: *"○，suí cóng yě"* (随从也, "to follow").

Thus, *Guangyun* (广韵) likely used *"luò"* (录) in its meaning.

Hong Yixian said: *"Liáng liáng"* (琭琭) is akin to *"lù lù"* (录录).

The *Guangya* (广雅) explains *"lù lù"* (逯逯) as *"zhòng"* (众, "many"). The *Shuowen Jiezi* (说文解字) also states: *"○，suí cóng yě"* (随从也, "to follow").

These characters are used interchangeably.

Wang Bi’s version reads: *"Guì wù yǐ duō ér jiàn jiàn, luò luò, shí jiān mào"* (贵物以多而见贱。 落落，石坚貌。 石本贱物，以坚而自贞，是以两不欲也。), meaning: *"Precious things are seen as cheap when they are many. 'Luò luò' (落落) is the firm appearance of stone. Stone is originally a cheap thing, yet it remains firm and steadfast, thus both are not desired."*

The *Yanzi Chunqiu* (晏子春秋) *Inner Chapters* (内篇) *Questions* (问) *Second Part* (下) states: *"Jiān yǐ shí hū! Luò luò, shì zhī zé jiān, wú yǐ wéi jiǔ, shì yǐ sù wáng yě"* (坚哉石乎！ 落落，视之则坚，无以为久，是以速亡也。), meaning: *"Firm indeed is stone! 'Luò luò' (落落), when viewed, appears firm, yet it cannot endure for long, hence it perishes quickly."*

This aligns with the same meaning.

Gao Yandi said: *"Liáng liáng"* (琭琭) is recorded as *"lù lù"* (录录) in the *Shiji* (史记) *Pingyuanjun Zhuan* (平原君传), and *"lù lù"* (碌碌) in the *Hou Han Shu* (后汉书) *Feng Han Zhuan* (冯衍传), annotated as *"lù lù wéi rén suǒ guì, luò luò wéi rén suǒ jiàn"* (碌碌为人所贵，落落为人所贱。), meaning: *"Lù lù (碌碌) is what people value, while luò luò (落落) is what people despise."*

The *He Shang* (河上) version annotated *"liáng liáng"* (琭琭) as *"yǔ shuǒ liáng liáng"* (琭琭喻少, "represents few"), and *"luò luò"* (落落) as *"yǔ shuǒ duō"* (落落喻多, "represents many"). Wang Bi interpreted *"liáng liáng luò luò"* (琭琭落落) as *"tǐ jìn yú xíng"* (体尽于形, "fully embodied in form").

Wang Yi’s (王逸) *Jiuxi* (九思) annotation states: *"Guò guò"* (硌硌, "long and abundant in appearance").

All these interpretations diverge from the original meaning of the text.

Moreover, as evidence, *Mao Suo* (毛遂) ridiculed the nineteen men saying: *"Gōng děng lù lù, yīn rén chéng shì zhě yě"* (公等录录，因人成事者也。), meaning: *"You gentlemen are long and abundant, relying on others to accomplish things."*

In the *Shi Jie* (世家) *Xiao He* (萧何) passage: *"Lù lù wèi yǒu qí jiē"* (录录未有奇节。), annotated as *"lù lù yóu lù lù"* (录录犹鹿鹿。), meaning: *"Lù lù (录录) is akin to lù lù (鹿鹿)."*

Xun Yue’s (荀悦) *Han Ji* (汉纪) *Wang Zhongyong* (王仲翁) criticism of *Xiao Wangzhi* (萧望之) states: *"Bù lù lù, fǎn bào guān mù"* (不碌碌，反抱关木。), meaning: *"Not long and abundant, yet clinging to the gatekeeper’s staff."*

The *Hou Han Shu* (后汉书) *Ma Yuan Zhuan* (马援传) states: *"Jīn gèng lù lù, yù wǎng zhī"* (今更陆陆，欲往之。), meaning: *"Now even more long and abundant, yet still desiring to go."*

The various interpretations are even more untenable.

According to the *Shuō Wén* (说文): **«录」 (○), to follow and attend** (meaning: to be enslaved by others).

The *Suǒ Yǐn* (索隐) by Wáng Xiào (王劭) states: *"Lù (录) is merely a borrowed character. The Shuō Wén says: ‘○○, the appearance of following and attending.’"*

The *Guǎng Yùn* (广韵) under **«录»** cites Máo Suǒ (毛遂) as saying: *"Gōng děng ○○, kě wèi yīn rén chéng shì ěr."* (公等○○，可谓因人成事耳。)

The *Shǐ Jì* (史记) also uses **«录」**. Thus, *jiāng (琭)*, *lù (碌)*, *lù (录)*, *lù (鹿)*, and *lù (陆)* are all borrowed forms of **«录」**, all conveying the meaning of *following and attending*, aligning with the criticisms of the earlier scholars and allowing for intuitive understanding.

Later scholars, seeing only the characters for *jade* (玉) and *stone* (石) below, mistakenly took the radicals *jade* and *stone* as the correct forms, each proposing divergent interpretations without realizing their inconsistency.

The variants *luò (落)*, *luò (珞)*, and *gē (硌)* are merely scribal variations, now following the *Hòu Hàn Shū* (后汉书) *Gěng Wěn Zhuan* (耿弇传): *«Luòluò nán hé»* (落落难合), annotated as *«shū kuò mào»* (疏阔貌), meaning *spacious and disjointed*—unable to integrate with others—which directly contradicts the meaning of *following and attending*.

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes:
*"Jiāngjiāng (琭琭)"* is sometimes written as *lùlù (碌碌)*, *lùlù (渌渌)*, *lùlù (禄禄)*, or *lùlù (鹿鹿)*.
*"Luòluò (落落)"* is sometimes written as *luòluò (珞珞)* or *gēgē (硌硌)*, all being phonetic variations and scribal errors commonly used in antiquity.

The *Hòu Hàn Shū* (后汉书) *Féng Yǎn Zhuan* (冯衍传) annotation elaborates: *"Kě guì kě jiàn, jiē fēi Dào zhēn. Yù mào luòluò, wéi rén suǒ guì; shí xíng luòluò, wéi rén suǒ jiàn. Jiàn yǐ shī yǐ, guì yì wèi dé."* (可贵可贱，皆非道真。玉貌珞珞，为人所贵；石形落落，为人所贱。贱既失矣，贵亦未得。) This interpretation applies Zhuāngzi’s philosophy to Lǎozi’s Dao.

**Phonology:**
Jiāng Shì’s (江氏) rhyme analysis:
- *Qīng (清), níng (宁), líng (灵), yíng (盈), shēng (生), zhēn (贞)* (Gēng department),
- *liè (裂), fā (发), xiē (歇), jié (竭), miè (灭), xī (溪)* (Jì department),
- *yé (邪), hū (乎), chē (车)* (Yú department; *yé* pronounced as *yú*),
- *jiāng (琭), yù (玉)* (Hóu department),
- *luò (落), shí (石)* (Yú department; *luò* as *lù* entering tone, *shí* as *chī* entering tone).

**Qián Zhī** (谦之) notes:
*"Yé (邪), hū (乎)"* both belong to the Yú department, while *"chē (车)"* and *"yú (舆)"* are errors for *"yù (誉)"*, making *yé, hū, yù* rhyme.
*"Fā (发)"* in ancient pronunciation is *xiē (歇)*; *xiē* in Gāo Běn (高本) and Hàn Běn (汉本) is sometimes written as *"xiè (泄)"*, forming the rhyme *liè, fā, xiè, jié, miè, jué (蹶)*.

The five lines beginning with *"Tiān wú yǐ qīng"* (天无以清) alternate between the rhymes *qīng, níng, líng, yíng, shēng, zhēn* and *liè, fā, xiē, jié, miè, xī* within the same stanza.

Additionally, *"bù gǔ"* (不谷) shares the same *gǔ (谷)* entering tone as *jiāng (琭)* and *yù (玉)* in the *liù wū* (六屋) category, forming a distanced rhyme in the following stanza.

Yáo Wéndiàn (姚文田) remarks: *"Luòluò rú shí"* (落落如石), where *luò (落)* and *shí (石)* rhyme, creating internal harmony with the preceding line.

chunks.original_text: 反者道之动，弱者道之用。 谦之案：碑本「昔之得一者」止「有生于无」句为一章。 严遵本与上章相连，同此石。 又宋赵志坚疏义「反」作「返」。 又案「反」，复也，此易义也。 易复彖曰：「反复其道，七日来复，天行也，复其见天地之心乎！ 」杂卦传曰：「复，反也。 」干彖传曰：「终日干干，反复道也。 」泰彖曰：「无平不陂，无往不复。 」反即复也。 故老子曰：「万物并作，吾以观其复。 夫物云云，各复归其根，归根曰静，静曰复命。 」又曰「复归于婴儿」，「复归于无极」，「复归于朴」，此复之即返而归之也。 「大曰逝，逝曰远，远曰反」，此待其远而后反也。 反自是动，不动则无所谓反，故曰：「反者道之动。 」反自是逆，逆而后顺，故曰：「玄德深矣远矣，与物反矣，然后乃至大顺。 」又「弱者道之用」，盖得易之坤者也，干藏于坤，故曰弱。 易曰「潜龙勿用」，而老言无用之用，是道之用。 天下万物生于有，有生于无。 严可均曰：「天下万物」，河上、王弼作「万物」，御注作「之物」。 谦之案：广明、景福、御览六百十九引并作「万物」，同此石。 邢玄、磻溪、楼正、室町、傅、范、高、赵并作「之物」，同御注。 敦煌、严遵本作「天地之物」。 又景福、范本「无」作「无」。 马叙伦曰：「弼注曰：『天下之物，皆有以为生。 』是王亦作『之物』。 今作『万物』者，后人据河上本改也。 」谦之案：首章「无名，天地始，有名，万物母」，以「无名」与「有名」对，「天地」与「万物」对，「始」与「母」对。 此章亦言「有」「无」，则「天下万物」，当作「天地万物」，于义为优。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读、姚文田、奚侗无韵。 邓廷桢、陈柱、高本汉：动、用韵，是也。 案孔广森诗声类（四）阳声四东、锺、江合为一部，并收「动」「用」二字，引老子曰：「反者道之动，弱者道之用。 」 右景龙碑本二十一字，敦煌本、河、王、傅、范本同。 河上题「去用第四十」，王本题「四十章」，范本题「反者道之动章第四十」。 四十一章 上士闻道，勤而行之； 严可均曰：「勤而行之」，御注无「之」字，傅奕作「而勤行之」。 谦之案：法京敦乙本作「懃能行」，罗卷同此石，与武内本异。 范本作「懃」，注云「古本」。 案夏竦古文四声韵卷一引古老子作「懃」。 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大之。 谦之案：「」，各本作「笑」，遂州本作「」，御注作「○」。 傅、范本作「而大笑之」。 俞樾曰：按王氏念孙读书杂志曰：「『大笑之』，本作『大而笑之』，犹言迂而笑之也。 牟子引老子，正作『大而笑之』。 抱朴子微旨篇亦云：『大而笑之，其来久矣。 』是牟、葛所见本皆作『大而笑之』。 」今按王说是也。 「下士闻道，大而笑之」，与上文「上士闻道，勤而行之」，两句相对。 傅奕本作：「上士闻道，而勤行之； 下士闻道，而大笑之。 」盖误移两「而」字于句首，然下句之有「而」字，则尚可籍以考见也。 「而勤行之」，是「勤而行之」之误。 然则「而大笑之」，是「大而笑之」之误，可以隅反矣。 高亨曰：「亡」读为「忘」，二字古通用。 诗假乐「不愆不忘」，说苑建本篇引「忘」作「亡」。

The **returning** is the **Dao’s** motion; the **weak** is the **Dao’s** use.

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The *Jǐnglóng Bēi* (景龙碑) version, *"Xī zhī dé yī zhě"* (昔之得一者), ends with *"Yǒu shēng yú wú"* (有生于无) as a single chapter. The *Yán Zōng Běn* (严遵本) connects with the preceding chapter, sharing the same stone inscription. Additionally, the *Sòng Zhù Zhìjiān Shūyì* (宋赵志坚疏义) renders *"fǎn"* (反) as *"fǎn"* (返).

Further commentary: *"Fǎn"* (反) means **returning**, aligning with the *Yì* (易) interpretation. The *Yì* *Fù Tuàn* (易复彖) states:
*"Returning and reversing the **Dao**, seven days to return—this is the movement of Heaven, returning to reveal the essence of Heaven and Earth!"*
The *Záguà Zhuàn* (杂卦传) says:
*"**Returning** is **reversal**."*
The *Gān Tuàn Zhuàn* (干彖传) states:
*"All day long, pressing and pressing—this is the **repeating** of the **Dao**."*
The *Tài Tuàn* (泰彖) declares:
*"Without levelness, there is no slope; without going, there is no **returning**."*

Thus, **"returning"** is the same as **"reversing."** Hence, *Lǎozǐ* (老子) says:
*"When all things arise together, I observe their **returning**. Things drift like clouds, each **returning** to its root. Returning to the root is called **stillness**; stillness is called **restoring the mandate**."*
He also says:
*"**Returning** to the infant,"*
*"**Returning** to the boundless,"*
*"**Returning** to the uncarved block,"*
—all meaning **reversing and returning**.

*"Great is called **passing**; **passing** is called **distant**; **distant** is called **returning**,"*
—meaning one must first go far before **returning**.

**Returning** is inherently **motion**; without motion, there is no **returning**, hence:
*"The **returning** is the **Dao’s** motion."*

**Returning** is inherently **contrary**; only by being contrary does it become harmonious, hence:
*"The profound **virtue** is deep and far, contrary to things, and only then does it attain the greatest harmony."*

As for *"the weak is the **Dao’s** use,"* this aligns with the *Yì*’s *Kūn* (坤), where *Gān* (干) is hidden within *Kūn*, hence called **weak**. The *Yì* says:
*"The hidden dragon does not act,"*
while *Lǎozǐ* speaks of *"the use of non-action,"*—this is the **Dao’s** use.

*"All things under Heaven are born from existence; existence arises from non-existence."*

**Commentary by Yán Kějūn (严可均):**
The *Héshàng Běn* (河上本) and *Wáng Běn* (王本) render *"tiānxià wànwù"* (天下万物) as *"wànwù"* (万物), while the *Yù Zhù* (御注) reads *"zhī wù"* (之物). **Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The *Guāngmíng*, *Jǐngfú*, and *Yù Lǎn* (御览) all cite *"wànwù"* (万物), matching the stone inscription. *Xíng Xuán* (邢玄), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóu Zhèng* (楼正), *Shìtīng* (室町), *Fù* (傅), *Fàn* (范), *Gāo* (高), and *Zhào* (赵) all read *"zhī wù"* (之物), aligning with the *Yù Zhù*. The *Dūnhuáng Běn* (敦煌本) and *Yán Zōng Běn* (严遵本) read *"tiāndì zhī wù"* (天地之物).

Additionally, the *Jǐngfú* and *Fàn Běn* (范本) render *"wú"* (无) as *"wú"* (无). *Mǎ Xùlún* (马叙伦) notes:
*"Wáng Pì’s (王弼) annotation says: ‘All things under Heaven have existence as their source.’ Thus, Wáng (王) also wrote *‘zhī wù’* (之物). Those now writing *‘wànwù’* (万物) later emended it based on the *Héshàng Běn* (河上本)."*

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
In the opening chapter, *"Wúmíng, tiāndì shǐ; yǒumíng, wànwù mǔ"* (无名，天地始；有名，万物母), *"wúmíng"* (无名) opposes *"yǒumíng"* (有名), *"tiāndì"* (天地) opposes *"wànwù"* (万物), and *"shǐ"* (始) opposes *"mǔ"* (母). Here, since it speaks of *"yǒu"* (有) and *"wú"* (无), *"tiānxià wànwù"* (天下万物) should read *"tiāndì wànwù"* (天地万物) for greater coherence.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter is read without rhyme by *Jiāng Shì* (江氏), *Yáo Wéndiàn* (姚文田), and *Xí Dòng* (奚侗). *Dèng Tíngzhēn* (邓廷桢), *Chén Zhù* (陈柱), and *Gāo Běnhàn* (高本汉) note that *"dòng"* (动) and *"yòng"* (用) rhyme, which is correct.

**Note:** *Kǒng Guǎngsēn*’s *Shī Shēnglèi* (诗声类) categorizes *"dòng"* (动) and *"yòng"* (用) under *yángshēng* (阳声) *dōng* (东), *zhōng* (钟), and *jiāng* (江) as one rhyme group, citing *Lǎozǐ*:
*"The **returning** is the **Dao’s** motion; the **weak** is the **Dao’s** use."*

The *Jǐnglóng Bēi* (景龙碑) version contains **21 characters**; the *Dūnhuáng Běn* (敦煌本), *Héshàng Běn* (河上本), *Wáng Běn* (王本), *Fù Běn* (傅本), and *Fàn Běn* (范本) all match this.

The *Héshàng Běn* (河上本) titles this *"Qùyòng dì sìshí"* (去用第四十); the *Wáng Běn* (王本) titles it *"Sìshí zhāng"* (四十章); the *Fàn Běn* (范本) titles it *"Fǎnzhě Dào zhī Dòng zhāng dì sìshí"* (反者道之动章第四十).

---
**Chapter Forty-One**
The superior person, hearing the **Dao**, diligently practices it;
**Commentary by Yán Kějūn (严可均):**
*"Qín ér xíng zhī"* (勤而行之), the *Yù Zhù* (御注) omits *"zhī"* (之), while *Fù Yì* (傅奕) renders it *"ér qín xíng zhī"* (而勤行之).

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The *Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ Běn* (法京敦乙本) reads *"qín néng xíng"* (懃能行), with *Luǒ Juàn* (罗卷) matching the stone inscription, differing from the *Wǔnèi Běn* (武内本). The *Fàn Běn* (范本) reads *"qín"* (懃), annotated as *"gǔběn"* (古本). **Note:** *Xià Sūn*’s (夏竦) *Gǔwén Sìshēngyùn* (古文四声韵) cites the ancient *Lǎozǐ* as *"qín"* (懃).

The middle person, hearing the **Dao**, holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The inferior person, hearing the **Dao**, **derides** it.

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The various manuscripts read *"xiào"* (笑), the *Suìzhōu Běn* (遂州本) reads *"[missing character]"*, and the *Yù Zhù* (御注) marks it *"○"*. The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions read *"ér dàxiào zhī"* (而大笑之).

**Commentary by Yú Yuè (俞樾):**
According to *Wáng Shì Niánsūn*’s *Duìshū Zhìzhí* (读书杂志):
*"‘Dàxiào zhī’ (大笑之) was originally ‘dà ér xiào zhī’ (大而笑之), akin to ‘yū ér xiào zhī’ (迂而笑之)."* The *Móu Zǐ* (牟子) cites *Lǎozǐ* as *"dà ér xiào zhī"* (大而笑之). The *Bàopǔ Zǐ*’s *Wéizhǐ Piān* (抱朴子微旨篇) also states:
*"‘Dà ér xiào zhī’ (大而笑之), this has been long so."*

Now, according to *Wáng*’s (王) explanation, this is correct. *"Xiàshì wén dào, dà ér xiào zhī"* (下士闻道，大而笑之) opposes the preceding *"Shàngshì wén dào, qín ér xíng zhī"* (上士闻道，勤而行之).

*Fù Yì* (傅奕) renders:
*"Shàngshì wén dào, ér qín xíng zhī; xiàshì wén dào, ér dàxiào zhī"* (上士闻道，而勤行之；下士闻道，而大笑之),
—mistakenly placing the *"ér"* (而) at the sentence’s beginning. However, the *"ér"* (而) in the latter sentence still allows us to infer the original.

*"Ér qín xíng zhī"* (而勤行之) is a misplacement of *"qín ér xíng zhī"* (勤而行之). Thus, *"ér dàxiào zhī"* (而大笑之) is a misplacement of *"dà ér xiào zhī"* (大而笑之), which can now be confirmed.

**Commentary by Gāo Hēng (高亨):**
*"Wáng"* (亡) is read as *"wàng"* (忘); the two characters were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Shī Jiǎ Yuè* (诗假乐) states *"bù qiān bù wàng"* (不愆不忘), and the *Shuōyuàn Jiànběn Piān* (说苑建本篇) cites *"wàng"* (忘) as *"wáng"* (亡).

chunks.original_text: 荀子劝学篇「怠慢忘身」，大戴礼劝学篇「忘」作「亡」。 吕氏春秋权勋篇「是忘荆国之社稷而不恤吾众也」，韩非子十过篇、淮南子人间篇并「忘」作「亡」。 皆其证。 诗绿衣「心之忧矣，曷维其亡」，郑笺「亡之言忘也」，亦其例也。 周易略例：「存言者，非得象者也； 存象者，非得意者也。 忘言者，乃得象者也； 忘象者，乃得意者也。 」「存」「忘」对举，与此文同。 不不足以为道。 罗振玉曰：敦煌本「笑」下有「之」字。 故建言有之： 严可均曰：御注无「故」字。 谦之案：邢玄、景福、庆阳、磻溪、楼正、高翿、室町本与御注同。 武内敦乙本「建言」下有「是以」二字，顾欢本同。 罗振玉曰：敦煌本作「是以建言有之曰」。 谦之案：傅、范本亦有「曰」字。 范应元曰：「王弼、孙登、阮咸同古本，河上公本无『曰』字。 」奚侗曰：「建言」，当是古载籍名。 高亨曰：「建言」，殆老子所称书名也。 庄子人间世篇引法言，鹖冠子天权篇引逸言，鬼谷子谋篇引阴言，汉书艺文志有谰言（班自注「不知作者」），可证名书曰言，古人之通例也。 明道若昧，进道若退，夷道若类， 严可均曰：「若类」，御注、王弼作「若颣」。 谦之案：「进道若退」，御注「退」作「○」，傅奕、彭耜、林希逸、赵孟俯此句在「夷道若类」句下。 「类」字，释文、河上、敦煌、景福、柰卷、顾欢并同，傅、范本作「颣」。 范曰：「『颣』，古本音耒，丝节也，河上公作『类』。 今从古本。 」今案：「颣」、「类」古通用。 广雅释言：「颣，节也。 」通俗文：「多节曰颣。 」「夷道若颣」，简文注：「疵也。 」淮南泛论「明月之珠，不能无颣」，注：「颣，盘若丝之结颣也。 」假借为「戾」。 左传昭十六「刑之颇颣」，服注：「不平也。 」不平与平对立，故曰「夷道若颣」。 夷，平也，「颣」则引申为不平之义。 上德若谷，大白若辱， 武内义雄曰：敦、遂二本「谷」作「俗」。 罗振玉曰：「大白若辱」，此句敦煌本在「上德若谷」之前。 谦之案：罗卷敦戊本「谷」不作「俗」，与法京敦乙本异。 成玄英曰：「『谷』本亦作「俗」字者，言亦能忘德，不异嚣俗也。 」马叙伦曰：「各本作『谷』，『俗』之省也。 言高上之德，反如流俗，即和光同尘之义。 」又「大白」，道藏王本「大」作「太」。 又「辱」字，傅、范本作「○」。 范曰：『○』音辱，黑垢也。 古本如此，河上本作『辱』。 」毕沅曰：「『○」，河上公、王弼并作『辱』。 作『○』者，所谓『以白造缁』是矣。 说文解字无『○』字。 」谦之案：玉篇：「○，垢黑也。 」当为「辱」之古文。 广雅释诂三：「辱，污也，又恶也。 」仪礼士昏礼「今吾子辱」，注：「以白造缁曰辱。 」素问气交变大论：「黑气乃辱。 」辱有黑义，与白对立，故曰「大白若辱」。 易顺鼎曰：按「辱」者，仪礼士昏礼注云「以白造缁曰辱」，即此「辱」字之义。 ……盖以白造缁，除去污辱之迹，故曰辱也。 此老子本义，幸有诗传、礼注可以互证。 广德若不足， 谦之案：庄子寓言篇：「老子曰：『而睢睢盱盱，而谁与居？ 大白若辱，盛德若不足。 』」末二句与此章同。

Xúnzǐ’s *Effort in Learning* (劝学篇) reads *“yān màn wàng shēn”* (怠慢忘身), while the *Great Rites of Dài* (大戴礼·劝学篇) renders *“wàng”* (忘) as *“wáng”* (亡). In the *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (吕氏春秋·权勋篇), it states *“shì wàng jīng guó zhī shèjì ér bù xù wú zhòng yě”* (是忘荆国之社稷而不恤吾众也), and similarly, the *Han Feizi* (十过篇) and *Huáinánzǐ* (人间篇) use *“wàng”* (忘) as *“wáng”* (亡). These serve as further evidence.

The *Shī* (诗·绿衣) states *“xīn zhī yōu yǐ, hé wéi qí wáng”* (心之忧矣，曷维其亡), with Zhèng’s annotation *“wáng zhī yán wàng yě”* (亡之言忘也), following the same pattern.

The *Yìjīng Liè Jiě* (周易·略例) declares:
*“Cún yán zhě, fēi dé xiàng zhě yě; cún xiàng zhě, fēi dé yì zhě yě.
Wàng yán zhě, nǎi dé xiàng zhě yě; wàng xiàng zhě, nǎi dé yì zhě yě.”*
(存言者，非得象者也；存象者，非得意者也。
忘言者，乃得象者也；忘象者，乃得意者也.)

Here, *“cún”* (存) and *“wàng”* (忘) are paired opposites, aligning with the passage’s structure. This does not suffice to elucidate the *Dao*.

Lǔ Zhènyù (罗振玉) notes that the *Dūnhuáng* manuscript includes *“zhī”* (之) after *“xiào”* (笑). Thus, the original text reads:
*“Jiàn yán yǒu zhī”* (建言有之).

Yán Kějūn (严可均) observes that the Imperial Commentary lacks the *“gù”* (故) character. My examination reveals that the editions by Xíng Xuán (邢玄), Jǐng Fú (景福), Qìngyáng (庆阳), Pánxī (磻溪), Lóuzhèng (楼正), Gāo Yì (高翿), and Shìmǎchōng (室町本) align with the Imperial Commentary. The *Wǔnèi Dūnyǐ* (武内敦乙本) and Gǔ Huān’s (顾欢) editions insert *“shì yǐ”* (是以) after *“jiàn yán”* (建言). Lǔ Zhènyù states that the *Dūnhuáng* text reads *“shì yǐ jiàn yán yǒu zhī yuē”* (是以建言有之曰). My review confirms that the Fù Yì (傅奕) and Fàn (范) editions also include *“yuē”* (曰).

Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) notes that Wáng Bì (王弼), Sūn Dēng (孙登), and Ruǎn Xián (阮咸) follow the ancient manuscripts, while the Héshànggōng (河上公) edition omits *“yuē”* (曰). Xí Dòng (奚侗) argues that *“jiàn yán”* (建言) likely refers to an ancient text title.

Gāo Hēng (高亨) suggests *“jiàn yán”* (建言) may be the title of a book referenced by Lǎozǐ.

The *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子·人间世篇) cites *“fǎ yán”* (法言), the *Hùguānzǐ* (鹖冠子·天权篇) references *“yì yán”* (逸言), and the *Guǐgǔzǐ* (鬼谷子·谋篇) invokes *“yīn yán”* (阴言). The *Hànshū Yìwénzhì* (汉书·艺文志) lists *“huáng yán”* (谰言), with Bān Gu’s annotation *“bù zhī zhǔzhe”* (不知作者), demonstrating that naming texts with *“yán”* (言) was a common ancient practice.

---
明道若昧，进道若退，
Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes that *“ruò lèi”* (若类) is rendered *“ruò chǎn”* (若颣) in the Imperial Commentary and Wáng Bì’s (王弼) edition.

My examination reveals:
- *“Jìn dào ruò tuì”* (进道若退) has *“tuì”* (退) marked *“○”* in the Imperial Commentary.
- Fù Yì (傅奕), Péng Zhì (彭耜), Lín Xīyì (林希逸), and Zhào Mèngfǔ (赵孟俯) place this sentence after *“yí dào ruò lèi”* (夷道若类).
- The *“lèi”* (类) character appears in the *Shìwén* (释文), *Héshànggōng* (河上公), *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Nǎijuàn* (柰卷), and *Gǔ Huān* (顾欢) editions, while Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) use *“chǎn”* (颣).

Fàn (范) states:
*“Chǎn”* (颣), in ancient manuscripts, is pronounced *“lěi”* (耒), referring to a silk node. The *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition uses *“lèi”* (类). I follow the ancient manuscript here.

My review confirms *“chǎn”* (颣) and *“lèi”* (类) were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Guǎngyǎ* (广雅·释言) defines *“chǎn”* (颣) as *“jié”* (节), and the *Tōngsúwén* (通俗文) states *“duō jié yuē chǎn”* (多节曰颣). The *Jiǎnwén Zhù* (简文注) for *“yí dào ruò chǎn”* (夷道若颣) explains *“cī”* (疵, flaw). The *Huáinánzǐ Fànlùn* (淮南子·泛论) describes *“míngyuè zhī zhū, bùnéng wú chǎn”* (明月之珠，不能无颣), with the annotation *“chǎn, pán ruò sī zhī jié chǎn yě”* (颣，盘若丝之结颣也). Borrowed as *“lì”* (戾), the *Zuǒzhuàn Zhāoshí* (左传·昭十六) uses *“xíng zhī pō chǎn”* (刑之颇颣), with Shì Zhù (服注) defining it as *“bù píng”* (不平, unevenness). Since *“píng”* (平) and *“bù píng”* (不平) are opposites, *“yí dào ruò chǎn”* (夷道若颣) signifies *“the Way of uniformity appears flawed.”*

---
上德若谷，大白若辱，
Wǔnèi Yìxióng (武内义雄) notes that the *Dūn* (敦) and *Suì* (遂) manuscripts render *“gǔ”* (谷) as *“sú”* (俗). Lǔ Zhènyù (罗振玉) observes that *“dà bái ruò rǔ”* (大白若辱) appears before *“shàng dé ruò gǔ”* (上德若谷) in the *Dūnhuáng* text.

My examination of the *Lǔjuàn Dūnwù* (罗卷敦戊本) confirms *“gǔ”* (谷) is not written as *“sú”* (俗), differing from the *Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ* (法京敦乙本). Chéng Xuányīng (成玄英) explains:
*“Gǔ”* (谷) was also written as *“sú”* (俗), meaning *“even one who embodies virtue can forget it, indistinguishable from the vulgar.”*

Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states:
*“All editions render it ‘gǔ’ (谷), a shorthand for ‘sú’ (俗). High virtue appears as the common crowd—embodying the meaning of blending with the world.”*

Additionally, the *Dàozàng Wángběn* (道藏王本) writes *“tài”* (太) instead of *“dà”* (大). The *“rǔ”* (辱) character is marked *“○”* in Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) editions.

Fàn (范) explains:
*“○”* is pronounced *“rǔ”* (辱), meaning *“black filth.”* Ancient manuscripts follow this, while the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition uses *“rǔ”* (辱).

Bì Yàn (毕沅) notes:
*“○”* is rendered *“rǔ”* (辱) in the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) and Wáng Bì (王弼) editions. Those writing *“○”* follow the principle of *“yǐ bái zào zī”* (以白造缁, transforming white into black). The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) does not list *“○”*.

My review confirms the *Yùpiàn* (玉篇) defines *“○”* as *“gòuhēi”* (垢黑, filth and blackness), an ancient form of *“rǔ”* (辱). The *Guǎngyǎ Shìgǔ* (广雅·释诂三) states *“rǔ, wū yě, yòu è yě”* (辱, 污也, 又恶也, defilement and evil). The *Yílì Shìhūn Lǐ* (仪礼·士昏礼) annotates *“jīn wú zǐ rǔ”* (今吾子辱) as *“yǐ bái zào zī yuē rǔ”* (以白造缁曰辱). The *Sūwèn Qìjiāo Biàn Dàlùn* (素问·气交变大论) states *“hēi qì nǎi rǔ”* (黑气乃辱). Since *“rǔ”* (辱) carries the meaning of blackness, opposing *“bái”* (白), the phrase *“dà bái ruò rǔ”* (大白若辱) follows this contrast.

Yì Shùndǐng (易顺鼎) clarifies:
*“Rǔ”* (辱) in the *Yílì Shìhūn Lǐ* (仪礼·士昏礼) annotation *“yǐ bái zào zī yuē rǔ”* (以白造缁曰辱) aligns with this usage. Transforming white into black—removing traces of defilement—hence *“rǔ”* (辱).

This reflects Lǎozǐ’s original intent, corroborated by the *Shīchuán* (诗传) and *Lǐzhù* (礼注).

---
广德若不足，
My examination of the *Zhuāngzǐ Yùyán Piān* (庄子·寓言篇) reveals:
*“Lǎozǐ yuē: ‘Ér suīsuī xūxū, ér wéi yǔ jū? Dà bái ruò rǔ, shèng dé ruò bùzú.’”* (老子曰：“而睢睢盱盱，而谁与居？ 大白若辱，盛德若不足。”)
The final two sentences match this chapter.
chunks.overlap_context:
latter sentence still allows us to infer the original.

*"Ér qín xíng zhī"* (而勤行之) is a misplacement of *"qín ér xíng zhī"* (勤而行之). Thus, *"ér dàxiào zhī"* (而大笑之) is a misplacement of *"dà ér xiào zhī"* (大而笑之), which can now be confirmed.

**Commentary by Gāo Hēng (高亨):**
*"Wáng"* (亡) is read as *"wàng"* (忘); the two characters were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Shī Jiǎ Yuè* (诗假乐) states *"bù qiān bù wàng"* (不愆不忘), and the *Shuōyuàn Jiànběn Piān* (说苑建本篇) cites *"wàng"* (忘) as *"wáng"* (亡).

chunks.original_text: 又史记老子本传老子教孔子语：「良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚。 」疑「广德」为「盛德」之讹。 马叙伦谓此文当从庄子，作「盛」是故书，是也。 严遵本作「盛德」，当从之。 又罗卷「若不足」作「若濡」，与诸本异。 建德若偷， 狩野直喜曰：河上公本之与王弼本，经文原不相同，后世辅嗣义行，而河上注渐微，遂据王本妄改经文，以致两者混而无别，幸有旧钞足以正刊本之误。 ……第四十一「建德若偷，质真若渝」，此本（谦之案：指柰卷）「若偷」作「若揄」。 案王弼注：「偷，匹也。 建德者因物自然，不立不施，故若偷匹。 」河上注：「建设道德之人，若可偷引使空虚也。 」「偷引」，此本亦作「揄引」。 盖王弼本作「偷」，其训为匹； 河上本作「揄」，其训为引。 说文手部：「揄，引也。 」韩非子饰邪篇：「庞援揄兵而南。 」汉书礼乐志「神之揄」，颜师古云：「揄，引也。 」是其证也。 可见两家经文不同，训释亦殊，后人无识，妄改「揄」为「偷」，以从王本，注亦改为「偷」，而河上公义更不可问矣。 又曰：案唐景龙刻石作「建德若偷」，……则河上公本为王本所乱，自唐时已然。 谦之案：河上本为王本所乱，是也。 惟此句，敦煌本无，河上公、王弼作「偷」，与此石同。 广明本、傅本作「偷」，高翿本作「输」，柰卷、室町本作「揄」。 范应元曰：「『输』，傅奕云『古本作输』，引『广韵云：「输，愚也。 」河上公作揄，乃草字，变车为手。 』傅奕云：『手字之误，动经数代，况「辱」字少「黑」字乎？ 』傅奕当时必有所据。 王弼作『偷』，董遇作『摇』，今从古本。 」案范说有误，傅奕此句作「偷」，下句作「输」，范本作「输」，乃误引傅奕。 案作「偷」是也。 说文：「偷，巧黠也，从女，俞声。 字亦作偷。 」朱骏声曰：「偷假为愉，汉书食货志：『民偷甘食好衣。 』路温舒传『偷为一切』，注：『苟且也。 』礼记表记：『安肆曰偷。 』左文十七传『齐君之语偷』，注：『苟且。 』又东京赋『剿民以偷乐』，注：『犹侥幸也。 』又后汉张衡传『虽遨游以偷乐兮』，注：『怀安也。 』尔雅释言：『佻，偷也。 』又荀子修身『偷儒转脱』，非十二子『偷儒而罔』，注：『当为输，苟避于事也。 』又为揄。 」由上知「偷」、「偷」、「揄」、「输」古可通用，「偷」字是故书。 俞樾曰：按河上公注曰：「建设道德之人，若可偷引，使空虚也。 」王弼注曰：「偷，匹也。 建德者因物自然，不立不施，故若偷匹。 」然偷匹之义，于古无征，义亦难晓。 ……今按「建」当读为「健」。 释名释言语曰：「健，建也，能有所建为也。 」是「建」、「健」音同，而义亦得通。 「健德者偷」，言刚健之德，反若偷惰也。 正与上句「广德若不足」一律。 质真若渝， 谦之案：傅奕本作「质直若输」，柰卷「真」亦作「直」。 「渝」、「输」古字通。 毕沅曰：「河上公、王弼作『渝』，古字通，如春秋『渝平』为『输平』是也。 」案「输」假为「愉」，有苟且怀安之意，又为「渝」。 「质真」之「真」，为「」之讹。 「质若渝」，盖谓质朴之人，行动迟缓，驽弱有若输愚者也。
chunks.translated_text:
*«Yòu Shǐjì Lǎozǐ běnchuán* (又史记老子本传) further records Lǎozǐ’s original words: *“Liáng jiǎ shēncáng ruò xū, jūnzǐ shèng dé, róngmào ruò yú.”* (良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚). It is suspected that *“guǎng dé”* (广德) is a corrupted form of *“shèng dé”* (盛德).

Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) argues that this passage should follow the *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子), and *“shèng”* (盛) is the original text, which is correct. Yán Zūn (严遵)’s version as *“shèng dé”* (盛德) should be adopted.

Lǔ Juǎn (罗卷) renders *“ruò bùzú”* (若不足) as *“ruò rú”* (若濡), differing from all other versions.

**Jiàn dé ruò tōu** (建德若偷),
Jìu yě Zhíxǐ (狩野直喜) states: *“Héshàng Gōng běn* (河上公本) and *Wáng Bì běn* (王弼本) originally had differing texts, but later scholars, following *Bùshì Yìxíng* (辅嗣义行), altered the text based on *Wáng Bì*’s version, causing the two to merge indistinguishably. Fortunately, old manuscript copies (*jiùzhāo* 旧钞) suffice to correct the errors in the printed editions.

In Chapter 41, *“jiàn dé ruò tōu, zhì zhēn ruò yú”* (建德若偷，质真若渝), this version (*qiānzhī’ān* 谦之案: referring to Lǔ Juǎn’s text) renders *“tōu”* (偷) as *“ruò yú”* (若揄). The annotation reads: *“Yú”* (揄) is the same as *“yǐn”* (引), as proven by the *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文手部): *“Yú, yǐn yě”* (揄，引也). The *Hànfēizǐ Dìxié Piān* (韩非子饰邪篇) states: *“Páng yuǎn yú bīng ér nán”* (庞援揄兵而南). The *Hànshū Lǐyuèzhì* (汉书礼乐志) mentions *“shén zhī yú”* (神之揄), with *Yán Shīgǔ* (颜师古) annotating: *“Yú, yǐn yě”* (揄，引也). Thus, the evidence confirms their difference.

It is clear that the two schools’ original texts differ, and their interpretations also vary. Later generations, lacking discernment, arbitrarily changed *“yú”* (揄) to *“tōu”* (偷) to align with *Wáng Bì*’s version, and the annotation was also altered to *“tōu”*, rendering *Héshàng Gōng*’s original meaning entirely obscure.

Moreover, it is noted that the *Táng Jǐnglóng Kèshí* (唐景龙刻石) reads *“jiàn dé ruò tōu”* (建德若偷), … thus proving that *Héshàng Gōng*’s version was corrupted by *Wáng Bì*’s as early as the Tang Dynasty. *Qiānzhī’ān* (谦之案): Indeed, *Héshàng Gōng*’s version was corrupted by *Wáng Bì*’s. Only this sentence—*Dùnhuáng běn* (敦煌本) omits it, while *Héshàng Gōng* and *Wáng Bì* both have *“tōu”* (偷), matching the stone inscription. The *Guǎngmíng běn* (广明本) and *Fù* (傅本) also have *“tōu”*, while *Gāo Yì* (高翿) has *“shū”* (输), and *Nài Juǎn* (柰卷) and *Shìdōng* (室町本) have *“yú”* (揄).

Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) states: *“Shū”* (输), as *Fù Yì* (傅奕) says, was originally *“shū”* (输), citing *“Guǎngyùn”* (广韵) which defines *“shū”* as *“yú”* (愚). *Héshàng Gōng*’s *“yú”* (揄) is a grass script error (*cǎozì* 草字), substituting *“chē”* (车) for *“shǒu”* (手). *Fù Yì* says: *“Shǒu”* (手) was mistaken in transmission across generations, how much more so *“rǔ”* (辱) missing *“hēi”* (黑)!*”*

*Fù Yì*’s version at the time must have had evidence to support it. *Wáng Bì*’s version has *“tōu”* (偷), while *Dòng Yù* (董遇) has *“yáo”* (摇); now we follow the ancient version (*gǔběn* 古本).

The *Shuōwén* (说文) defines *“tōu”* (偷) as *“qiǎo xiá yě”* (巧黠也), from *“nǚ”* (女), with the sound of *“yú”* (俞声). The character is also written as *“tōu”* (偷). *Zhū Qūnshēng* (朱骏声) explains: *“Tōu”* (偷) is borrowed as *“yú”* (愉), in the *Hànshū Shíhuòzhì* (汉书食货志): *“Mín tōu gānshí hào yī”* (民偷甘食好衣). The *Lù Wēnshū zhuàn* (路温舒传) uses *“tōu wéi yīqiè”* (偷为一切), with the annotation *“gǒuqiě yě”* (苟且也). The *Lǐjì Biǎojì* (礼记表记) states *“ān sì yuē tōu”* (安肆曰偷). The *Zuǒ Wén shíqī zhuàn* (左文十七传) mentions *“Qí jūn zhī yǔ tōu”* (齐君之语偷), with the annotation *“gǒuqiě”* (苟且). Additionally, the *Dōngjīng fù* (东京赋) says *“jiāo mín yǐ tōu lè”* (剿民以偷乐), with the annotation *“yú jiùxìng yě”* (犹侥幸也). The *Hòuhàn Zhāng Héng zhuàn* (后汉张衡传) states *“suī àoyóu yǐ tōu lè xī”* (虽遨游以偷乐兮), with the annotation *“huái ān yě”* (怀安也). The *Ěryǎ Shìyán* (尔雅释言) defines *“tiāo”* (佻) as *“tōu yě”* (偷也). *Xúnzǐ Xiūshēn* (荀子修身) and *Fēi Shí’ěr zǐ* (非十二子) both use *“tōu rú”* (偷儒), with the annotation *“dāng wéi shū, gǒu bì yú shì yě”* (当为输，苟避于事也). *“Tōu”* (偷) is also used as *“yú”* (揄).

From the above, *“tōu”* (偷), *“shū”* (输), *“yú”* (揄), and *“shū”* (愉) were interchangeable in ancient usage, and *“tōu”* (偷) is the original text (*gùshū* 故书).

Yú Yì (俞樾) states: *“Tōu”* (偷) in *Héshàng Gōng*’s annotation means *“ruòkě tōu yǐn, shǐ kōngxū yě”* (若可偷引，使空虚也). *Wáng Bì*’s annotation reads: *“Tōu, pǐ yě”* (偷，匹也). *“Jiàn dé zhě tōu”* (建德者偷), meaning one who upholds **Dao**/**Way** and **Virtue/Power** acts like a simple, unassuming matchmaker (*pǐ* 匹), neither imposing nor contriving, thus resembling *“tōu”* (偷) as *“pǐ”* (匹).

However, the meaning of *“tōu pǐ”* (偷匹) is unattested in antiquity, and its interpretation is difficult to grasp.

Now, *“jiàn”* (建) should be read as *“jiàn”* (健). The *Shìmíng Shìyányǔ* (释名释言语) states: *“Jiàn, jiàn yě, néng yǒu suǒ jiànwéi yě”* (健，建也，能有所建为也). Thus, *“jiàn”* (建) and *“jiàn”* (健) share the same pronunciation, and the meaning also becomes clear. *“Jiàn dé zhě tōu”* (健德若偷) means that **Virtue/Power** that is robust and vigorous (*jiàn* 健) paradoxically appears as lazy and indolent (*tōu* 偷).

chunks.original_text: 刘师培曰：案上文言「广德若不足，建德若偷」，此与并文，疑「真」亦作「德」，盖「德」字正文作「」，与「真」相似也。 「质德」与「广德」「建德」一律，「广德」为广大之德，与「不足」相反； 「建德」为刚健之德，与「偷」相反（用俞说）； 「质德」为质朴之德，与「渝」相反； 三德乃并文也。 大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形。 道隐无名。 谦之案：法京敦乙本「无」作「无」，罗卷均作「无」。 易顺鼎曰：「大方无隅」，道德指归论作「大方不矩」。 顾广圻曰：「大音希声」，傅本「希」作「稀」，按同字也。 王先慎曰：傅本「音」作「言」，与各本全异。 李翘曰：吕氏春秋乐成篇首曰「大智不形，大器晚成，大音希声」，不引老子。 夫唯道，善贷且善。 严可均曰：「善贷且善」，各本作「且成」。 罗振玉曰：敦煌本「贷」作「始」。 谦之案：譣罗卷敦煌乙本「无名」下缺，此云「贷」作「始」，乃据老子义本。 傅本、诸王本、室町本作「善贷且成」，范本作「善货且善成」，云：「严遵、王弼同古本，河上公作『善贷且成』、今从古本。 」今按怡兰堂严本亦作「善贷且成」，与范所见不同，盖与王本同脱一「善」字，碑本句末脱一「成」字，宜从范本增入。 「成」与成、声、形、名为韵。 「贷」与庄子应帝王篇述老聃语「化贷万物而民弗恃」之「贷」意旨相同。 「道隐无名」，亦即庄子「有莫举名，使物自喜」之意，所谓功成不名，立乎不测，而游于无有者也。 于省吾曰：景龙本作「夫唯道，善贷且善」，当脱「成」字。 敦煌「贷」作「始」，乃声之转。 周语「纯明则终」，注：「终，成也。 」又「故高明令终」，注：「终犹成也。 」书皋陶谟「箫韶九成」，郑注：「成犹终也。 」是成、终互训，义同。 然则「善始且成」，即善始且终也。 六十四章「慎终如始」，亦「终」「始」对文。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读：行、亡韵（阳部），笑、道韵（幽、宵通韵，道协音盗）。 昧、退、类韵（脂部，昧音寐，退，吐位反）。 谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅韵（侯部，渝，喻蓲反，隅，俄蓲反）。 成、声、形、名、成韵（耕部）。 谦之案：笑，宵部，道，幽部，幽、宵通韵。 惟道音盗，似误。 「道」，徒皓切。 古，徒苟切。 「道」，首声，九章与守、咎韵，十四章与有韵，四十七章与牖、少韵，此其例证。 又谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅一韵，姚文田、邓廷桢分谷、辱、足一韵（六屋入声），偷、渝、隅一韵（十三侯平声）。 又「建德若偷」之「偷」字，高本汉本一作「偷」，一作「输」，皆韵。 顾炎武曰：「行」，古音杭，引老子：「上士闻道，勤而行之； 中士闻道，若存若亡。 」「故弱之胜强，柔之胜刚，天下莫不知，莫能行。 」（唐韵正卷五十二庚）又曰：四句二韵，而语助「之」字，一有一无，在他诗亦有可证者。 老子曰「上士闻道，勤而行之，中士闻道，若存若亡」，行与亡为韵。 又唐韵正卷十七，十三末：「昧」，今考古书「昧」字，有读去声者，有读入声者。 去声则莫佩反。 老子「明道若昧，夷道若类，进道若退」。 又卷六十九侯：「偷」，古音俞。 老子「建德若偷，质直若渝，大方无隅」。

**Dao** (道) is subtle and nameless.

Wáng Xiānshèn (王先慎) observes: The *Fù* (傅) edition reads *“yīn”* (音) as *“yán”* (言), differing entirely from all other versions.

It is only **Dao** (道) that is both generous and good.

- *“Xiào, dào”* (笑、道) in the *Yōuxiào tōngyùn* (幽、宵通韵) rhyme, with *“dào”* (道) rhyming with *“dào”* (盗).

chunks.original_text: 邓廷桢曰：偷、渝、隅为韵。 「渝」，古音读若羭。 诗羔裘「舍命不渝」，与「侯」为韵。 「隅」，古音盖读若耦之平声。 诗绸缪「三星在隅」，与「逅」为韵。 偷、渝、隅古音皆侯部字。 又曰：俞、禺二字今音与鱼、虞同，而古音皆在侯部，其从俞声、禺声之字，并当入侯。 ……老子：「上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质直若渝，大方若隅。 」谷、辱、足皆侯部之入声，偷、渝皆侯部之平声，而隅与之为韵，则从禺声之字皆隅之类，不但如唐韵厚部所收之偶、耦、藕等字矣。 右景龙碑本九十五字，敦煌本、河本、王本同，傅本九十七字，范本九十八字。 河上本题「同异第四十一」，王本题「四十一章」，范本题「上士闻道章第四十一」。 四十二章 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 谦之案：淮南子天文训：「道日规，始于一。 」王念孙曰：「『日规』二字与上下文义不相属，此因上文『故曰规生矩杀』而误衍也。 宋书律书作『道始于一』，无『日规』二字。 」今案王说是也。 淮南义本老子此章，故下文曰：「一而不生，故分而为阴阳，阴阳合和万物生。 故曰一生二，二生三，三生万物。 」又庄子天地篇「泰初有无无，有无名，一之所起，有一而未形」，语本老子一章「无名，天地始」与本章「道生一」之旨。 又黄帝内经太素卷十九知针石篇杨上善注曰：「从道生一，谓之朴也； 一分为二，谓天地也； 从二生三，谓阴阳和气也； 从三以生万物，分为九野、四时、日月乃至万物。 」语亦出此。 又案：道生一，一者气也。 庄子知北游篇曰：「通天下一气耳，圣人故贵一。 」李道纯曰：「道生一，虚无生一气； 一生二，一气判阴阳。 」赵志坚曰：「一，元气，道之始也，古昔天地万物同得一气而有生。 」大田晴轩曰：「一二三，古今解者纷纭不一。 案淮南天文训：『规生矩杀，衡长权藏，绳居中央，为四时根。 道日规，始于一，一而不生，故分而为阴阳，阴阳合和而万物生。 故曰道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 』此以一为一气，二为阴阳，三为阴阳交通之和也，此说极妥贴。 」又曰：「案道，理也； 一，一气也； 庄周所谓『一之所起，有一而未形』，是也。 二，阴阳也； 三，形气质之始也。 第十四章曰：『此三者不可致诘，故混而为一。 』盖此三也。 意谓道生一气，一气分为阴阳，气化流行于天地之间，形气质具，而后万物生焉，故曰『三生万物』。 」 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 谦之案：淮南精神训引「万物背阴而抱阳，冲气以为和」，高诱注：「万物以背为阴，以腹为阳。 」又汉书高帝纪注引作「向阴而负阳」。 又列子天瑞篇：「冲和气者为人。 」太素卷十九知针石篇杨上善注曰：「万物负阴抱阳，冲气以为和，万物尽从三气而生，故人之形不离阴阳也。 」语皆本此。 「抱」，傅本作「袌」；
