chunks.original_text: 「噎」有忧义。 刘端临经传小记曰：「噎，忧也。 诗『中心如噎』，传曰：『噎忧不能息也。 』噎忧双声字。 玉篇引『诗「中心如噎」，谓噎忧不能息也』，增一『谓』字，最得毛氏之意。 『噎忧』即『欭嚘』，气逆也。 说文『欭』字注：『忧也。 』玉篇『嚘』字注：『老子曰：「终日号而不嚘。 」嚘，气逆也，亦作○。 』广韵：『欭，忧叹也。 』『○，气逆也。 』噎、噫、欭、忧一声之转。 」案端临所见，王念孙方言疏证补（高邮王氏遗书本第三册）引之，谓「实贯通毛传、方言之旨」是也。 今据以订正老子，知「号而嘶不嗄」，「嗄」是故书，其演变为「嚘」，为「○」，因又转为「噫」，为「哑」，盖皆方言之变耳。 易顺鼎曰：「按庄子庚桑楚篇云『终日号而嗌不嗄』，正本老子之文，较之太玄、玉篇更为近古可据。 『嗄』即史记刺客传『舌炭为哑』之『哑』，索隐谓：『哑，喑病也。 』此章以螫、据、搏、固、作、嗄为韵，皆古音同部字，若作『嚘』则无韵矣。 释文：『嗄，一迈反，又于介反。 』音并非。 」章炳麟曰：「司马彪曰：『楚人谓极无声曰嗄。 』今通谓不能言者为『嗄』，极无声亦曰『嗄』，通借『哑』字为之。 『哑』本训笑，易言『笑言哑哑』，然史记刺客列传已云『吞为哑』，其假借久矣。 」（新方言四）据此知「哑」为假借字，本字实为「嗄」。 「嗄」「哑」同字，故河上、柰卷作「哑」，然「哑」为后起之字，欲复老子古本之真，则宜从碑本作「嗄」，作「嚘」、作「○」、作「噫」、作「哑」皆非也。 知和曰常，知常曰明，益生曰祥，心使气曰强。 严可均曰：「知常曰明」，河上作「日明」，下二句皆然。 武内义雄曰：「益生曰祥」之「祥」字，罗振玉所藏敦煌本作「详」。 案「祥」为「牂」之假借，与「壮」同义，与下「物壮则老」之「壮」字相应。 谦之案：罗考异未及此。 校罗卷确为「详」字，与遂州本同，罗失校。 遂本无「知常曰明」句。 「曰」字，景福、柰卷作「日」，下三句皆然； 室町本下三句作「日」，首句作「曰」。 「强」字，楼正、武内敦本作「强」，傅奕「曰强」作「则强」。 又「益生曰祥」，李道纯作「益生不祥」。 道德会元序例云：「『益生不祥』，或云『日祥』，或云『曰祥』，皆非也。 」李本据河上丈人章句白本，理长。 庄子德充符篇：「常因自然而不益生。 」盖益生则老子所谓「生生之厚」，反于自然而动之，不祥是也。 「不祥」二字，经文三见：三十一章「夫佳兵者不祥之器」，「兵者不祥之器」，七十八章「受国不祥」。 惟此独作「祥」字，似有可疑。 盖祥有妖祥之义。 李奇曰：「内妖曰眚，外妖曰祥。 」玉篇：「祥，妖怪也。 」是祥即不祥。 道德经取善集引孙登曰：「生生之厚，动之妖祥。 」是也。 「曰祥」，说亦通。 易顺鼎曰：按祥即不祥。 书序云「有祥桑谷共生于朝」，与此「祥」字同义。 王注曰：「生不可益，益之则夭。 」「夭」字当为「妖」，盖以「妖」解「祥」字。 谦之案：道藏张太守汇刻四家注引王弼正作「妖」。 马叙伦曰：河上注曰：「人能知道之常行，则日以明达于玄妙也。 」是河上亦作「日明」。
chunks.translated_text:
The character *"噎"* [yē] carries the meaning of *"worry."*

Liu Duānlín’s [刘端临] *Jīngchuán Xiǎojì* [经传小记] states:
*"噎"* [yē] means *"worry."* In the *Shī* [诗], *"Centered like noise"* [中心如噎], the *Zhuàn* [传] says: *"Noise—worry that cannot be stilled."* *"噎"* [yē] and *"忧"* [yōu] are rhyming words. The *Yùpiàn* [玉篇] cites *"The Shī: ‘Centered like noise,’ meaning noise—worry that cannot be stilled,"* adding the word *"meaning"* [谓], most accurately capturing Máo Qí’s [毛奇] intent. *"噎忧"* [yēyōu] is the same as *"欭嚘"* [yìngōng], meaning *"reversed qi."* The *Shuōwén* [说文] defines *"欭"* [yì] as *"worry."* The *Yùpiàn* [玉篇] annotates *"嚘"* [gōng] as: *"Lǎozǐ [老子] says: ‘All day crying yet not 嚘.’ 嚘 means reversed qi, also written as ○."* The *Guǎngyùn* [广韵] states: *"欭 [yì], sighing in worry. ○, reversed qi."* *"噎"* [yē], *"噫"* [yī], *"欭"* [yì], and *"忧"* [yōu] are variations of the same sound.

By examining Liu’s observations, Wáng Niǎnsūn’s [王念孙] *Fāngyán Shūzhèng Bǔ* [方言疏证补] (from the *Gāoyóu Wángshì Yíshū* [高邮王氏遗书], Vol. 3) cites it, declaring: *"This truly unifies the intent of Máo’s commentary and dialectal usage."* Now, based on this, we correct *Lǎozǐ* [老子], knowing that *"号而嘶不嗄"* [háo ér sī bù shà] should have *"嗄"* [shà] as the original text, which later evolved into *"嚘"* [gōng], then *"○"* [yī], and further transformed into *"噫"* [yī], and finally *"哑"* [yǎ]—all being dialectal variations.

Yì Shùndǐng [易顺鼎] says:
*"According to *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子], *Gēngsāng Cǔ* [庚桑楚], it states: ‘All day crying yet not 嗌 [shà] not 嗄 [shà].’ This is the original text of *Lǎozǐ* [老子], closer to antiquity than *Tàixuàn* [太玄] or *Yùpiàn* [玉篇]. 嗄 [shà] is the same as the ‘charcoal tongue made mute’ [舌炭为哑] in *Shǐjì* [史记], *Cìkè Zhuan* [刺客传]. The *Suǒyǐn* [索隐] states: ‘哑 [yǎ], a speech impediment.’ This chapter rhymes with 螫 [shì], 据 [jù], 搏 [bó], 固 [gù], 作 [zuò], 嗄 [shà], all ancient phonetic rhymes. If written as 嚘 [gōng], there would be no rhyme. The *Shìwén Jiězhu* [释文] states: ‘嗄 [shà], one reads as *mài* [迈], another as *yújiè* [于介].’ The pronunciation is incorrect."*

Zhāng Bǐnglín [章炳麟] says:
*"Sīmǎ Biāo [司马彪] states: ‘The Chu [楚] term for utter silence is 嗄 [shà].’ Today, 嗄 [shà] commonly refers to those unable to speak, and utter silence is also called 嗄 [shà], often borrowed as 哑 [yǎ]. 哑 [yǎ] originally means ‘laughter,’ as in *Yì* [易]: ‘Laughing speech, 哑哑 [yǎyǎ].’ Yet, the *Shǐjì* [史记], *Cìkè Lièzhuan* [刺客列传], already uses ‘swallowed into mute’ [吞为哑], showing its long-standing usage as a borrowed character."* (*Xīn Fāngyán* [新方言], Vol. 4)

From this, we know *"哑"* [yǎ] is a borrowed character, with *"嗄"* [shà] as the original. *"嗄"* [shà] and *"哑"* [yǎ] are the same character, so *Héshàng* [河上] and *Nǎi* [柰] volumes use *"哑"* [yǎ]. However, *"哑"* [yǎ] is a later character. To restore *Lǎozǐ* [老子]’s ancient text, we should follow the stele inscription’s *"嗄"* [shà]. Writing it as *"嚘"* [gōng], *"○"* [yī], *"噫"* [yī], or *"哑"* [yǎ] is incorrect.

---
*"Knowing harmony as constant, knowing constancy as clarity, augmenting life as auspicious, directing qi by the heart as strength."*

Yán Kějūn [严可均] states: *"Knowing constancy as clarity"* [知常曰明], the *Héshàng* [河上] version reads *"日明"* [rìmíng], and the same applies to the following two sentences.

Bùnài Yìyǒng [武内义雄] notes that in the *"augmenting life as auspicious"* [益生曰祥] passage, the *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌] manuscript preserved by Luó Zhènyù [罗振玉] reads *"详"* [xiáng].

Upon examination, *"祥"* [xiáng] is a borrowed character for *"牂"* [zāng], synonymous with *"壮"* [zhuàng], aligning with the *"物壮则老"* [wùzhuàngzélǎo] *"壮"* [zhuàng] below. My note: Luó Zhènyù’s [罗振玉] *Kǎoyì* [考异] did not account for this. The *Suìzhōu* [遂州] edition confirms *"详"* [xiáng], while Luó failed to correct it. The *Suì* [遂] edition lacks the *"Knowing constancy as clarity"* [知常曰明] sentence.

The word *"曰"* [yuē], in *Jǐngfú* [景福] and *Nǎi* [柰] volumes, is written as *"日"* [rì] for all three following sentences. The *Shìtōng* [室町] edition writes *"日"* [rì] for the last three sentences but *"曰"* [yuē] for the first.

The character *"强"* [qiáng], in *Lóuzhèng* [楼正] and *Wǔnèi Dūnhuáng* [武内敦煌] editions, is *"强"* [qiáng], while Fù Yì [傅奕]’s *"曰强"* [yuēqiáng] reads *"则强"* [zéqiáng].

Additionally, *"益生曰祥"* [yìshēngyuēxiáng], Lǐ Dàochún [李道纯]’s version reads *"益生不祥"* [yìshēngbùxiáng]. The *Dàodé Huìyuán Xùlì* [道德会元序例] states: *"‘益生不祥’ is sometimes written as ‘日祥’ or ‘曰祥,’ both incorrect."* Lǐ’s [李] edition, based on *Héshàng Zhàngrén Zhāngjù Báiběn* [河上丈人章句白本], is logically sound.

In *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子], *Déchōng Fú* [德充符]: *"Constantly following nature without augmenting life."* Augmenting life contradicts *Lǎozǐ*’s [老子] *"generative generosity"* [生生之厚], acting against spontaneity—thus, *"not auspicious"* [不祥].

The phrase *"不祥"* [bùxiáng] appears three times in the text: Chapter 31 *"佳兵者不祥之器"* [jiābīngzhébùxiángzhīqì], *"兵者不祥之器"* [bīngzhébùxiángzhīqì], and Chapter 78 *"受国不祥"* [shòuguóbùxiáng]. Only here does it appear as *"祥"* [xiáng], which is questionable. *"祥"* [xiáng] carries the meaning of *"omen"* or *"portent."* Lǐ Qí [李奇] states: *"Internal portents are called *‘shèng’* [眚], external portents are called *‘xiáng’* [祥]."* The *Yùpiàn* [玉篇] defines *"祥"* [xiáng] as *"portentous omens."* Thus, *"祥"* [xiáng] is synonymous with *"不祥"* [bùxiáng].

The *Dàodé Jīng*’s *Qǔshàn Jíyǐn* [取善集引] cites Sūn Dēng [孙登]: *"Generative generosity, when acted upon, becomes a portentous omen."* This aligns with the passage.

Yì Shùndǐng [易顺鼎] states: *"‘祥’* [xiáng] is the same as *‘不祥’* [bùxiáng]. The *Shū* [书] *Xù* [序] says: ‘There was an auspicious *xiáng* [祥]—the *sāng* [桑] and *gǔ* [谷] trees grew together in the morning,’ where *xiáng* [祥] shares the same meaning. Wáng Bì’s [王弼] annotation states: ‘Life cannot be augmented; augmenting it leads to decline.’ The character *‘夭’* [yāo] should be *‘妖’* [yāo], interpreting *‘xiáng’* [xiáng] as *‘妖’* [yāo]."* My note: The *Dàozàng* [道藏] *Zhāng Tàishǒu Huìkè Sìjiā Zhù* [张太守汇刻四家注] cites Wáng Bì [王弼] as writing *"妖"* [yāo].

Mǎ Xùlún [马叙伦] states: *"The *Héshàng* [河上] annotation says: ‘If one knows the constant Dao and acts accordingly, one’s understanding will daily grow clearer toward the mysterious.’"* Thus, *Héshàng* [河上] also writes *"日明"* [rìmíng].
chunks.overlap_context:
assage originates from *Lǎozǐ* [老子]. *"嚘"* [嚘], composed of the radicals *"mouth"* [口] and *"worry"* [忧], resembles *"嗄"* [嗄] in form and is close in meaning, with *"嗄"* [嗄] likely being the original character.

Sīmǎ Biāo’s [司马彪] annotation in *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子]’s *Gēngsāng Cǔ* [庚桑楚] states: *"The Chu [楚] term for utter silence is *‘嗄’* [嗄]."* Since *Lǎozǐ* [老子] was a Chu [楚] person, he used Chu [楚] dialect, and thus *"嗌"* [嗌] in Qin [秦] and Jin [晋] would also be rendered as *"嗄"* [嗄] or *"噎"* [噎].

chunks.original_text: 成疏曰：「多贪世利，厚益其生，所以烦恼障累，日日增广。 」又曰：「是以生死之业，日日强盛。 」是成「曰祥」作「日祥」。 ……伦谓「日」为「曰」误，「曰」「则」通用。 谦之案：作「曰」是也。 淮南道应训、文子下德篇引并作「曰」，当从之。 刘文典三余札记（卷一）谓「曰当为日，形似而误」，以河上本此章为证，非是。 马叙伦又曰：「气」当作「气」，「强」借为「僵」。 庄子则阳篇「推而强之」，玉篇引作「僵」，是其例证。 ……老、庄「气」字有视「心」字义为胜者，如庄子人间世篇：「无听之以耳，而听之以心； 无听之以心，而听之以气。 气也者，虚而待物者也。 」应帝王曰：「汝游心于淡，合气于漠。 」本书「专气致柔」，「冲气以为和」，皆是也。 此「气」字义亦然，故曰「心使气曰僵」。 俞樾曰：按此下本有「是故用其光，复归其明」二句，后人因已见于五十二章而删去之耳。 淮南道应篇引老子曰：「知和曰常，知常曰明，益生曰祥，心使气曰强，是故用其光，复归其明也。 」是古本有此二句之明证。 且「用其光，复归其明」，正见物不可终壮之意。 故下文曰：「物壮则老，谓之不道，不道早已。 」今脱此二句，则与下文之意不属矣。 文子下德篇曰「知和曰常，知常曰明，益生曰祥，心使气曰强，是谓玄同，用其光，复归其明」，亦有下二句。 物壮则老，谓之不道，不道早已。 严可均曰：「谓之不道」，御注、高翿作「是谓不道」。 罗振玉曰：两「不」字，敦煌本并作「非」。 谦之案：作「不」是也。 「早已」当作「早亡」，说见第三十章。 遂州本、顾本「不」作「非」，严本上句作「非」，下句作「不」。 楼正、磻溪、彭、傅、范、赵并同此石。 王羲之「谓之」作「是谓」，河上「物壮则老」作「物壮将老」，广明「早已」作「早以」。 又太素卷三引老子三句同此。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读：螫、据、搏、固、作、嗄韵（鱼部，螫音恕，搏音布，作音诅，嗄，疏去声）。 常、明、祥、强、（阳部），老、道、已韵（之、幽通韵，老，卢叟反，已协音酉）。 谦之案：老、道，幽部，已，之部，此之、幽通韵。 姚文田、邓廷桢同，惟「嗄」作「哑」，「已」字无韵。 高本汉：「螫」作「赦」，赦、搏、作与据、固相间为韵，老、道、已韵。 顾炎武唐韵正二十二昔：「螫」去声则音赦。 十九铎「搏」去声则音甫，引老子此章，作音则故反，嗄音户。 江有诰唐韵四声正二十二昔曰：「螫」，施只切。 按古有去声，当与御部并收。 老子玄符篇「毒虫不螫」，与据、搏（音布）协。 孔广森诗声类（九）鱼类曰：古文去入通协者，老子：「猛兽不据，攫鸟不搏，骨弱筋柔而握固。 」 邓廷桢曰：螫、据、搏、固、作、嗄为韵。 按「抟」当作「搏」。 说文「搏」字解云：「索持也。 」周礼射人「狸首」注云：「狸善持者也，持即搏也。 」淮南子曰：「鸟穷则搏，兽穷则攫。 」此其义也。 周礼环人「搏谍贼」，经典释文「搏，房布反」，为御部字，此其音也。 此节上下文皆用御韵，不应此句独无，惟作「搏」则于韵正协。 又尔雅曰「攫父善顾」，郭注云：「能攫持人，善顾盼。
chunks.translated_text:
Chéng Shū states: *"Excessive greed for worldly gain and excessive augmentation of life are what give rise to daily proliferation of afflictions and entanglements."* He further says: *"Thus, the karmic causes of birth and death grow ever stronger each day."* This confirms that Chéng’s *"rìxiáng"* [日祥] should be *"rìxiáng"* [曰祥].

Mǎ Xùlún argues that *"rì"* [日] is a mistaken transcription for *"yuē"* [曰], as *"yuē"* [曰] and *"zé"* [则] are interchangeable. My note: The reading *"yuē"* [曰] is correct. The *Húinán Dàoyīng Xiàn* [淮南道应训] and *Wénzǐ Xià Dé Piān* [文子下德篇] both cite it as *"yuē"* [曰], and this should be followed. Liú Wéndiǎn’s *Sānyú Zházhì* (卷一) claims *"yuē"* [曰] should be *"rì"* [日], mistaken due to similar shapes, but this is incorrect, as the *Héshàng* text here proves otherwise.

Mǎ Xùlún further states: *"Qì"* [气] should be *"qì"* [气], and *"qiáng"* [强] is borrowed as *"jiāng"* [僵]. In the *Zhuāngzǐ Jiéyáng Piān* [庄子则阳篇], *"tuī ér qiáng zhī"* [推而强之] is cited in the *Yù Piān* [玉篇] as *"jiāng"* [僵], providing the precedent.

In *Lǎozǐ* and *Zhuāngzǐ*, the term *"qì"* [气] often surpasses *"xīn"* [心] in meaning, as seen in *Zhuāngzǐ Rénjiānshì Piān* [庄子人间世篇]:
*"Do not listen with the ears, but listen with the heart; do not listen with the heart, but listen with the *qì* [气]. The *qì* [气] is the empty vessel that awaits things."* In *Yìng Dìwáng* [应帝王], it states: *"Let your mind dwell in serenity, and harmonize your *qì* [气] with emptiness."* In this text, *"zhuāng qì zhì róu"* [专气致柔] and *"chōng qì yǐwéi hé"* [冲气以为和] all follow this usage. Thus, *"xīn shǐ qì yuē jiāng"* [心使气曰僵] is correct.

Yú Yì states: *"Below this passage, the original text originally included the lines: ‘Thus, using its brilliance, it returns to its clarity.’ Later commentators omitted them, having already appeared in Chapter 52."* The *Húinán Dàoyīng Piān* [淮南道应篇] cites *Lǎozǐ* as saying: *"Knowing harmony is called constancy; knowing constancy is called clarity; augmenting life is called *xiáng* [祥]; the heart directing *qì* [气] is called *qiáng* [强]. Thus, using its brilliance, it returns to its clarity."* This confirms that the ancient text originally contained these two lines.

Moreover, *"Using its brilliance, it returns to its clarity"* clearly illustrates the idea that things cannot remain perpetually vigorous. Hence, the following passage states: *"When vigor peaks, decay follows—this is called *bùdào* [不道]; *bùdào* [不道] brings early demise."* If these two lines are omitted, the meaning disconnects from what follows.

The *Wénzǐ Xià Dé Piān* [文子下德篇] states: *"Knowing harmony is called constancy; knowing constancy is called clarity; augmenting life is called *xiáng* [祥]; the heart directing *qì* [气] is called *qiáng* [强]. This is called *Xuántóng* [玄同]; using its brilliance, it returns to its clarity."* It also includes the subsequent two lines: *"When vigor peaks, decay follows—this is called *bùdào* [不道]; *bùdào* [不道] brings early demise."* Yán Kějūn states: *"This is called *bùdào* [不道]"* is annotated in the *Yùzhù* [御注] and *Gāoxì* [高翿] as *"Shìwèi bùdào"* [是谓不道]. Luó Zhènyù notes that in the *Dūnjiāng* [敦煌] manuscripts, both *"bù"* [不] are written as *"fēi"* [非]. My note: The reading *"bù"* [不] is correct. *"Zǎoyǐ"* [早已] should be *"zǎowáng"* [早亡], as explained in Chapter 30. The *Suìzhōu* [遂州] and *Gù* [顾] editions write *"fēi"* [非] for *"bù"* [不], while the *Yán* [严] edition writes *"fēi"* [非] in the first instance and *"bù"* [不] in the second. The *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], *Pánxī* [磻溪], *Péng* [彭], *Fù* [傅], *Fàn* [范], and *Zhào* [赵] editions all follow the stone text. Wáng Xīzhī writes *"shìwèi"* [是谓] instead of *"wèi"* [谓之], while *Héshàng* [河上] writes *"wù zhuàng zé lǎo"* [物壮则老] as *"wù zhuàng jiāng lǎo"* [物壮将老], and *Guāngmíng* [广明] writes *"zǎoyǐ"* [早已] as *"zǎoyǐ"* [早以]. The *Tàisū* [太素] Volume 3 also cites these three lines identically.

**[Phonology]** Jiāng Shì’s rhyme reading for this chapter:
*Shì* [螫], *jù* [据], *bó* [搏], *gù* [固], *zuò* [作], *shà* [嗄] (Fish department, *shì* as *shù*, *bó* as *bù*, *zuò* as *zǔ*, *shà* as *shū* with a falling tone).
*Cháng* [常], *míng* [明], *xiáng* [祥], *qiáng* [强] (Yang department),
*Lǎo* [老], *dào* [道], *yǐ* [已] (Zhi and Yu departments, *lǎo* as *lùshòu*, *yǐ* as *yǒuyǔ*).

My note: *Lǎo* [老] and *dào* [道] belong to the Yu department, while *yǐ* [已] belongs to the Zhi department, thus forming a *zhī-yōu* [之幽] rhyme. Yáo Wéntián and Dèng Tíngzhēn agree, except they write *"shà"* [嗄] as *"yǎ"* [哑] and omit the rhyme for *"yǐ"* [已]. Gāo Běn Hàn states that *"shì"* [螫] should be *"shè"* [赦], making *shè* [赦], *bó* [搏], *zuò* [作] rhyme with *jù* [据] and *gù* [固].

Gǔ Yánwù’s *Tángyùn Zhèng* (Volume 22, *Xī* [昔]): *"Shì"* [螫] in the falling tone is pronounced as *shè* [赦]. Volume 19, *Du* [铎]: *"Bó"* [搏] in the falling tone is pronounced as *fú* [甫], and in the citation of this *Lǎozǐ* passage, it is pronounced as *jùgù* [故反], while *"shà"* [嗄] is pronounced as *hù* [户]. Jiāng Yǒuguò’s *Tángyùn Sìshēng Zhèng* (Volume 22, *Xī* [昔]) states: *"Shì"* [螫], pronounced as *shìzhǐ* [施只].

According to ancient usage, the falling and entering tones were interchangeable in rhyme. In *Lǎozǐ*, it states: *"Fierce beasts do not *jù* [据], grasping birds do not *bó* [搏]; though bones are weak and sinews supple, their grip is firm."* Dèng Tíngzhēn states: *"Shì"* [螫], *"jù"* [据], *"bó"* [搏], *"gù"* [固], *"zuò"* [作], *"shà"* [嗄] form a rhyme. I note that *"tuán"* [抟] should be *"bó"* [搏]. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* [说文解字] defines *"bó"* [搏] as *"seizing and holding."* The *Zhōulǐ Shèrén* [周礼射人] annotation for *"lífǒu"* [狸首] states: *"The weasel is skilled at holding, and ‘holding’ is the same as ‘bó’ [搏]."* The *Húinánzǐ* [淮南子] says: *"When birds are cornered, they *bó* [搏]; when beasts are cornered, they *jué* [攫]."* This is its meaning. The *Zhōulǐ Huánrén* [周礼环人] states: *"Bó tièzéi"* [搏谍贼], and the *Jīngdiǎn Shìwén* [经典释文] annotates *"bó"* [搏] as *fángbù* [房布], belonging to the Yu department. This confirms its pronunciation. Since the entire passage above and below uses the Yu rhyme, this single line should not lack it—only *"bó"* [搏] makes the rhyme consistent.

Additionally, the *Ēryá* [尔雅] states: *"Juéfù shàn gù"* [攫父善顾], and Guō Xiànzhě’s annotation says: *"One who is skilled at seizing and holding others, and good at glancing around."*

「攫」 in the *Shuōwén Jiězì* is defined as *"the large mother monkey, skilled at seizing and holding others."*

The passage here, in its meaning, speaks of how poisonous insects are skilled at stinging (*shì* [螫]) yet do not sting, fierce beasts are skilled at seizing (*jù* [据]) yet do not seize, birds skilled at *bó* [搏] yet do not *bó*, and thus the sense also aligns.

Again, the character 「作」 was pronounced in ancient times like *zuò* [阼], *zì* [胙].

The *Yu* rhyme group’s ancient pronunciation was in the *Gòng* [御] department, though the *Shuōwén Jiězì* has no 「嗄」 character. The *Guǎngyuàn* [广韵] cites 「嗄」 from the *Lǎozǐ* [老子]: *"终日号而不嗄"*, annotated as *"the voice does not change."* The *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] says of *Gēngsāng Chǔ* [庚桑楚]: *"终日嗥而嗌不嗄"*, matching this text. Thus, the *Lǎozǐ* originally had 「嗄」, rhyming with *shì* [螫], *jù* [据], *bó* [搏], *gù* [固], and 「作」.

Fù Yì [傅奕] emended the *Lǎozǐ* to read 「不○」; the *Yùpiàn* [玉篇] cites 「嚘」 in this passage as 「不嚘」, annotated as *"the qi is obstructed."* Both variations stem from not recognizing 「嗄」 as a character belonging to the *Yu* rhyme group, leading to divergent readings.

Additionally, the *Lǎo* [老] and *Dào* [道] characters form a rhyme, both belonging to the *Yōu* [幽] department’s upper tone. 「老」 in ancient pronunciation was in the *Yōu* [黝] department: it rhymes with 「手」 in the *Shījì* [击鼓], with 「酒」 in *Nǚyuē* [女曰], with 「雠」, 「犹」, and 「丑」 in *Cǎiqí* [采芑], and with 「首」 in *Xiǎobiàn* [小弁]. In *Pànshuǐ* [泮水], it rhymes with 「○」, 「酒」, 「道」, and 「丑」.

The *Jīngdìng Shìwén* [景龙碑本] has **77 characters**, the *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌本] **75**, the *Héshàng* [河上] **79**, the *Wáng* [王本] **81**, the *Fù* [傅本] **83**, and the *Fàn* [范本] **82**.

The *Héshàng* [河上] titles this as *"Chapter of Mysterious Harmony, the Fifty-Fifth"* (玄符第五十五), the *Wáng* [王本] as *"Chapter Fifty-Five"* (五十五章), and the *Fàn* [范本] as *"Chapter of the Depth of Virtue, the Fifty-Fifth"* (含德之厚章第五十五).

---
**Chapter Fifty-Six**
The wise do not speak; those who speak do not know.

*According to my examination*: The *Fù* [傅本] and *Fàn* [范本] both append 「也」 after 「不言」 and 「不知」. The *Héshàng* [河上公], *Wáng* [王弼], and other versions, as well as the annotations in *Lǐhuò Lùn* [理惑论], *Wénxuǎn* [文选]’s *Wèi Dū Fù* [魏都赋], and *Yùnmìng Lùn* [运命论], all omit these two 「也」 characters. *Fǔxíng Jì* [辅行记] also cites the same, but changes 「者」 to 「则」. The *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] in *Tiāndào Piān* [天道篇] states: *"则知者不言，言者不知."* In *Zhīběi Yóu Piān* [知北游篇]: *"夫知者不言，言者不知."* Both passages derive from this text and also lack 「也」.

Seal its *yuè* [兑], close its gate, blunt its sharpness, disperse its wrath, harmonize its brilliance, and blend its dust—this is called *Mystic Uniformity* (玄同).

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: In the *Héshàng* [河上] version, 「解其忿」 is written as 「纷」, while *Wáng* [王弼] renders it as 「分」.

*Wǔnèi Yìxióng* [武内义雄] states: The *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌本], *Jǐngfú* [景福本], and *Suì* [遂本] all use 「忿」, likely because 「纷」 is a borrowed character for 「忿」.

*According to my examination*: The *Jǐngfú* [景福本], *Yán Zūn* [严遵], and *Gāo Yì* [高翿] also use 「忿」, while *Qíng Xuán* [邢玄], *Pánxī* [磻溪], *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], *Nǎi Juàn* [柰卷], *Gù Huān* [顾欢], *Péng* [彭], *Fù* [傅], *Fàn* [范], and *Zhào* [赵] render it as 「纷」. The *Lǚlùn* [吕览]’s *Shèn Dà Piān* [慎大篇] annotates 「纷纷分分」 as *"fear and resentment"*, likely considering 「分」 a contracted form of 「棼」. The *Shìwén Jiězì* [释文] for *Zuǒyǐn Sìchuán* [左隐四传] defines 「棼」 as *"chaos"*. *Wáng* [王本]’s 「解其分」 means to disperse its disorder. The *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌本], *Jǐngfú* [景福本], and *Suì* [遂本] all use 「忿」. The *Guǎngyǎ* [广雅]’s *Shìgǔ* [释诂] defines 「忿」 as *"anger"*. The *Yì Xiàngtuán* [易象传] states: *"The virtuous one restrains anger and checks desires."* The *Chūcí* [楚辞]’s *Huáishā* [怀沙] uses 「惩改忿兮」, annotated as *"resentment"*, where 「改忿」 also means 「解其忿」—both interpretations are consistent.

*Yì Shùndīng* [易顺鼎] says: These six lines have already appeared earlier; likely they are a repetition. The four lines of 「挫其锐」 match the *Shàng Piān* [上篇]’s *Dìsì Piān* [第四章], suggesting this annotation may also belong to the *Shàng Piān*’s *Dìsì Piān*. Both annotations in *Wénxuǎn* [文选]’s *Wèi Dū Fù* [魏都赋] and *Yùnmìng Lùn* [运命论] cite only the *Lǎozǐ* [老子]’s line: *"知者不言，言者不知，是谓玄同"*, without these six lines, confirming their duplication.

Thus, it cannot be approached with excessive familiarity, nor can it be avoided with excessive distance;

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: Before 「不可得而疏」, the *Héshàng* [河上] version adds 「亦」, and the same applies to the following two lines.

*Luó Zhènyù* [罗振玉] states: The *Jǐngfú* [景福本] lacks the 「而」 character, and the same applies to the next five lines.

*According to my examination*: The *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌本] and *Suì* [遂本] omit the six 「而」 characters; the *Yán Zūn* [严遵] and *Péng* [彭] versions lack 「故」; the *Fù* [傅本] and *Fàn* [范本] versions include 「亦」, and the same applies below.

It cannot be exploited for gain, nor can it be harmed;

*Bì Qián* [毕沅] notes: *Wáng* [王弼] omits 「亦」, and the same applies below.

Additionally, 「害」 is written as 「刿」. *Sū Língzhī* [苏灵芝]’s text renders it as 「秽」. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* [说文解字] defines 「刿」 as *"sharp injury"*, but has no 「秽」 character.

It cannot be esteemed as noble, nor can it be disdained as lowly.
Thus, it is held in highest honor by the world.

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: All versions lack 「亦」, except the *Héshàng* [河上].

*According to my examination*: In the sentence 「而疏」, *Nǎi Juàn* [柰卷] includes 「亦」. In the sentences 「而害」 and 「而贱」, *Nǎi Juàn* [柰卷] and *Gù Huān* [顾欢] both include 「亦」. The sentence 「不可得而贵」 is omitted in *Zhào* [赵].

Additionally, the *Zhuāngzǐ* [庄子] in *Xúnwúguǐ Piān* [徐无鬼篇] states: *"Thus, the true person has none whom he holds in excessive familiarity, nor has he any whom he avoids with excessive distance, embracing virtue and brilliance, to harmonize with the world—this is called the true person."*

**[Phonology]** In this chapter, Jiang’s rhyme reads: *mén* (門), *fēn* (纷), *chén* (尘) rhyme (文部). *Yáo Wéndiàn* [姚文田] and *Xī Zòng* [奚侗] agree. *Gāo Běn Hàn* [高本汉] treats *duì* (兑), *ruì* (锐), *mén* (门), *fēn* (纷), *chén* (尘), and *guāng* (光), *tóng* (同) as alternating rhymes. *Duì* rhymes with *ruì*, *mén* with *fēn* and *chén*, and *guāng* with *tóng*—this is an example of rhyming across separate lines.

The *Jǐnglóng* [景龙] stele version contains **68 characters**, the *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌] version **60**, the *Héshàng* [河上] version **69**, the *Wáng* [王] version **66**, and the *Fù* [傅] and *Fàn* [范] versions **70**. The *Héshàng* [河上] version is titled *"Chapter 56 on Mysterious Virtue"* [玄德第五十六], the *Wáng* [王] version *"Chapter 56"* [五十六章], and the *Fàn* [范] version *"Chapter 56 on the Wise Who Speak Not"* [知者不言章第五十六].

**Chapter 57: Governing the State with Rectitude**
*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: The *Yù Zhù* [御注] misinterprets 「以正」 as 「以政」.
*Wǔ Nèi Yì Xióng* [武内义雄] states: The *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌] and *Suì* [遂] versions read 「政」.

*According to my examination*: The *Fù Yì* [傅奕], *Xíng Xuàn* [邢玄], *Pánxī* [磻溪], and the *Wénzǐ Shàng Lǐ Piān* [文子上礼篇] all read 「政」. *Nǎi Juàn* [柰卷] reads 「以正之国」, *Gù Huān* [顾欢] reads 「以正理国」, while the *Héshàng Gōng* [河上公] and *Wáng Rì* [王弼] versions follow this stele.

*Yǐn Wénzǐ Dàdào Xià* [尹文子大道下] cites *Lǎozǐ* [老子] as saying: *"Governing the state with rectitude, employing the Dao/Way in warfare, and attaining the world through non-action. Rectitude refers to established laws and norms."* *Gù Běnchéng* [顾本成] glosses: *"Rectitude refers to the laws and teachings of the state"*—this aligns with *Yǐn Wénzǐ* [尹文子], likely reflecting the perspective of the *Námiǎ* [名法] school.

*According to my examination*: 「正」 and 「政」 were interchangeable in ancient usage, but here, paired with 「奇」, it should read 「正」. In **Chapter 45**, *"Calmness and tranquility are the Dao/Way for the world"* [清静为天下正], and in this chapter, *"I love tranquility, and the people naturally align with rectitude"* [我好静而民自正], both should use the original character.

*Employing the Dao/Way in warfare*

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: The *Yù Zhù* [御注] mistakenly reads 「以奇」 as 「以其」.
*Liú Shīpéi* [刘师培] says: Since 「奇」 is paired with 「正」, its meaning aligns with *yé* (邪, "deviant"). The *Guānzǐ Báixīn Piān* [管子白心篇] glosses: *"A deviant person is one whose name and conduct are ruined"* [奇身名废], and explains: *"Deviant means unorthodox and not rectified."* Thus, 「奇」 means "not rectified," and *employing the Dao/Way in warfare* refers to "not relying on orthodox military methods."

*Attaining the world through non-action.*

How do I know this to be so?
*According to this.*

*According to my examination*: *Attaining the world* refers to *winning the hearts of the people*. In **Chapter 48**, it states: *"What is called attaining the world is to do so through non-action; when there is action, it is insufficient to attain the world."* *Xúnzǐ Wángzhì Piān* [荀子王制篇] corroborates this: *"Chéng Hóu* [成侯] and *Sì Gōng* [嗣公] were rulers who accumulated wealth and calculated numbers, but they did not win the people’s hearts. *Zǐchǎn* [子产] won the people’s hearts, but he did not implement governance."* *Yáng Tà* [杨倞] annotates: *"Unattained means their abilities were insufficient; winning the people’s hearts refers to gaining the people’s loyalty."* Thus, observing that action fails to win the people’s hearts confirms that non-action can gain their loyalty and attain the world.

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: The phrase *知其然* [知其然], in the *Héshàng* [河上], *Wáng Rì* [王弼], and *Gāo Qì* [高翿] versions, has an additional 「哉」 at the end.
*Wǔ Nèi Yì Xióng* [武内义雄] states: The *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌] and *Suì* [遂] versions read 「天下之然」 for 「其然」.
*Luó Zhènyù* [罗振玉] notes: The *Jǐnglóng* [景龙], *Yù Zhù* [御注], and *Jǐngfú* [景福] versions all lack the 「哉」 character.

*According to my examination*: The *Fù* [傅] and *Fàn* [范] versions read 「奚」 instead of 「何」, and have an additional 「天下」 after 「知」. The *Pánxī* [磻溪], *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], and *Gù Huān* [顾欢] versions agree. *Yán* [严], *Péng* [彭], *Gāo Qì* [高翿], and *Wú Miǎnxué* [吴勉学] versions omit 「以此」. *Yú Yì* [俞樾] notes: The following sentences from *"Governing the state with rectitude"* to *"according to this"* should belong to the previous chapter. For example, in **Chapter 21**, it states: *"How do I know the multitude’s nature to be such? According to this."* In **Chapter 54**, it states: *"How do I know the world’s nature to be such? According to this."* Both use 「以此」 as the concluding phrase for the chapter. The subsequent passage *"The world abounds with taboos, yet the people grow ever poorer"* should be treated as a separate chapter, but it is mistakenly combined here.

*The world abounds with taboos, yet the people grow ever poorer;*
*The more the people possess useful tools, the more the state becomes corrupt.*

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: All versions read 「民」 instead of 「人」.
*Wú Yún* [吴云] states: The *Fù* [傅] version reads 「夫天下多忌讳」, but other versions lack the 「夫」 character.

*According to my examination*: The *Péng* [彭], *Fàn* [范], and *Gāo* [高] versions follow the *Fù* [傅] version, including 「夫」. 「弥」 is written as 「○」 in the *Fù* [傅] version. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* [说文解字] defines 「○」 as *"long duration"* [久长也], from *cháng* (长), with the phonetic *ěr* (尔); modern usage renders it as 「弥」. The *Xiǎo Ěryǎ* [小尔雅] glosses: *"弥 means prolonged."* Additionally, the *Yílì Shìguān Lǐ* [仪礼士冠礼] states: *"Threefold reverence is added to the crown"* [三加弥尊], with the note: *"Like ‘benefit’."* The *Jìn Yǔ* [晋语] says: *"The praise grew ever more flourishing"* [赞言弥兴], and the *Dōngjīng Fù* [东京赋] states: *"The ages passed, yet its brilliance grew"* [历世弥光]—both use 「弥」 as a substitute for 「益」.

The phrase *"The world abounds with taboos"* is annotated by *Wáng Rì* [王弼] as: *"What is feared is ‘忌’, what is concealed is ‘讳’."* It means that as taboos and prohibitions multiply in the world, the people become ever poorer.

In the phrase *"The more the people possess useful tools"*, the *Héshàng Gōng* [河上公] and *Wáng Rì* [王弼] versions both have an additional 「民」 character at the start, while the *Fù* [傅] version lacks it. This 「民」 character is rendered as 「人」 in the *Suìzhōu* [遂州], *Pánxī* [磻溪], *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], and *Péng* [彭] versions. The *Fàn* [范] version includes an additional 「而」 after 「器」, with *Fàn* [范] noting: *"The ancient versions had the ‘而’ character."*

*The more the people possess clever skills and strange devices, the more corruption arises;*
*The more the people possess wisdom, the more deviant practices flourish.*

*According to my examination*: The *Fù* [傅] and *Fàn* [范] versions read 「民」 instead of 「人」, while the *Héshàng Gōng* [河上公] and *Wáng Rì* [王弼] versions read 「人」. The *Fù* [傅] and *Fàn* [范] versions read *"The people possess wisdom, and deviant practices flourish"* [民多知慧而邪事滋起], with *Fàn* [范] noting: *"Wáng Rì* [王弼] follows the ancient version, with ‘邪’ repeated."*

「谦之案」: The *Wáng Bì* [王弼] annotation reads: *"When the people possess much wisdom, clever deceits arise; when clever deceits arise, deviant practices flourish."* This is the *Wáng* [王] version’s original reading of 「邪事」, consistent with the *Fù* [傅], *Fàn* [范], and *Lù Xīshēng* [陆希声] versions.

「伎巧」: The *Sīmǎ* [司马] version renders 「伎」 as 「利」, while the *Yùzhù* [御注], *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], and other versions read 「技」.

*Note*: 「邪」 and 「奇」 are interchangeable characters.

In the *Jiǎzǐ* [贾子] text on Daoist teachings: *"Square and straight is called ‘正’ (right/orthodox); deviation from this is ‘邪’ (deviant)."*
In the *Lǐjì* [礼记] *Jìyì* [祭义]: *"Though there are strange and deviant things, they are not addressed"* [虽有奇邪而不治者], where 「奇邪」 may also be written as 「奇邪」.
In the *Zhōulǐ* [周礼] *Bǐzhǎng* [比长]: *"If there are crimes or strange deviant acts, they are brought to justice"* [有罪奇邪则相及], with the annotation: *"This means evil."* In the *Gōngzhèng* [宫正] text: *"With those who are strange and deviant"* [与其奇邪之民], the annotation states: *"Strange and deviant, meaning cunning and deceitful."* In the *Nèizǎi* [内宰]: *"Prohibit their strange and deviant acts"* [禁其奇邪], the annotation explains: *"Like today’s flatterers."* In the *Sījìu* [司救]: *"Deviant and evil transgressions"* [邪恶过失], the annotation clarifies: *"Deviant and evil refers to disrespecting elders, speaking without restraint, though not yet punishable by law."*

This passage thus reads: *"The more the people possess clever skills, the more deviant practices arise."*

In this chapter, 「伎巧」 is a corruption of 「知巧」. *Wáng* [王]’s annotation lists 「知慧」 and 「巧伪」 together, while *Zhāng Shèng* [章圣]’s *Běncóng* [本成] commentary states: *"‘知巧’ means cunning intelligence."* The *Suìzhōu* [遂州] version also reads 「知巧」, confirming that the original text should be: *"The people possess much wisdom, and deviant practices flourish"* [人多知巧，邪事滋起]. Ancient texts referred to deviant acts as 「奇物」, so 「奇物」 elucidates the meaning of 「邪事」.

However, the *Fù* [傅] and *Fàn* [范] versions, though following ancient usage, are more logically sound, and thus should be preferred.

*"When lawful things flourish, thieves and robbers abound."*

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: The *Yùzhù* [御注], *Wáng Bì* [王弼], and *Gāo Yè* [高翿] versions read 「法令」 (laws and commands), while the *Héshàng Gōng* [河上公] version reads 「法物」 (lawful things). *Héshàng* [河上] states: *"‘法物’ means desirable things."* *Qiánzhī* [谦之] notes: The *Jǐngfú* [景福], *Nǎijuàn* [柰卷], and *Héshàng* [河上] versions all read 「法物」, while the *Lóuzhèng* [楼正], *Fù* [傅], *Fàn* [范], and *Wáng Xǐzhī* [王羲之] versions read 「法令」. The reading 「法令」 is correct; 「法物」 lacks meaning. *Zhāng Shèng* [章圣]’s *Běncóng* [本成] commentary states: *"‘法物’ is the same as ‘法令’"*, confirming that 「法令」 is the superior reading. The *Huánnán* [淮南] *Dàoyìng* [道应训], *Wénzǐ* [文子] *Dàoyuán* [道原篇], *Shǐjì* [史记] *Cūlì Lièchuán* [酷吏列传], and *Hànshū* [后汉书] *Dōngyí Chuán* [东夷传] all quote 「法令」. The character 「物」 likely resulted from confusion with the preceding 「奇物」.

*"When lawful commands flourish"* [法令滋彰] aligns with *"the heavy taxes on the people"* [上食税之多] and *"‘佳兵者不祥之器’ (Fine weapons are ominous tools)"* [夫佳兵者不祥之器], all of which represent *Lǎozǐ* [老子]’s political philosophy—not merely opposition to luxurious objects.

Thus, the Sage says:
*"I take no action, yet the people transform themselves;
I love tranquility, yet the people become upright;
I take no action, yet the people grow wealthy;
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity."*

*Yán Kějūn* [严可均] notes: In most versions, 「人」 is written as 「而民」 in *"I take no action, yet the people transform themselves"* [我无为，而民自化], and similarly in the following three sentences. This version reads 「民」 (people) instead of 「人」 (person), as the inscriptions all avoid the Tang dynasty taboo on 「人」.

The *Laozi* states:

*"The Dao ever acts without doing, yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings can preserve it,
All things will transform spontaneously.

I act without doing, yet the people transform spontaneously.
Thus, the Sage desires without desiring,
Does not prize hard-to-obtain treasures;
Teaches without teaching,
Returns to the errors of the common folk;
Supports the spontaneous nature of all things, yet does not dare act."*

The *Jǐnglóng* stele version contains **83 characters**; the *Dūnhuáng* version, **85**; the *Héshàng* and *Wáng* versions, **88**; the *Fù* version, **92**; and the *Fàn* version, **94**.

chunks.original_text: 祸，福之所倚； 福，祸之所伏。 熟知其极？ 严可均曰：御注作「祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏」。 河上、王弼有两「兮」字，无两「之」字。 谦之案：景福、磻溪、楼正、彭、范、高、王羲之、赵孟俯并与河上、王弼同。 遂州本二「兮」字并无。 又「熟知其极」，诸本「熟」皆作「孰」。 此言众人不知祸福之所归也。 文子微明篇云：「利与害同门，祸与福同邻，非神圣莫之能分，故曰：『祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏，孰知其极？ 』」吕氏春秋制乐篇云：「故祸者福之所倚，福者祸之所伏。 圣人所独见，众人焉知其极？ 」荀子正名篇云：「权不正则祸托于欲，而人以为福； 福托于恶，而人以为祸。 此亦人所以惑乱祸福也。 」又大略篇云：「庆者在堂，吊者在闾。 祸与福邻，莫知其门。 」此与贾谊鵩赋所云：「夫祸之与福，何异纠缠； 命不可测，孰知其极？ 」语皆出于老子。 又韩非解老篇云：「故曰『祸兮福之所倚』，以成其功也。 ……故曰『福兮祸之所伏』……故谕人曰：『孰知其极？ 』」刘师培以所引于「祸兮」句下有「以成其功也」五字，疑此节多佚文。 又御览四百五十九说苑引老子曰：「得其所利，必虑其所害； 乐其所乐，必顾其败。 人为善者，天报以福； 人为不善者，天报以祸。 故曰：『祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 』」易顺鼎以所引疑系此处逸文。 实则老子语盖只此三句，韩非「以成其功也」与说苑引「故曰」以上诸语，皆为后人发挥老子之旨，非其本文，不可不辨。 其无正。 政复为奇，善复为妖。

Misfortune is the leaning of fortune;
Fortune is the hidden foundation of misfortune.
Who truly knows their limits?

Yán Kějūn notes: The *Yù Zhù* (御注) reads:
*"Misfortune, oh, where fortune leans;
Fortune, oh, where misfortune lurks."*

The *Hé Shàng* (河上) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) versions both include two *"xī"* (兮) but omit the two *"zhī"* (之).

*Qián Zhī* (谦之) observes: The *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Péng* (彭), *Fàn* (范), *Gāo* (高), *Wáng Xīzhī* (王羲之), and *Zhào Mèngfǔ* (赵孟俯) versions all align with *Hé Shàng* and *Wáng Bì*. The *Suìzhōu* (遂州) version omits both *"xī"* (兮) characters.

Again, all versions render *"shú"* (熟) as *"shú"* (孰).
This speaks of how the common people do not know where misfortune and fortune ultimately rest.

The *Wénzǐ* (文子) in the *"Wēimíng"* (微明) chapter states:
*"Benefit and harm share the same gate;
Misfortune and fortune dwell as neighbors.
Only the divine and sagely can distinguish them,
Thus it is said:
'Misfortune, oh, where fortune leans;
Fortune, oh, where misfortune lurks.
Who truly knows their limits?'*

The *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (吕氏春秋) in the *"Zhì Yuè"* (制乐) chapter states:
*"Thus, misfortune is the leaning of fortune,
And fortune is the hidden foundation of misfortune.
This is what only the sage perceives;
How could the common people know their limits?"*

The *Xúnzǐ* (荀子) in the *"Zhèngmíng"* (正名) chapter states:
*"When authority is unjust, misfortune is entrusted to desire,
Yet people take it as fortune;
When fortune is entrusted to evil,
Yet people take it as misfortune.
This is how people are confused about misfortune and fortune."*

Again, in the *"Dàluè"* (大略) chapter:
*"Celebrations in the hall,
Condolences at the gates.
Misfortune and fortune dwell as neighbors,
None know their threshold."*

This aligns with *Jiǎ Yì* (贾谊) in the *"Fú Fú"* (鵩赋):
*"What difference is there between misfortune and fortune?
They are intertwined like knots;
Fate is unfathomable—
Who truly knows their limits?"*

All these passages derive from *Lǎozǐ* (老子).

Again, *Hán Fēi* (韩非) in the *"Jiě Lǎo"* (解老) chapter states:
*"Thus it is said, 'Misfortune, oh, where fortune leans'—
To complete its purpose.
...
Thus it is said, 'Fortune, oh, where misfortune lurks'...
Thus he instructs people: 'Who truly knows their limits?'*

*Liú Shīpéi* (刘师培) suspects that the passage after *"Confusion, oh, where fortune leans"* includes lost text due to the five characters *"to complete its purpose"* (以成其功也).

Again, the *Yù Lǎn* (御览) in Volume 459, quoting from *Shuōyuàn* (说苑), attributes to *Lǎozǐ*:
*"When one gains what benefits, one must consider what harms;
When one rejoices in what brings joy, one must foresee its ruin.
When people do good, Heaven rewards them with fortune;
When people do evil, Heaven punishes them with misfortune.
Thus it is said:
'Misfortune, oh, where fortune leans;
Fortune, oh, where misfortune lurks.'"*

*Yì Shùndǐng* (易顺鼎) suspects this may be the lost text from this passage.

In truth, *Lǎozǐ*'s original words consist only of these three sentences. *Hán Fēi*'s *"to complete its purpose"* and the *Shuōyuàn*'s *"Thus it is said"* and the preceding lines are all later elaborations on *Lǎozǐ*'s intent, not his original text. This must be clearly distinguished.

*Its governance is rigid yet perverse;
Its virtue is strange yet bizarre.*

chunks.translated_text:
Yán Kějūn remarks:
*"Its lack of **zhèng** [正],"* the Imperial Commentary glosses as *"zhèngxié [正邪; right and wrong]."*
*"Its governance becomes **qí** [奇],"* the transmitted texts uniformly read *"zhèngfù [正复; restored]."*
Luó Zhènyù notes:
*"Yāo [妖],"* the Imperial Commentary reads *"yāo [妖],"* while the Dunhuang and Jingfu manuscripts read *"yàn [訞]."*
Bì Yàn states: Fù Yì’s text reads *"[○],"* Héshànggōng’s *"yàn [訞],"* and Wáng Bì’s *"yāo [妖]."*
Upon examination, *"yāo [妖]"* should be *"[○],"* as there was no ancient character *"yàn [訞]."*
Qiánzhī’s note: Fù and Fàn’s texts both read *"[○],"* Zhào’s *"[○],"* the Imperial Commentary *"[○],"* Xíng Xuán, Gù, and Péng’s *"yāo [妖],"* while Suìzhōu’s manuscript reads *"yàn [訞]."*
*"Yāo [妖]," [○],* and *"yàn [訞]"* are all interchangeable.
The *Yùpiàn* under the *shì* [示] radical states:
*"Yāo [妖],* pronounced *yújiāo [于骄],* is when Heaven’s order is disrupted as calamity, and Earth’s nature is perverted as *yāo [妖].* The *Shuōwén* writes *[○]*.*
Again, under the *yán* [言] radical:
*"Yàn [訞],* meaning calamity."*
Lí’s edition of the *Yùpiàn* states:
*"[○],* pronounced *yújiāo [于骄],* is also the character for *yāo [妖]*" in the character dictionaries.
Xià Jǔn’s *Gǔwén Sìshēngyùn* cites the ancient *Lǎozǐ* as *"yàn [訞]" ([○]).*

Furthermore, regarding *"Its lack of **zhèng** [正],"* **"zhèng"** is read as **"dìng" [定],** meaning its lack of constancy.
The *Yùpiàn* states:
*"Zhèng [正],* meaning *cháng [long]* and *dìng [fixed]."*
Here, it is taken as *"fixed,"* stating that as fortune and misfortune alternate, who can know their ultimate end?
Its lack of constancy means their resolution is unknown.
Fù’s text appends *"xié [邪]"* after *"zhèng [正],"* conflating it with *"xié [邪; wrong]."*
Furthermore, Xí Dòng altered *"zhèng [正]"* to *"zhǐ [止],"* arguing that the rise and fall of the world, like an unbroken circle, has no end.
Though the argument holds, it is suspect to emend characters arbitrarily—just as Xí altered *"bùxíng ér zhī [不行而知]"* to *"bùzhī ér xíng [不知而行]"* in Chapter 47, changes unsupported by evidence and rejected by textual scholars.

*"The confusion of people is indeed long-standing."*
Yán Kějūn remarks:
*"The confusion of people,"* the Imperial Commentary, Héshànggōng, and Gāo Yì all read *"the confusion of the people [mínzhī [民之]]."*
Qiánzhī’s note: Pánxī, Lóuzhèng, Gù, Fàn, and Zhào’s texts all align with the Imperial Commentary.
Péng’s text reads *"the confusion of the people [mínzhī de yě [民之迷也]]."*
*"Its duration is indeed long,"* the Imperial Commentary reads *"Its saying is indeed long [qíyuē gùjiǔ [其曰固久]],"* while Zhào’s text reads *"Its saying is indeed already long [qíyuē gùyǐjiǔ yǐ [其曰固已久矣]],"* with *"yuē [曰]"* being erroneous.
Wáng Xīzhī, Fàn, and Péng’s texts read *"Its duration is indeed already long [qí rì gùyǐjiǔ yǐ [其日固已久矣]],"* matching *Yì Míngyí Wáng*’s annotation and *Fǎyán* Vol. 10’s Lǐ Guǐ’s annotation.
Yán and Fù’s texts also append *"yǐ [矣]"* after *"jiǔ [久],"* aligning with Fàn’s version.
*"The confusion of people,"* it is confirmed by *Hán Fēi’s* *"Xiě Lǎozǐ"*:
*"Those who stray from their desired path and act in vain are said to be confused."*
Thus it is.

Therefore, the Sage is square yet does not cut,
sharp yet does not harm.

chunks.original_text: 严可均曰：「廉而不害」，御注作「不秽」，王弼作「不刿」。 罗振玉曰：释文、河上作「害」，景龙、景福、敦煌三本均同。 谦之案：柰卷、室町、顾欢作「害」，遂州、磻溪、楼正及武内敦本作「秽」，韩非解老引此，干道本作「秽」，道藏本作「刿」。 顾广圻云：「藏本乃以他本老子改耳，韩非自作秽。 」王先慎云：「刿、秽声近而误，非韩子本作秽也。 」今案作「刿」是也。 傅、范本均作「刿」，淮南道应训引亦作「刿」。 景龙本作「害」，乃涉上文「割」字而误。 「刿」，庄子释文：「居卫反，司马云：伤也。 」伤、害义同。 「廉而不刿」与上文「方而不割」对文。 方，方正也； 廉，谓廉隅也：皆棱角伤刺之意。 杨倞注荀子不苟篇「廉而不刿」曰：「廉，棱也。 说文：『刿，利伤也。 』但有廉隅，不至于刃伤也。 」此于义为长。 「廉而不刿」一语，荀子中数见。 法行云：「廉而不刿，行也。 」荣辱云：「廉而不见贵者，刿也。 」又礼聘义「廉而不刿」，疏：「廉，棱也。 」皆与此同。 直而不肆，光而不曜。 严可均曰：「不曜」，御注作「耀」，王弼作「嬥」。 毕沅曰：王弼「耀」作「嬥」。 「耀」俗作「耀」。 罗振玉曰：景龙、景福、敦煌三本作「曜」。 王先慎曰：说文无「耀」字，河上公作「曜」，傅本作「耀」。 李约本作「方而不割，直而不肆，光而不耀，廉而不刿」，与各本全异，误倒。 谦之案：「曜」、「耀」、「耀」古通用。 今柰卷、室町作「曜」，磻溪、楼正、严、顾、彭、赵、傅、范作「耀」。 释名：「曜，耀也，光明照耀也。 」玉篇：「曜，余照切，照也。 亦作耀。 」庄子刻意篇：「光矣而不耀。 」汉书司马迁传曰：「光耀天下，复反无名。 」释文又作「嬥」。 玉篇女部：「『嬥』，徒了、徒聊二切。 嬥嬥，往来也。 」义亦可通。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读：闷、醇韵（文部，闷，平声），察，缺韵（祭部，察音掣），祸、倚韵（歌部，倚音○），福、伏、极韵（之部，福，方逼反，伏，扶逼反）。 奚侗：伏、极、止为韵，奇、妖为韵。 歌、宵相转，如易大过过、弱为韵之例。 割、刿、肆、耀为韵，以耀韵割、刿、肆，音转，如○音弥，○从○得声，读若。 高本汉：闷（一作「闵」）、淳（一作「偆」）为韵，妖、久为韵，刿（一作「秽」，一作「害」。 ）、割为韵。 姚文田、奚侗、陈柱、高本汉皆未知此章之首尾韵。 顾炎武唐韵正卷八四纸：「倚」，古音于我反。 老子「祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏」，祸与倚为韵，福与伏为韵。 江有诰古韵总论曰：古人有一句首尾为韵者，如老子「祸兮福所倚」二句是也。 江永古韵标准入声第三部：「缺」，苦穴切。 老子：「其政察察，其民缺缺。 」

Yán Kějūn remarks: *"Lian while not hài [廉而不害],"* the Imperial Commentary renders as *"not huì [不秽],"* while Wáng Bì reads *"not jué [不刿]."*

Luó Zhènyù states: The *Shìwén* and Héshàng versions read *"hài [害],"* while the *Jǐnglóng*, *Jǐngfú*, and three *Dūnhuáng* manuscripts all agree. Qiān Zhī annotates: The *Nǎijuàn*, *Shìmáchéng*, and Gù Huān versions read *"hài [害],"* while the *Suìzhōu*, *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, and *Wǔnèi Dūn* versions read *"huì [秽]."* *Hán Fēi’s Xiě Lǎozǐ* cites this passage, and the *Dàodào* version reads *"huì [秽]."* The *Dàozàng* version reads *"jué [刿]."*

Gù Guǎngqì notes: *"The Daozang version merely substitutes another text’s reading of Laozi; Hán Fēi himself used ‘huì [秽].’"* Wáng Xiāoshèn argues: *"Jué [刿] and huì [秽] are phonetically close and thus mistaken; it was not Hán Fēi’s original text that read ‘huì.’"* Now, the reading *"jué [刿]"* is correct.

Fù and Fàn’s versions both read *"jué [刿],"* and the *Huáinán Dàoyīng Xuányìn* also cites *"jué [刿]."* The *Jǐnglóng* version reads *"hài [害],"* likely due to contamination from the preceding *"gē [割]."*

*"Jué [刿],"* as explained in the *Zhuāngzǐ Shìwén*: *"Resides in the Wèi dialect; Sīmǎ [司马] says: ‘To injure.’"* Injury and harm share the same meaning.

*"Lian while not jué [廉而不刿]"* parallels the preceding *"fāng while not gē [方而不割]."*
Fāng means *square and upright*; lián refers to *sharp edges*. Both convey the sense of *sharp angles that injure*.

Yáng Shì’s annotation on *Xúnzǐ Bùgǒu Piān* explains *"lián while not jué [廉而不刿]"* as:
*"Lián means ‘sharp edges.’ The *Shuōwén* states: ‘Jué means *sharp injury*.’ Yet though there are sharp edges, they do not reach the point of cutting injury."*

This interpretation is most fitting. The phrase *"lián while not jué [廉而不刿]"* appears multiple times in *Xúnzǐ*:
*Fǎxíng* states: *"Lián while not jué [廉而不刿], that is *conduct* [行也]."*
*Róngrǔ* states: *"Lián yet unseen as noble—*that* is *jué* [刿也]."*
The *Lǐ Pìnyì* also cites *"lián while not jué [廉而不刿],"* with the *Cóng* explaining: *"Lián means ‘sharp edges.’"* All align with this meaning.

**Zhí while not sì [直而不肆], guāng while not yào [光而不曜].**

Yán Kějūn remarks: *"Not yào [不曜],"* the Imperial Commentary renders as *"yào [耀],"* while Wáng Bì reads *"yāo [嬥]."*

Bì Yàn notes: Wáng Bì’s *"yào [耀]"* is written as *"yāo [嬥]."* *"Yào [耀]"* is a vulgarized form.
Luó Zhènyù states: The *Jǐnglóng*, *Jǐngfú*, and three *Dūnhuáng* manuscripts all read *"yào [曜]."*

Wáng Xiāoshèn argues: The *Shuōwén* has no *"yào [耀]"* character; Héshànggōng’s version reads *"yào [曜],"* while Fù’s reads *"yào [耀]."* Lǐ Yuē’s version reads: *"Fāng while not gē [方而不割], zhí while not sì [直而不肆], guāng while not yào [光而不耀], lián while not jué [廉而不刿],"* differing entirely from other versions, with the order mistakenly inverted.

Qiān Zhī annotates: *"Yào [曜], yào [耀],"* and *"yāo [嬥]"* were interchangeably used in antiquity. Now, the *Nǎijuàn* and *Shìmáchéng* versions read *"yào [曜],"* while the *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, Yán, Gù, Péng, Zhào, Fù, and Fàn versions read *"yào [耀]."*

The *Shìmíng* states: *"Yào [曜], yào [耀]—both mean ‘illuminating brilliance.’"*
The *Yùbiǎn* states: *"Yào [曜], yúzhào [余照]—to shine. Also written as yào [耀]."*
The *Zhuāngzǐ Kèyì Piān* states: *"Guāng yet not yào [光矣而不耀]."*
The *Hànshū Sīmǎ Qiānchuán* states: *"Guāngyào tiānxià [光耀天下],"* returning to namelessness.

The *Shìwén* also renders it as *"yāo [嬥]."*
The *Yùbiǎn* under the female radical states: *"Yāo [嬥], túliǎo [徒了], túliáo [徒聊]—to move back and forth."* The meaning is also acceptable.

---
**Phonetic Notes:**
This chapter, according to Jiāng Shì’s *yùndú* [韵读]:
- *Mèn* [闷], *chún* [醇] (Wén department, *mèn* [闷], level tone),
- *chá* [察] (Zhài department, *chá* [察] rhymes with *chè* [掣]),
- *huò* [祸], *yǐ* [倚] (Gē department, *yǐ* [倚] rhymes with *○*),
- *fú* [福], *fú* [伏], *jí* [极] (Zhī department, *fú* [福] as *fāngbì* [方逼], *fú* [伏] as *fūbì* [扶逼]).

Xí Dòng states: *Fú* [伏], *jí* [极], *zhǐ* [止] form a rhyme; *qí* [奇], *yāo* [妖] form a rhyme. *Gē* [歌] and *xiāo* [宵] transform as in the *Yì Dàguò* example where *guò* [过] and *ruò* [弱] rhyme.

*Gē* [割], *jué* [刿], *sì* [肆], *yào* [耀] form a rhyme, with *yào* [耀] rhyming with *gē* [割], *jué* [刿], and *sì* [肆] through phonetic transformation, akin to *○* [○] rhyming with *mí* [弥], *○* [○] derived from *○* [○] with the *shēng* [声] of *○* [○], read as *yǐ* [豷].

Gāo Běnhàn states: *Mèn* [闷] (also written *mǐn* [闵]), *chún* [醇] (also written *zhuǎn* [偆]) form a rhyme; *yāo* [妖], *jiǔ* [久] form a rhyme; *jué* [刿] (also written *huì* [秽], *hài* [害]), *gē* [割] form a rhyme.

Yáo Wéntián, Xí Dòng, Chén Zhù, and Gāo Běnhàn all failed to recognize the rhyme scheme of this chapter’s beginning and end.

Gù Yánwú’s *Tángyùn Zhèng* (卷八四纸) states: *"Yǐ [倚],"* in ancient pronunciation as *yúwǒ* [于我反]. In *Lǎozǐ*: *"Huò xī fú suǒ yǐ [祸兮福所倚], fú xī huò suǒ fú [福兮祸所伏],"* with *huò* [祸] rhyming with *yǐ* [倚], and *fú* [福] rhyming with *fú* [伏].

Jiāng Yǒuguǐ’s *Gǔyīn Zǒnglùn* states: The ancients had instances where the first and last words of a sentence rhymed, as in *Lǎozǐ*’s *"Huò xī fú suǒ yǐ [祸兮福所倚]"* two lines.

Jiāng Yǒng’s *Gǔyīn Biāozhǔn Rùshēng* (第三部) states: *"Quē [缺],"* as *kǔxiá* [苦穴切]. In *Lǎozǐ*: *"Qí zhèng cháchá [其政察察], qí mín quēquē [其民缺缺]."*

chunks.original_text: 右景龙碑本六十八字，敦煌本六十四字，河上、王本七十字，傅本七十三字，范本七十一字。 河上题「顺化第五十八」，王本题「五十八章」，范本题「其政闵闵章第五十八」。 五十九章 治人事天，莫若啬。 魏稼孙曰：「治人事天」，御注「人」作「民」。 武内义雄曰：敦、遂二本「啬」作「式」，「式」为「啬」之借字。 谦之案：邢玄「人」亦作「民」。 「若」字，严、顾、彭、赵作「如」，释文出「如」字。 「啬」，敦、遂二本及赵志坚本作「式」，作「式」是也。 顾本成疏：「『天』，自然也。 『式』，法也。 『莫若』，犹无过也。 言上合天道，下化黎元者，无过用无为之法也。 」是成所见本作「式」。 又本荣注：「莫过以道用为法式。 」是李荣所见本亦作「式」。 「式」即法式，犹今语规律。 说文：「式，法也。 」周书谥法：「式，法也。 」广雅释诂一：「式，○也。 」诗下武「下士之式」，传：「法也。 」经文二十二章「圣人抱一为天下式」，易顺鼎曰：「『式』即『栻』字。 广雅：『栻，梮也。 』梮有天地，所以推阴阳，占吉凶，以枫子枣心木为之。 汉书王莽传『天文郎案栻于前』即此，字亦作『式』。 周礼『太史抱天时，与太师同车』，郑司农云：『大出师，则太史主抱式以知天时，主吉凶。 』……老子『式』字即此义。 』谦之案：易说甚辨。 老子为周柱下史，曾子问引郑玄云：「老聃，周之太史。 」则其曾抱式以知天时，或亦分内之事。 惟此云「治人事天莫若式」，乃就法式而言。 二十八章「为天下式」，六十五章「两者亦楷式，常知楷式」，「式」字均作法式解，而法式之观念则固从观察天文之现象来也。 夫唯啬，是谓早服。 谦之案：「啬」，敦、遂二本作「式」。 「谓」，敦、遂本及严、彭、顾、傅、范作「以」。 「早」，严本作「蚤」。 「以」「蚤」二字并与韩非子解老同。 「早服」，敦、遂二本「服」作「伏」，彭、赵作「复」，傅、范同此石。 范曰：「王弼、孙登及世本作『早服』。 」 俞樾曰：按困学纪闻卷十引此文，两「服」字皆作「复」，且引司马公、朱文公说并云「不远而复」。 又曰：「王弼本作『早服』，而注云『早服常也』，亦当为『复』。 」今案韩非子解老篇曰：「夫能啬也，是从于道而服于理者也。 众人离于患，陷于祸，犹未知退而不服从道理。 圣人虽未见祸患之形，虚无服从于道理，以称蚤服。 」然则古本自是「服」字。 王说非。 又案韩非解老引「夫谓啬，啬是以蚤服」，卢文弨曰：「张本『谓』作『惟』，『以』作『谓』，凌本『服』作『复』，上下句皆同。 王弼本作『复』，释文：『复音服。 』」顾广圻曰：「傅本及今德经『谓』皆作『惟』。 今德经『以』作『谓』，傅本与此合。 」 王先慎曰：凌本作「复」者，用老子误本改也。
chunks.translated_text:
「The *Jǐnglóng* stele version has sixty-eight characters, the *Dūnhuáng* version sixty-four, the *Héshàng* and *Wáng* versions seventy, the *Fù* version seventy-three, and the *Fàn* version seventy-one. The *Héshàng* version is titled *"Chapter Fifty-Eight on Harmonizing Transformation,"* the *Wáng* version *"Chapter Fifty-Eight,"* and the *Fàn* version *"Chapter Fifty-Eight on the Dao/Way of Governing the People with Benevolence."*

**Chapter Fifty-Nine:** To govern people and serve the Dao/Way of Heaven, nothing surpasses *jǐn* [啬].

Wei Jiǎsūn remarks: *"To govern people and serve the Dao/Way of Heaven"*—the *Yùzhù* [御注] glosses *"people"* as *"min"* [民].

Takesuchi Yoshio states: The *Dūnhuáng* and *Suì* versions render *"jǐn"* [啬] as *"shì"* [式], where *"shì"* [式] is a borrowed character for *"jǐn"* [啬].

Qiánzhī notes: Xíng Xuán also glosses *"people"* [人] as *"min"* [民]. The character *"ruò"* [若] is rendered as *"rú"* [如] by Yán, Gù, Péng, and Zhào, with the *Shìwén* [释文] also listing *"rú"* [如]. *"Jǐn"* [啬] appears as *"shì"* [式] in the *Dūnhuáng*, *Suì* versions, and the *Zhàozhìběn* [赵志坚本], which is correct.

Gù’s annotated version states: *"Heaven"* [天] refers to the natural order. *"Shì"* [式] means *dharma/law*. *"Mòruò"* [莫若] is akin to *"wúguò"* [无过], meaning "nothing surpasses." It states that to harmonize with the Heavenly Dao/Way above and transform the people below, nothing surpasses applying the *dharma/law* of non-action.

This is what Gù saw in his version as *"shì"* [式].

Honor’s annotation further says: *"Nothing surpasses using the Dao/Way as the standard dharma/law."* Thus, even Li Róng’s version he saw had *"shì"* [式]. *"Shì"* [式] is the standard dharma/law, akin to today’s term *guīlǜ* [规律].

The *Shuōwén Jiězì* [说文解字] states: *"Shì"* [式], *dharma/law*.

The *Zhōushū Xìfǎ* [周书谥法] states: *"Shì"* [式], *dharma/law*.

The *Guǎngyǎ Shìgǔ* [广雅释诂] states: *"Shì"* [式], *○* [也] (i.e., "so").

The *Shīxià Wǔ* [诗下武] annotation on *"xiàshì zhīshì"* [下士之式] says: *"Dharma/law."*

In the *Yìjīng* [易经], Chapter Twenty-Two: *"The sage holds unity as the standard dharma/law for all under Heaven,"* Yì Shùndīng remarks: *"Shì"* [式] is the same as *"zhuó"* [栻]. The *Guǎngyǎ* [广雅] states: *"Zhuó"* [栻], *fú* [梮] (a wooden divination device). This *fú* [梮] embodies Heaven and Earth, used to observe yin and yang, and divine auspiciousness and inauspiciousness, made from *fēngzǐ* [枫子] and *zǎoxīn* [枣心] wood. The *Hànshū Wángmào* [汉书王莽传] states: *"The Heavenly Astronomy Officer examines the *fú* [栻] before him,"* which is the same, though the character is also written as *"shì"* [式]. The *Zhōulǐ* [周礼] states: *"The Grand Historian holds the *shì* [式] to know the Heavenly times, riding with the Grand Musician,"* and Zhèng Sīnóng [郑司农] explains: *"When the Grand Historian goes out, he holds the *shì* [式] to know the Heavenly times and divines auspiciousness and inauspiciousness."* Thus, *"shì"* [式] holds this meaning.

Qiánzhī notes: The *Yì* [易] explanation is quite distinct. Since Lǎozǐ was the Grand Historian beneath the *Zhōu* [周] pillar, Zēngzǐ’s question, as cited by Zhèng Xuán, states: *"Lǎodān"* [老聃], the Grand Historian of *Zhōu* [周]. Thus, it is likely that he once held the *shì* [式] to know the Heavenly times, which may also have been part of his duties.

Here, it states: *"To govern people and serve the Dao/Way of Heaven, nothing surpasses the standard dharma/law."* In Chapter Twenty-Eight: *"To be the standard dharma/law for all under Heaven,"* and Chapter Sixty-Five: *"These two are also the standard dharma/law; always know the standard dharma/law,"* the term *"shì"* [式] is consistently interpreted as the standard dharma/law, and this concept originates from observing celestial phenomena.

Only through *jǐn* [啬] is it called *zǎo fú* [早服].
Qiánzhī notes: The *Dūnhuáng* and *Suì* versions render *"jǐn"* [啬] as *"shì"* [式]. *"Wèi"* [谓] is written as *"wéi"* [惟] in the *Dūnhuáng* and *Suì* versions, as well as in Yán, Péng, Gù, Fù, and Fàn versions. *"Zǎo"* [早] is rendered as *"zǎo"* [蚤] in Yán’s version. Both *"wéi"* [谓] and *"zǎo"* [蚤] align with Hàn Fēi’s interpretation of Lǎozǐ.

*"Zǎo fú"* [早服] is written as *"zǎo fú"* [早伏] in the *Dūnhuáng* and *Suì* versions, *"zǎo fù"* [早复] in Péng and Zhào’s versions, and matches this stone version in Fù and Fàn’s versions.

Fàn states: *"Wáng Bì"* [王弼], *"Sūn Dēng"* [孙登], and the world’s versions all read *"zǎo fú"* [早服].

Yú Yì states: According to *Kùn Xué Jìwén* [困学纪闻], Volume Ten, the two *"fú"* [服] characters are rendered as *"fù"* [复], and he also cites *Sīmǎ Gōng* [司马公] and *Zhū Wén Gōng* [朱文公]’s interpretations, stating *"bùyuǎn ér fù"* [不远而复].

He further states: *"Wáng Bì’s version is ‘zǎo fú’ [早服], but his annotation reads ‘early fú [服] is constant,’ which should also be ‘fù’ [复]."*

Now, according to Hàn Fēi’s *Jiě Lǎo* [解老] essay, it states: *"He who is able to practice *jǐn* [啬] is one who follows the Dao/Way and submits to *lǐ* [理]. The common people are distant from calamity and immersed in misfortune, yet they still do not know to retreat and submit to the Dao/Way and principles. The sage, though he has not yet seen the form of calamity and misfortune, emptily submits to the Dao/Way and principles, thus calling it *zǎo fú* [早服]."*

Hence, the ancient versions were indeed *"fú"* [服]. Wáng’s annotation is incorrect.

Additionally, according to Hàn Fēi’s *Jiě Lǎo* [解老], *"Only through *jǐn* [啬] is it called *zǎo fú* [早服],"* Lú Wénpián states: *"Zhāng’s version renders ‘wèi’ [谓] as ‘wéi’* [惟], and ‘yǐ’* [以] as ‘wèi’* [谓]. Líng’s version renders ‘fú’* [服] as ‘fù’* [复], with both characters identical in the upper and lower sentences. Wáng Bì’s version reads ‘fù’* [复], and the *Shìwén* [释文] states: ‘*fù* [复] pronounced as *fú* [服].’"*

Gù Guǎngchì states: *"Fù’s version and the current *Déjīng* [德经] render ‘wèi’* [谓] as ‘wéi’* [惟]. The current *Déjīng* [德经] renders ‘yǐ’* [以] as ‘wèi’* [谓], aligning with Fù’s version."*

Wáng Xiānshèn states: *"Líng’s version renders it as ‘fù’* [复], likely due to a miscorrection of the ancient Lǎozǐ text."*
chunks.overlap_context:
cient pronunciation as *yúwǒ* [于我反]. In *Lǎozǐ*: *"Huò xī fú suǒ yǐ [祸兮福所倚], fú xī huò suǒ fú [福兮祸所伏],"* with *huò* [祸] rhyming with *yǐ* [倚], and *fú* [福] rhyming with *fú* [伏].

Jiāng Yǒuguǐ’s *Gǔyīn Zǒnglùn* states: The ancients had instances where the first and last words of a sentence rhymed, as in *Lǎozǐ*’s *"Huò xī fú suǒ yǐ [祸兮福所倚]"* two lines.

Jiāng Yǒng’s *Gǔyīn Biāozhǔn Rùshēng* (第三部) states: *"Quē [缺],"* as *kǔxiá* [苦穴切]. In *Lǎozǐ*: *"Qí zhèng cháchá [其政察察], qí mín quēquē [其民缺缺]."*

chunks.original_text: 上文「从于道而服于理」，又言「不服从道理」，又云「虚无服从道理」，即解老子「蚤服」之义。 「服从」之服当作「服」，更无疑义。 知韩子所见德经本作「服」，不作「复」也。 困学纪闻十引老子「服」作「复」，并引司马光、朱文公说云「不远而复」，谓「王弼本作『早服』，而注云『早服常也』，亦当作『复』」。 据此则王弼本仍作「服」，与本书合。 宋儒据释文为训，未检韩子也。 凌氏依误本老子改本书，非是。 谦之案：作「蚤服」是也。 范本引王本作「早复」，道藏宋张太守汇刻四家注引王注「早复常也」，「早复谓之重积德者也」，是范、张皆见王本亦有作「复」者。 司马光谓：「不远而复，不离于德，可以修身。 」 朱熹谓：「能啬则不远而复，重积德者，先己有所积，后养以啬，是又加积之也。 」盖皆以儒家之说解老，擅改「早服」为「早复」，王先慎所云「误本」者，殆即此耳。 高亨曰：窃疑「服」下当有「道」字，「早服道」与「重积德」句法相同，辞意相因，「服道」即二十三章所云「从事于道」之意也。 韩非子引已无「道」字，盖其捝也久矣。 本章啬、道、德、克、极、母、久、道为韵。 下句「早服」下亦捝「道」字。 谦之案：高说是也。 河上公注「早服」句：「早，先也； 服，得也。 夫独爱民财，爱精气，则能先得天道也。 」又注「重积德」句云：「先得天道，是谓重积德于己也。 」知河上公二句皆有「道」字，今脱。 早服谓之重积德。 王先慎曰：河上「谓之」作「是谓」，与韩非解老文合。 谦之案：严遵本无此句。 「早服」二字可从韩子注，「服」训服从道理。 虞书「五刑有服」，传：「从也。 」尔雅释诂：「服，事也。 」礼记孔子闲居「君子之服之也」，注：「犹习也。 」服有从习之义，谓从于道而习于理也。 又「德」借为「」。 广雅释诂三：「德，得也。 」左襄廿四传：「德，国家之基也。 」家语入官：「德，政之始也。 」吕览精通：「德也者，万民之宰也。 」皆借「德」为「」。 言早服从道理，则积得深厚也。 重积德则无不克，无不克则莫知其极。 严可均曰：「则无不克」，御注、王弼作「不克」，下句亦然。 谦之案：景福、严遵、河上、室町、柰卷均作「克」，敦煌、傅、范作「克」，遂州误作「充」。 严无下「无不克则」二句。 案「克」「克」可通用。 字林、尔雅释言均训「克」为能。 河上注：「克，胜也。 」案字林「克，能也」，是音义同。 又「莫知其极」，尔雅释诂：「极，至也。 」吕览制乐「乐人焉知其极」，注：「犹终也。 」礼记大学「君子无所不用其极」，注：「尽也。 」离骚「观民之计极」，注：「穷也。 」此「莫知其极」，即莫知其所穷尽之义。 莫知其极，可以有国。 有国之母，可以长久。 谦之案：敦、遂二本「莫」作「能」，严本「有」作「为」，遂州本「长久」作「久长」。 范本「极」下有「则」字。 范曰：「『则』字，河上公、韩非同古本。 」 是谓深根、固蒂、长生、久视之道。 严可均曰：「固蒂」，御注作「故蒂」，王弼作「固柢」。 毕沅曰：「柢」，河上公作「蒂」，韩非作「深其根，固其柢」，无「是谓」二字。
chunks.translated_text:
The passage above states: *"From the Way and in accordance with Principle"* [従于道而服于理], yet it also says *"not to serve the Way and Principle"*, and further declares *"the empty and void serve the Way and Principle"*—thus elucidating the meaning of Laozi’s *"early service"* [蚤服]. The *"service"* [服] in *"service to"* [服从] should indeed be *"service"* [服], leaving no room for doubt. Thus, it is clear that the *Déjīng* [德经] cited by Hàn Fēi reads *"service"* [服], not *"repeat"* [复].

The *Kùnxué Jìwén* [困学纪闻] cites Laozi with *"service"* [服] as *"repeat"* [复], also quoting Sīmǎ Guāng and Zhú Wén Gōng as saying: *"Not distant and yet returning"* [不远而复], claiming *"Wáng Bì’s text reads ‘early service’ [早服], but his annotation states ‘early service is the constant’ [早服常也], which should also be ‘returning’ [复]."* By this account, Wáng Bì’s text still reads *"service"* [服], aligning with this book. The Sòng scholars, relying on the *Shìwén* [释文] for interpretation, failed to verify Hàn Fēi’s text. Líng Shì [凌氏] altered the text based on a corrupted Laozi manuscript, which is incorrect.

**My examination:** *"Early service"* [蚤服] is correct. Fàn Běn [范本] cites Wáng’s text as *"early returning"* [早复], and the *Dàozàng* [道藏] Sòng Zhāng Tàishǒu’s [张太守] compilation of the Four Commentaries quotes Wáng’s annotation: *"Early returning is the constant"* [早复常也], *"Early returning is called the repeated accumulation of virtue"* [早复谓之重积德者也]. Thus, both Fàn [范] and Zhāng [张] saw that Wáng’s text also had instances of *"returning"* [复]. Sīmǎ Guāng said: *"Not distant and yet returning, not departing from virtue—this can be used to cultivate oneself."* Zhú Xī said: *"If one practices *jǐn* [啬], then one is not distant and yet returns, repeatedly accumulating virtue—first, one has already accumulated [virtue], and later, one nurtures it through *jǐn* [啬], which is yet another layer of accumulation."* All of these interpretations apply Confucian reasoning to Laozi, arbitrarily changing *"early service"* [早服] to *"early returning"* [早复]. The *"corrupted manuscript"* [误本] that Wáng Xiānshèn refers to is likely this very alteration.

Gāo Hēng conjectures: *"Perhaps there should be a ‘Way’ [道] after ‘service’ [服], making ‘early service to the Way’ [早服道], which parallels the structure of ‘repeatedly accumulating virtue’ [重积德]. The phrase ‘service to the Way’ [服道] aligns with Chapter 23’s ‘engaging in the Way’ [从事于道]."* The Hàn Fēi’s citation lacks the ‘Way’ [道], indicating that the omission occurred long ago. This chapter’s rhyme scheme follows: *jǐn* [啬], *dào* [道], *dé* [德], *kè* [克], *jí* [极], *mǔ* [母], *jiǔ* [久], *dào* [道]. The ‘Way’ [道] is also omitted after *"early service"* [早服] in the following sentence.

**My examination:** Gāo’s conjecture is correct. Héshàng Gōng’s [河上公] annotation on *"early service"* [早服] states: *"Early means ‘prior’; service means ‘obtaining.’ He who loves the people’s wealth and cherishes *qì* [精气] can first obtain the Way of Heaven."* His annotation on *"repeatedly accumulating virtue"* [重积德] reads: *"To first obtain the Way of Heaven is called repeatedly accumulating virtue in oneself."* Thus, both of Héshàng Gōng’s sentences originally included ‘Way’ [道], now omitted.

*"Early service"* is called *"repeatedly accumulating virtue."* Wáng Xiānshèn notes: *"Héshàng Gōng’s ‘is called’ [谓之] is written as ‘this is called’ [是谓], matching the text in Hàn Fēi’s *Jiě Lǎo* [解老]."* **My examination:** Yán Zhēn’s [严遵] text lacks this sentence. The characters *"early service"* [蚤服] can be verified through Hàn Fēi’s annotation, where *"service"* [服] is interpreted as *"serving the Way and Principle"* [服从道理].

The *Yú Shū* [虞书] states: *"The Five Punishments have their service"* [五刑有服], with the transmission explaining: *"Follow"* [从也]. The *Éryá* [尔雅] *Shìgǔ* [释诂] defines *"service"* [服] as *"to attend to"* [事也]. The *Lǐjì* [礼记] *Kǒngzǐ Xiánjū* [孔子闲居] states: *"The gentleman’s service to it"* [君子之服之也], with the annotation: *"Like habituation"* [犹习也]. *"Service"* [服] carries the meaning of *"following and habituating"* [从习], meaning *"following the Way and habituating to Principle"* [从于道而习于理].

Additionally, *"virtue"* [德] is borrowed for *"obtain"* [得]. The *Guǎngyǎ* [广雅] *Shìgǔ* [释诂] states: *"Virtue, to obtain"* [德，得也]. The *Zuǒzhuàn* [左传] (24th year of Duke Xiāng) says: *"Virtue is the foundation of the state"* [德，国家之基也]. The *Jiālǐng* [家语] *Rùguān* [入官] states: *"Virtue is the beginning of governance"* [德，政之始也]. The *Lǚshì* [吕览] *Jīngtōng* [精通] declares: *"Virtue is the sovereign of the people"* [德也者，万民之宰也]. All these instances borrow *"virtue"* [德] for *"obtain"* [得].

It states: *"Early service to the Way and Principle"* [早服从道理] *"accumulates deep and profound virtue"* [则积得深厚也]. Repeatedly accumulating virtue means nothing is unconquered; nothing unconquered means its limits are unknown. Yán Kějūn [严可均] notes: *"Then nothing is unconquered"* [则无不克], with the Imperial annotation and Wáng Bì reading *"unconquered"* [不克], as in the following sentence.

**My examination:** The *Jǐngfú* [景福], Yán Zhēn [严遵], Héshàng Gōng [河上公], Shìmáng [室町], and Nǎijuǎn [柰卷] texts all read *"conquer"* [克], while the *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌], Fù [傅], and Fàn [范] texts also read *"conquer"* [克], whereas the *Suìzhōu* [遂州] text mistakenly reads *"fill"* [充]. Yán Zhēn’s text lacks the following *"nothing is unconquered, its limits are unknown"* [无不克则莫知其极] sentences.

**Examination:** *"Conquer"* [克] and *"able"* [能] can be used interchangeably. Both the *Zìlín* [字林] and *Éryá* [尔雅] *Shìyán* [释言] define *"conquer"* [克] as *"able"* [能]. Héshàng Gōng’s annotation states: *"Conquer, to overcome"* [克，胜也]. The *Zìlín* [字林] defines *"conquer"* [克] as *"able"* [能], indicating that the sound and meaning are identical.

The *Éryá* [尔雅] *Shìgǔ* [释诂] defines *"extreme"* [极] as *"to reach"* [至也]. The *Lǚshì* [吕览] *Zhìyuè* [制乐] states: *"How can the musician know its extreme?"* [乐人焉知其极], with the annotation: *"Like ‘end’* [犹终也]. The *Lǐjì* [礼记] *Dàxué* [大学] says: *"The gentleman exhausts all things"* [君子无所不用其极], with the annotation: *"Exhaust"* [尽也]. The *Lí Sāo* [离骚] states: *"Observing the people’s calculations reach their extreme"* [观民之计极], with the annotation: *"Exhaustion"* [穷也]. Here, *"its limits are unknown"* [莫知其极] means *"its exhaustion is unknown"* [莫知其所穷尽之义].

If its limits are unknown, one can establish a state. The foundation of establishing a state can endure long. **My examination:** The *Dūn* [敦] and *Suì* [遂] texts read *"able"* [能] instead of *"unknown"* [莫], Yán’s [严] text reads *"can be"* [为] instead of *"establish"* [有], and the *Suìzhōu* [遂州] text reads *"long enduring"* [久长] instead of *"long"* [长久]. Fàn’s [范] text includes *"then"* [则] after *"extreme"* [极]. Fàn states: *"The ‘then’ [则] character appears in Héshàng Gōng’s and Hàn Fēi’s ancient texts."*

This is called the *Dao* of deep roots, firm foundations, longevity, and enduring vision. Yán Kějūn [严可均] notes: *"Firm foundations"* [固蒂] is annotated in the Imperial text as *"old foundations"* [故蒂] and by Wáng Bì as *"firm roots"* [固柢]. Bì Yàn [毕沅] states: *"Roots"* [柢], Héshàng Gōng reads as *"foundations"* [蒂], and Hàn Fēi reads: *"Deepen its roots, firm its foundations"* [深其根，固其柢], without the *"this is called"* [是谓] characters.

chunks.original_text: 苏灵芝书亦为「蒂」。 罗振玉曰：「柢」，释文：「亦作『蒂』。 」敦煌、御注、景福三本作「蒂」。 谦之案：遂州、邢玄、磻溪、楼正，室町、柰卷、严、顾、赵、高并作「蒂」，意林、御览六百五十九引同。 傅、范本作「柢」。 范曰：「『柢』字，傅奕引古本云：『柢，木根也。 』又引郭璞云：『柢谓根柢也。 』河上公作『蒂』，非经义。 夫『柢』亦是根。 」谦之案：字林云：「蒂、柢音同。 」夏竦古文四声韵卷四引古老子亦作「蒂」，范说非。 又「长生久视」为当时通行语。 荀子荣辱篇云：「是庶人之所以取暖衣饱食、长生久视以免于刑戮也。 」吕氏春秋重己篇云「世之人主贵人，无贤不肖莫不欲长生久视」，高诱注：「视，活也。 」老子义同此。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读：啬、啬、复、德、德、克、克、极、国、母、久、道韵（之、幽通韵，啬，史入声，服协房逼反，克，枯力反，国，古逼反，道协徒以反）。 谦之案：啬、复、德、克、极、国、母，之部，久、道，之、幽并收，此之、幽通韵。 姚文田分啬、啬、服、德、克、极、极、国为一韵（一戠入声），母、久为一韵（四之上声）。 邓廷桢同。 邓曰：「久字上与母韵，与诗韵同； 下与道韵，与易象传韵同。 」奚侗分啬、啬、复、复、德、德、克、克、极、极、国为一韵，复读若服。 母、久、道为一韵。 盖皆未审「之」「幽」诸字其初皆全相协也。 又「啬」，敦、遂本作「式」，「式」亦之部入声。 陈第屈宋古音义曰：「服音逼，诗、易及秦、汉古辞无有不读逼者。 」顾炎武唐韵正入声一屋：「服」，古音蒲北反，引老子此章。 旁证：楚辞离骚：「瞻前而顾后兮，相观民之计极，夫孰非善而可服！ 」 右景龙碑本六十四字，敦煌本六十三字，河上、王、傅本六十四字，范本六十五字。

For ‘roots’ [柢] is also the root."* Qiánzhī notes: The *Zìlín* [字林] states: *"‘Foundation’ [蒂] and ‘roots’ [柢] share the same pronunciation."* Xià Jùn’s [夏竦] *Gǔwén Sìshēngyùn* [古文四声韵] (vol. 4) cites an ancient *Lǎozǐ* [老子] text also reading *"foundation"* [蒂], but Fàn disagrees.

Furthermore, *"long life, enduring vision"* [長生久視] was a common phrase of the time. In the *Róngrù Piān* [荣辱篇] of *Xúnzǐ* [荀子], it states: *"This is how the common people secure warm clothing, full stomachs, long life, and enduring vision to avoid punishment."* In the *Chóngjǐ Piān* [重己篇] of *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* [吕氏春秋], it states: *"The rulers and nobles of the world, whether virtuous or otherwise, all desire long life and enduring vision."* Gāo Yù [高诱] annotates: *"Vision"* [視] *"means ‘to live’* [活也]."* The meaning here aligns with *Lǎozǐ*.

---
**Phonology:**
Jiāng Shì’s [江氏] rhyme reading for this chapter:
*"Shè, shè, fù, dé, dé, kè, kè, jí, guó, mǔ, jiǔ, dào"* [啬、啬、复、德、德、克、克、极、国、母、久、道] (with *zhī* [之] and *yōu* [幽] in the same rhyme group, *shè* [啬] as *shǐ* [史] in the entering tone, *fù* [复] rhyming with *fángbī* [房逼], *kè* [克] as *kūlì* [枯力], *guó* [国] as *gǔbī* [古逼], *dào* [道] rhyming with *túyǐ* [徒以]).

Qiánzhī notes: *"Shè, fù, dé, kè, jí, guó, mǔ"* [啬、复、德、克、极、国、母] belong to the *zhī* [之] rhyme, while *jiǔ* [久] and *dào* [道] share the *zhī/yōu* [之、幽] final.

Yáo Wéntián [姚文田] groups *"shè, shè, fù, dé, kè, jí, jí, guó"* [啬、啬、服、德、克、极、极、国] as one rhyme (first *yàn* [戠] entering tone), and *"mǔ, jiǔ"* [母、久] as another (fourth *zhī* [之] rising tone). Dèng Tíngzhēn [邓廷桢] agrees. Dèng states: *"The character ‘jiǔ’* [久] *rhymes with ‘mǔ’* [母] *above, matching the *Shī* [诗] rhyme, and with ‘dào’* [道] *below, matching the *Yì Xiàngzhuàn* [易象传] rhyme."*

Xí Dòng [奚侗] groups *"shè, shè, fù, fù, dé, dé, kè, kè, jí, jí, guó"* [啬、啬、复、复、德、德、克、克、极、极、国] as one rhyme, with *fù* [复] pronounced as *fú* [服]. *"Mǔ, jiǔ, dào"* [母、久、道] form another. All failed to recognize that *"zhī"* [之] *and "yōu"* [幽] *originally fully rhymed.*

Additionally, *"shè"* [啬] is read as *"shì"* [式] in the *Dūnhuáng* [敦煌] and *Suìzhōu* [遂州] texts, with *"shì"* [式] also belonging to the *zhī* [之] entering tone. Chén Dì’s [陈第] *Qū Sòng Gǔyīnyì* [屈宋古音义] states: *"‘Fú’* [服] *is pronounced ‘bī’* [逼]; in *Shī* [诗], *Yì* [易], and ancient Qin-Han texts, there is none that does not read it as ‘bī’* [逼]."* Gù Yánwù’s [顾炎武] *Tángyùn Zhèng* [唐韵正] (under *Yīwū* [一屋] entering tone) cites *"fú"* [服] with the ancient pronunciation *pǔběifǎn* [蒲北反], referencing this passage of *Lǎozǐ*.

In the *Lí Sāo* [离骚] of *Chǔcí* [楚辞]:

chunks.original_text: 河上本题「守道第五十九」，王本题「五十九章」，范本题「治人事天章第五十九」。 六十章 治大国若亨小鲜。 罗振玉曰：「亨」，王本作「烹」，与景福本同。 释文出「烹」，注：「不当加『火』。 」则王本原作「亨」，今改正。 景龙本、敦煌本均作「亨」，御注本、敦煌庚本作「享」。 又「鲜」，敦煌辛本作「腥」，注：「河上作『鲜』。 」 谦之案：遂州本作「厚小腥」，「厚」字误。 范本作「亨小鳞」，注：「小鳞，小鱼也。 治大国譬如亨小鳞。 夫亨小鳞者不可扰，扰之则鱼烂。 治大国者当无为，为之则民伤。 盖天下神器不可为也。 」鳞、神为韵，于义可通。 又「腥」字，成玄英疏：「腥，鱼也； 河上公作鲜字，亦鱼也。 」唯腥有臭义。 楚辞涉江「腥臊并御」，注：「臭也。 」又「肉则麋腥」，疏：「生肉也，又为○。 」通俗文：「鱼臭曰腥。 」作「腥」义短，仍从碑本作「亨小鲜」为是。 孔广森诗声类三「亨」字下曰：「案『亨』、『烹』、『享』三字，后人所别，古人皆祇作『亨』字，而随义用之，其读似亦祇有亨音。 」河上注：「烹小鱼不去肠，不去鳞，不敢挠，恐其糜也。 」淮南齐俗训引老子曰：「治大国若烹小鲜，为宽裕者，曰勿数挠，为刻削者，曰致其咸酸而已。 」皆合老子古义。 洪颐烜曰：按韩非子解老篇：「事大众而数摇之，则少成功； 藏大器而数徙之，则多败伤； 烹小鲜而数挠之，则贼其泽； 治大国而数变法，则民苦之。 是以有道之君贵静，不重变法。 故曰：『治大国者苦烹小鲜。 』」「若」是「苦」字之讹。 易顺鼎曰：旧注皆以烹小鲜为烹小鱼，然义颇难解。 道德指归论治大国篇云：「是以明王之治大国也，若亨小澌。 」亨，通也。 「澌」者，说文云：「水索也。 」水索谓水将尽。 亨小澌，谓通极小之水，若行所无事矣。 「亨」读如字，后人误读为烹，「澌」与「鲜」古字亦通。 诗「有兔斯首」，笺：「斯，白也。 」今俗语「斯白」之字作「鲜」，是其证。 小鲜即小澌也。 谦之案：洪、易皆颇迂曲其说，惟以此知「若」字疑本或作「苦」，「鲜」字疑严本作「澌」，是也。 又韩非解老引「国」下有「者」字，顾广圻曰：「傅本及今德经皆无『者』字。 」王先慎曰：「治要有『者』字。 」今案三国志卷四十四陈寿评，「治大国者若烹小鲜」，后汉书循吏传注引「理大国者若亨小鲜也」，蜀志姜维传评引「治大国者犹烹小鲜」，皆有「者」字。 北堂书钞二十七引「治国若烹小鲜」，后汉书逸民传引「理大国若烹小鲜」，类聚五十二、淮南齐俗训、文子道德篇引「治大国若烹小鲜」，均无「者」字，同此石。 又马其昶曰：「诗毛传云：『烹鱼烦则碎，治民烦则散，知烹鱼则知治民。 』义出老子。 」
chunks.translated_text:
The **Heshang Gong** [河上] text titles this as *"Shǒudào Dì Wǔshíjiǔ"* [守道第五十九], the **Wang** [王] text as *"Wǔshíjiǔpiān"* [五十九章], and the **Fan** [范] text as *"Zhìrén Shìtiān Zhāng Dì Wǔshíjiǔ"* [治人事天章第五十九].

**Chapter Sixty:**
*"Zhì dàguó ruò hēng xiǎoxiān"* [治大国若亨小鲜].

Luo Zhènyù [罗振玉] notes: *"Hēng"* [亨], the **Wang** [王] text reads *"pēng"* [烹], matching the **Jǐngfú** [景福] text. The *Shìwén* [释文] cites *"pēng"* [烹], with the annotation: *"Should not add ‘fire’."* Thus, the **Wang** [王] text originally read *"hēng"* [亨], now corrected. The **Jǐnglóng** [景龙] and **Dūnhuáng** [敦煌] texts both read *"hēng"* [亨], while the **Yùzhù** [御注] and **Dūnhuáng** [敦煌] **Gǔběn** [古本] read *"xiǎng"* [享].

Again, *"xiān"* [鲜], the **Dūnhuáng** [敦煌] **Xīn** [辛] text reads *"xīng"* [腥], annotated: *"Heshang Gong* [河上] *reads ‘xiān’* [鲜]."*
Qián Zhī [谦之] notes: The **Suìzhōu** [遂州] text reads *"hòu xiǎoxīng"* [厚小腥], with *"hòu"* [厚] being erroneous. The **Fan** [范] text reads *"hēng xiǎolín"* [亨小鳞], annotated: *"Xiǎolín* [小鳞] *refers to small fish. To govern a great state is like cooking small fish. He who cooks small fish must not disturb it, for disturbance causes the fish to spoil. Thus, governing a great state requires non-action; action harms the people. For the Dao/Way is the sacred instrument of Heaven, and cannot be manipulated."*

*"Lín"* [鳞] and *"shén"* [神] rhyme, and the meaning aligns.

Further, the character *"xīng"* [腥]: Chéng Xuányīng’s [成玄英] *cóng* [疏] states: *"Xīng* [腥] *refers to fish; Heshang Gong* [河上] *wrote ‘xiān’* [鲜], also meaning fish."* Only *"xīng"* [腥] carries the connotation of stench. In the *Chǔcí* [楚辞] *Shèjiāng* [涉江], it reads: *"Xīngchòu bìng yù"* [腥臊并御], annotated: *"Stench."* Additionally, *"ròu zé míxīng"* [肉则麋腥], with the *cóng* [疏] explaining: *"Raw meat; also written as* [○]." *Tōngsúwén* [通俗文] states: *"The stench of fish is called* xīng*."* Though *"xīng"* [腥] is more concise in meaning, the **Jǐnglóng** [景龙] stele’s reading of *"hēng xiǎoxiān"* [亨小鲜] is preferred.

Kǒng Guāngsēn’s [孔广森] *Shīshēng Lèi* [诗声类] under *"hēng"* [亨] states: *"‘Hēng’* [亨], *‘pēng’* [烹], and *‘xiǎng’* [享] are later distinctions; in antiquity, only *‘hēng’* [亨] was used, with its pronunciation likely only as *hēng*."*

Heshang Gong’s [河上] annotation reads: *"Cooking small fish without removing its entrails, scales, or stirring it—lest it spoil."*

The *Huáinán Qísú Xuǎn* [淮南齐俗训] cites *Lǎozǐ* [老子] as saying: *"To govern a great state is like cooking small fish: the lenient approach avoids frequent disturbance; the harsh approach seeks only to season it properly."* Both align with the ancient meaning of *Lǎozǐ* [老子].

Hóng Yíxiǎn [洪颐烜] states: Referencing *Hánfēizǐ* [韩非子]’s *Jiě Lǎo* [解老], *"Disturbing the masses frequently yields little success; storing precious instruments while moving them often leads to ruin; stirring small fish excessively ruins their flavor; frequently altering laws in a great state brings suffering to the people. Thus, the enlightened ruler values stillness and avoids frequent legal changes. Hence it is said: ‘To govern a great state is like cooking small fish.’"* The character *"ruò"* [若] is likely a corruption of *"kǔ"* [苦].

Yì Shùndìng [易顺鼎] notes: Previous annotations interpret *"pēng xiǎoxiān"* [烹小鲜] as *"cooking small fish,"* yet the meaning remains obscure. The *Dàodé Zhǐguī Lùn* [道德指归论] on *"Zhì Dàguó"* [治大国] states: *"Thus, the enlightened ruler governs a great state as if draining small streams."* *"Hēng"* [亨] means *"to drain"* or *"to complete."* *"Xiān"* [鲜] in *Shuōwén Jiězì* [说文解字] is defined as *"water’s last remnants."* *"Hēng xiǎoxiān"* [亨小鲜] thus means *"draining the last of small water,"* akin to acting without effort. *"Hēng"* [亨] is read as written, while later scholars misread it as *"pēng"* [烹]; *"xiān"* [鲜] and *"xiān"* [鲜] (as in *"shuǐ xiān"* [水鲜]) were interchangeable in antiquity. In the *Shī* [诗], *"Yǒu tù sīshǒu"* [有兔斯首], the *Jiān* [笺] explains: *"Sī* [斯] *means ‘white.’"* Today, *"sībái"* [斯白] is written as *"xiān"* [鲜], confirming this. *"Xiǎoxiān"* [小鲜] is thus *"xiǎoxiān"* [小鲜].

Qián Zhī [谦之] concludes: Both Hóng [洪] and Yì [易] offer convoluted interpretations, yet it is clear that *"ruò"* [若] likely originally read *"kǔ"* [苦], and *"xiān"* [鲜] may have been *"xiān"* [澌] in the strict text.

Further, *Hánfēizǐ* [韩非子]’s *Jiě Lǎo* [解老] includes *"guó"* [国] followed by *"zhě"* [者], with *Gù Guǎngqì* [顾广圻] noting: *"The Fèi* [傅] *text and today’s* Dàodéjīng [道德经] *lack the ‘zhě’* [者] *character."* Wáng Xiānshèn [王先慎] states: *"The* Zhìyào [治要] *includes ‘zhě’* [者]."*
Upon review, the *Sān Guó Zhì* [三国志] (Vol. 44, Chén Shǔ’s [陈寿] evaluation) reads: *"Zhì dàguó zhě ruò pēng xiǎoxiān"* [治大国者若烹小鲜], the *Hòuhànshū* [后汉书] *Xúnlì Zhuan* [循吏传] annotation cites: *"Lǐ dàguó ruò hēng xiǎoxiān yě"* [理大国若亨小鲜也], and the *Shǔ Zhì* [蜀志] *Jiāng Wéi Zhuan* [姜维传] evaluation quotes: *"Zhì dàguó zhě yóu pēng xiǎoxiān"* [治大国者犹烹小鲜], all including *"zhě"* [者]. Conversely, the *Běitáng Shūchuán* [北堂书钞] (Vol. 27) cites *"Zhì guó ruò pēng xiǎoxiān"* [治国若烹小鲜], the *Hòuhànshū* [后汉书] *Yìmín Zhuan* [逸民传] quotes *"Lǐ dàguó ruò pēng xiǎoxiān"* [理大国若烹小鲜], the *Lèijú* [类聚] (Vol. 52), *Huáinán Qísú Xuǎn* [淮南齐俗训], and *Wénzǐ Dàodé Piān* [文子道德篇] all read *"Zhì dàguó ruò pēng xiǎoxiān"* [治大国若烹小鲜], lacking *"zhě"* [者], matching this stele.

Additionally, *Mǎ Qíchǎng* [马其昶] notes: *"The* Máo Zhuan [毛传] *of the* Shī [诗] *states: ‘Stirring fish too much breaks it; governing the people too much scatters them. Knowing how to cook fish is to know how to govern the people.’ This meaning originates from* Lǎozǐ [老子]."*

chunks.original_text: 以道邪天下，其鬼不神。 顾广圻曰：傅本「下」下有「者」字，与各本全异。 王先慎曰：治要引老子亦有「者」字，盖唐人所见老子本有「者」字。 罗振玉曰：敦煌庚本、景福本均有「者」字。 谦之案：柰卷、室町、彭、赵亦有「者」字。 又「邪」，傅本作「莅」。 毕沅曰：「古『莅』字作『○』，亦通用位，俗作『莅』及『邪』，并非也。 」陆德明曰：「邪，古无此字，说文作『○』。 」易顺鼎曰：「按淮南俶真训注云：『以道○天下，其鬼不神。 』『○』乃『莅』之正字，知高诱所见老子本作『○』，作『莅』与『莅』者非也。 此与说文引老子书『盅』字，同为古文之可宝贵者。 」 谦之案：「○」与「莅」义同。 「邪」，玉篇：「力致切。 诗云：『方叔邪止。 』莅，临也。 」「○」，玉篇：「力季、力至二切，临也，从也。 」此云「以道○天下」者，即以道临天下也，与「邪」无二义。 「邪」字见诗经，说文未收，非古无此字。 谦之案：论衡知实篇曰：「故夫贤圣者，道德智能之号； 神者，渺茫恍惚无形之实。 」以「贤圣」与「神」对举，其谊出于老子。 又王道曰：「传曰：『国将兴，听于人； 国将亡，听于神。 』圣人以道临天下，则公道昭明，人心纯正，善恶祸福，悉听于人； 而妖诞之说，阴邪之气，举不得存乎其间，故其鬼不神。 」 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人。 严可均曰：御注作「伤民」，下二句亦然。 谦之案：庆阳、磻溪、楼正、彭、范、高并作「民」，傅本作「人」。 韩非子引「非其鬼不神，其神不伤人也」， 下有「也」字。 惟干道本「伤」下脱「人」字。 顾广圻曰：傅本及今德经皆无上下两「也」字。 藏本「伤」下有「人」字，是也，傅本及今德经皆有。 非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 夫两不相伤，故得交归。 严可均曰：「交归」，各本作「交归焉」。 魏稼孙曰：御注「故德交归焉」，严举「焉」字，失校「德」字。 罗振玉曰：景龙本、敦煌辛本均作「故得交归」。 谦之案：庆阳、磻溪、楼正、彭、范、高「人」并作「民」。 韩非子解老「故」作「则」，与范本同。 又引「圣人亦不伤民」，顾广圻曰：「傅本及今德经『民』皆作『人』。 案韩子自作『民』。 」王先慎曰：「上当有『非其神不伤』句，惟赵孟俯本无，疑刊本书者从误本老子删之也。 河上公、王弼、傅本并有。 」又案「亦」字，诸本同，惟敦煌辛本作「之」，并云：「诸本皆作『亦』字，唯张系天（案强本成疏『天』作『师』）、陆先生本作『之』字。 然『之』『亦』二字形似，故写者误作『亦』字，今用『之』为是。 言非此鬼之不伤物，但为人以道莅天下，能制伏耶恶（顾本、强本成疏『耶』作『邪』），故鬼不复伤害于人，力在圣治（顾本成疏『治』作『理』），故云『圣人之不伤人』也。 」 陶鸿庆曰：「非其」二字，盖涉上文「非其鬼不神」而误衍也。 王注云：「道洽则神不伤人； 神不伤人，则不知神之为神。 道洽则圣人亦不伤人； 圣人不伤人，则不知圣之为圣也。 犹云不知神之为神，亦不知圣人之为圣也。 」是其所见经文本作「神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人」。 【音韵】此章江氏韵读无韵。 姚文田：鲜、神、神、人韵（七真平声）。
