chunks.original_text: 抑其高者，损有余也； 举其下者，补不足也。 天之道如是，故其用不穷也。 沈一贯曰：人之道则不然。 裒聚穷贱之财，以媚尊贵者之心； 下则棰楚流血，取之尽锱铢； 上则多藏而不尽用，或用之如泥沙：损不足以奉有余，与天道异矣。 熟能有余以奉天下？ 其唯有道者。 严可均曰：御注「以」字在「能」字下。 「其唯有道者」，各本无「其」字。 罗振玉曰：御注、景福、广明、敦煌庚本「能」下均有「以」字。 「有余以」，御注、景福二本均无「以」字。 谦之案：傅本作「孰能损有余而奉不足于天下者，其惟道者乎」！ 严、彭、范亦作「损」字，彭有「不足于」三字。 李道纯曰：「『孰能以有余奉天下』，其中加『不足』二字者非。 」譣义，有道者不以有余自奉，而以奉天下，于义已足，傅本「不足」二字赘。 是以圣人为而不恃，功成不处，斯不见贤。 严可均曰：「为而不恃」，御注无「而」字。 「功成不处」，河上、王弼「成」下有「而」字。 「斯不见贤」，各本作「其不欲见贤」，高翿句末有「邪」字。 罗振玉曰：「功成而不处」，敦煌庚、辛本「功成」作「成功」，景龙、御注、敦煌辛本均无「而」字。 「其不欲见贤」，敦煌庚本「贤」下有「也」字，辛本「则其欲退贤」。 武内义雄曰：敦本「见」作「示」。 谦之案：河上注：「不欲示人知己之贤。 」是河上「见」亦作「示」，顾欢同。 遂州本「见」作「贵」。 「斯不见贤」，「斯」即「厮」字。 「斯」「厮」古今字。 左传哀二年「人臣隶圉免」，杜注：「去役。 」释文：「厮字又作斯。 」新序杂事四、潜夫论叙录「役」均作「斯役」。 此云「斯不见贤」，案诗毛传：「贤，劳也。 」圣人能损有余，补不足，裒多以益寡，抑高而举下，岂劳烦役者耶？ 傅本「贤」下有「邪」字。 高亨曰：「『贤』下当有『邪』字。 本章全是韵文，无『邪』字则失韵，是其证。 」 【音韵】此章江氏韵读无韵。 邓廷桢：举、与韵，云：「『与』，一本作『补』，举、补亦韵也。 」奚侗：举、补韵。 陈柱同，增余、下韵。 高本汉同。 武内义雄：恃、处韵。 谦之案：诸说均不全。 此章与、举、与（补）、余、下、者、处、邪皆鱼部，实通篇一韵。 恃、处非韵，武内说误。 右景龙碑本七十五字，敦煌本七十四字，河上、王本七十九字，傅本七十七字，范本八十三字。 河上本题「天道第七十七」，王本题「七十七章」，范本题「天之道章第七十七」。 七十八章 天下柔弱莫过于水，而攻坚； 强莫之能先。 严可均曰：「天下柔弱莫过于水」，王弼作「天下莫柔弱于水」。 御注、王弼「强」下有「者」字，「先」作「胜」。 河上亦有「者」字，作「莫之能胜」，高翿作「莫之能爽」。 罗振玉曰：释文：「河上本作『天下柔弱莫过于水』。 」御注、敦煌辛本、景福诸本并同。 「攻」，敦煌辛本作「功」。 「强者」，景龙本、敦煌辛本均无「者」字，敦煌庚本此句上有「言水柔弱」四字。 又景龙本、敦煌辛本「胜」均作「先」。 武内义雄曰：敦、遂、景三本「胜」作「先」。 李道纯曰：「天下柔弱莫过于水」，或云「莫柔弱于水」，非也。 谦之案：世德堂河上公本作「莫知能胜」，「知」字误。

「But if it is too high, it is reduced—this is to diminish what is in excess; if it is too low, it is raised—this is to supplement what is deficient. The Dao/Way of Heaven is thus, and therefore its application is inexhaustible.

Yì Pèixiān (易佩绅) states: *«The Dao/Way of humanity is not so. He amasses wealth from the humble and lowly to curry favor with the noble and exalted; he oppresses them with rods and whips, drawing blood and taking every last coin. Yet to those above, he hoards riches without using them fully, or uses them as if they were mud and sand: diminishing what is deficient to serve what is in excess, thus differing from the Dao/Way of Heaven. Who can have excess to serve all under Heaven? Only the one who follows the Dao/Way.»*

**Yán** (严) **Kějūn** (可均) notes: In the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) edition, *«with»* (以) is placed under *«can»* (能). *«Only the one who follows the Dao/Way»* (其唯有道者) lacks the *«only»* (其) character in all other editions.

Yì Pèixiān (易佩绅) states: The *Suìzhōu* (遂州), *Jǐngfú* (景福), and *Guǎngmíng* (广明) editions all have *«with»* (以) under *«can»* (能). *«With excess»* (有余以), the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) and *Jǐngfú* (景福) editions lack the *«with»* (以) character.

**Yán** (严) **Qiānzhī** (谦之) case notes: The *Fù* (傅) edition renders *«Who can diminish what is in excess and serve what is deficient under Heaven? Only the one who follows the Dao/Way, is it not so?»* (孰能损有余而奉不足于天下者，其惟道者乎). The **Yán** (严) and **Péng** (彭) editions also use *«diminish»* (损), with **Péng** (彭) including the *«deficient under»* (不足于) phrase. **Lǐ Dàochún** (李道纯) states: *«Who can serve all under Heaven with excess»* (孰能以有余奉天下), adding *«deficient»* (不足) is incorrect.

**Yán** (严) **Kějūn** (可均) notes: *«Acts without claiming credit»* (为而不恃), the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) edition lacks the *«and»* (而) character. *«When virtue/power is achieved, does not claim it»* (功成不处), the *Héshàng* (河上) and **Wáng** (王) editions have *«when»* (而) under *«achieved»* (成). *«This is why the sage is not seen»* (斯不见贤), all editions render *«This is why he does not wish to be seen»* (其不欲见贤), with **Gāo Qì** (高亨) adding *«is it not so?»* (邪) at the sentence's end.

**Luò Zhènyù** (罗振玉) states: *«When virtue/power is achieved and does not claim it»* (功成而不处), the *Dūnhuáng Gēng* (敦煌庚) and *Dūnhuáng Xīn* (敦煌辛) editions render *«achieved»* (成) as *«success»* (成功). *«This is why he does not wish to be seen»* (斯不见贤), the *Dūnhuáng Gēng* (敦煌庚) edition adds *«also»* (也) under *«sage»* (贤), while the *Dūnhuáng Xīn* (敦煌辛) edition renders *«This is why he wishes to retire the sage»* (则其欲退贤). **Wǔnèi Yìxióng** (武内义雄) states: The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) edition renders *«seen»* (见) as *«show»* (示).

The *Suìzhōu* (遂州) edition renders *«seen»* (见) as *«noble»* (贵). *«This»* (斯) is the same as *«collaborate»* (厮), with *«斯»* and *«厮»* being interchangeable ancient and modern characters. The *Zhōulǜ* (左传) *Āi* (哀) year 2 annotation reads: *«Release from labor.»* The *Shìwén* (释文) states: *«厮 is also written as 斯.»* In *Xīnxù* (新序) *Záshì* (杂事) 4 and *Qiánfū Lùn* (潜夫论) *Xùlù* (叙录), *«labor»* (役) is uniformly written as *«collaborate labor»* (斯役). - *«垢»* (filth), *«主»* (sovereign) in the **Hóu rhyme category** (侯部, where *«主»* is pronounced as *«朱掫反»* [Zhǔ, rhyming with *chǔ*])

**Dàtián Qíngxuān** (大田晴轩) says:
『The scholars variously interpret 『彻』 as *permeating*, *illuminating*, or the *chè* in *chèfǎ* (彻法), but none grasp what this chapter truly addresses—thus their conflicting, erroneous theories, like a chaotic marketplace.
『彻』 means *to strip* or *exploit*. In the *Fēng* ode 『Píxiāo』 (豳风·鸱鸮), it says 『彻彼桑土，绸缪牖户』 (Strip the mulberry soil, mend the lattice doors), with the *Máo* commentary: 『彻, to strip.』
In the *Xiao Ya* 『Shíyuè zhījiāo』 (小雅·十月之交), it says 『彻我墙屋，田卒污莱』 (Strip my walls and houses, the fields lie fallow and overgrown).
Virtuous rulers prioritize harmonizing the people’s will, so they take nothing from them; unvirtuous rulers disregard the people’s sentiments, thus only digging and stripping become their concern.』

Another view suggests 『彻』 may instead be *kill*.

**Gāo Hēng** (高亨) states:

Here, 『司杀』 (overseeing killing) carries the same meaning.
Virtuous rulers are benevolent and generous, hence 『司契』 (overseeing *contracts*); unvirtuous rulers are tyrannical and excessive in punishment, hence 『司杀』 (overseeing *killing*).
Those who oversee *contracts* are the virtuous, whom Heaven blesses; those who oversee *killing* are the wicked, whom Heaven dooms.
Thus the following text states 『天道无亲，常与善人』 (The Dao of Heaven favors none, always aiding the virtuous)—a warning to rulers not to oversee *killing* but to oversee *contracts*.

**[Phonology]**
In Jiang’s (江氏) rhyme readings for this chapter:
- *Yuàn* (怨, *grudge*) and *yuàn* (怨, *grudge*) share the *Shàn* (善, *virtue*) rhyme (from the *Yuàn* 部, *Yuan* group),
- *Qì* (契, *contract*) and *chè* (彻, *pierce*, pronounced *jié* 如挈) share the *Jì* (祭, *sacrifice*) rhyme,
- *Qīn* (亲, *near*) and *rén* (人, *person*) share the *Zhēn* (真, *true*) rhyme.
**Yáo Wéndiàn** (姚文田) and **Xí Zòng** (奚侗) concur.
**Takuchi Kaoru** (武内义雄) and **Chén Zhù** (陈柱) read: *Yuàn* (怨), *yuàn* (怨), *shàn* (善), *rén* (人) in rhyme.
Thus, *Yuàn* (怨), *yuàn* (怨), *shàn* (善) belong to the *Yuan* (元) group, and *rén* (人, *person*) to the *Zhēn* (真, *true*) group—these two groups were phonetically associated in ancient rhyme.

**Gǔ Yīnmù** (顾炎武) in his *Tángyùn zhèng* (唐韵正, *Correct Rhymes of the Tang Dynasty*), Volume 17, Section 17, *Xué* (薛, *shoe*): *"Zhé"* (辙, *track*), when pronounced in the *Qù* (去, *departing*) tone, follows the *Zhí* (直, *straight*) rhyme category.
**Lǎozi** (老子) states: *"Those with virtue oversee *contracts*, those without oversee *killing*."* Some manuscripts read *"chè"* (彻).
**Lǐ Qìnyún** (李赓芸) in his *Bǐngzhú biān* (炳烛编, *Illuminated Candle Notes*), Volume 3, says of the *Lǎozi* (老子) chapter *"Rènqì"* (任契, *Entrusting Contracts*): *"Those with virtue oversee *contracts*, those without oversee *chè* (彻)."*
This aligns with the rhyme of *qì* (契) and *chè* (彻).

The *Guǎngyùn* (广韵) places *"qì"* (契) in the *Xiè* (屑, *shavings*) group (16) and *"chè"* (彻) in the *Xué* (薛, *shoe*) group (17), indicating that *Xiè* (屑) and *Xué* (薛) were phonetically interchangeable.

「Although there are boats and carriages, there is nothing to ride them upon; although there are armor and weapons, there is nothing to display them with. [The Way teaches] to make the people return to knotting cords for use.

**Qiānzhī** commentary: *"To make people value death"*—the *Heshang Gong* and *Wang Bi* versions read *"to make the people."* *Luó Zhènyù* notes: *"To make the people"*—the *Jinglong* and *Dunhuang* versions render *"people"* as *"the people."* *"Though they do not flee far"*—the *Dunhuang* version omits *"though,"* and *"Although there are"* becomes *"its,"* with the subsequent *"although"* removed. **Qiānzhī** commentary: In the *"To make people"* passage, the *Suizhou* version also reads *"the people."* In the *"To make the people"* passage, the *Imperial Commentary (Yùzhù)*, *Xíng Xuàn*, *Jìngfú*, *Qìngyáng*, *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, *Gāo Yì*, *Nǎn Juǎn*, *Heshang Gong*, *Dunhuang* versions, and the scholars *Gù*, *Péng*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Zhào* all render it as *"the people,"* consistent with this stone text.

*Bì Qián* notes: *"The people"*—*Wang Bi* renders it as *"the people."* Changing *"the people"* to *"people"* aligns with the Tang dynasty versions.

Further, the character *"陈"* (*chén*), in the *Suizhou* version, is written as *"阵"* (*zhèn*). The *Yùjiǎn* notes: *"阵, read as *zhèn* (from *shīlièng* and *zhèn* cuts), meaning troops; originally written as *陈* (*chén*)." Thus, *"陈"* (*chén*) and *"阵"* (*zhèn*) were anciently interchangeable.

*"舆"* (*yú*), the *Shìwén* glosses: *"Heshang Gong says *车* (*chē*)."* The *Imperial Commentary (Yùzhù)*, *Wang Bi*, *Suizhou*, *Song Heshang*, and *Nǎn Juǎn* versions render it as *"舆"* (*yú*), while *Zhào* renders it as *"车"* (*chē*). **Qiānzhī** commentary: The reading of *"舆"* (*yú*) is correct. *"舆"* (*yú*) is the ancient form of *"舆"* (*yú*). *Xià Cún*’s *Ancient Texts in Four Tones* cites the ancient *Laozi* as using *"舆"* (*yú*).

*"When their food is sweet, their clothing fine, their dwellings secure, and their customs joyous, neighboring states are visible to one another, and the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard between them. The people live out their lives until old age and death without visiting one another."*

**Qiānzhī** commentary: *"Sounds of roosters and dogs"*—the *Imperial Commentary (Yùzhù)* and *Gāo Yì* versions render it as *"sounds of roosters and dogs"* (*jīgǒu zhī yīn*), while *Wang Bi* renders it as *"sounds of roosters and dogs"* (*jīgǒu zhī shēng*). *Luó Zhènyù* notes: The *Jinglong*, *Jìngfú*, *Guāngmíng*, *Dunhuang* *Sīn* and *Xīn* versions all write *"狗"* (*gǒu*), and the *Dunhuang* version omits *"death"* (*sǐ*), while the *Xīn* version reads *"to make the people live out their lives."* **Qiānzhī** commentary: The *Fù* and *Fàn* versions have *"至治之极"* (*zhìdào zhī jí*, "at the utmost limit of good governance") and *"民各"* (*mín gè*, "each of the people") before *"甘其食"* (*gān qí shí*). Additionally, *Fù* and *Fàn*, along with *Péng*, write *"居"* (*jū*, "dwellings") as *"俗"* (*sú*, "customs"), *"俗"* (*sú*) as *"业"* (*yè*, "livelihood"), and insert *"使"* (*shǐ*, "to make") before *"民"* (*mín*). The *Yán* version places *"安其居"* (*ān qí jū*) after *"乐其俗"* (*lè qí sú*). The *Heshang Gong* and *Gù* versions omit *"death"* (*sǐ*), while *Fù* and *Péng* add *"与"* (*yǔ*, "with") after *"相"* (*xiāng*). The *Zhìyào* citation renders *"美其服"* (*měi qí fú*) as *"美其衣"* (*měi qí yī*).

**Qiānzhī** commentary: The character *"邻"* (*lín*), in the *Guāngmíng*, *Luó Juǎn*, and *Gù* versions, is consistent. The *Shuōwén Jiězì* notes: *"Five families form a neighborhood, from *邑* (*yì*), phonetic."* Anciently written as *○*. The *Jiǔ Jīng Zìyàng* states: *"The versions writing '邻' (*lín*) are erroneous; it should be written as '邻' (*lín*)."*

**Qiānzhī** commentary: The *Zhuangzi* in *"Tú Gē"* (*Túgē*, "Opening the Coffers") discusses *"至德之世"* (*zhìdé zhī shì*, "the age of utmost virtue"), and in *"Mǎtí"* (*Mǎtí*, "Horses’ Hooves") states *"民有常性，织而衣，耕而食"* (*mín yǒu chángxìng, zhī ér yī, gēng ér shí*, "the people have inherent nature, they weave to clothe themselves and till to feed themselves"), both passages drawing from this chapter. The nine sentences cited in *"Tú Gē"* differ only in that *"安其居，乐其俗"* (*ān qí jū, lè qí sú*, "secure their dwellings, joy in their customs") are inverted.

Further, the *Huáinán Zǐ* in *"Qí Sú"* (*Qísú*, "On the Customs of Equality") states: *"Thus neighboring states are visible to one another, the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard, yet their footprints do not cross the borders of the lords, and their wheel tracks do not join at a thousand *lǐ* (miles) away—all find their proper place."* The *Lùnliáng* in *"Shuō Rì"* (*Shuōrì*, "Discussing the Sun") states: *"In ancient times, simplicity prevailed, neighboring states bordered each other, the sounds of roosters and dogs were heard, yet they did not visit one another throughout their lives."* Both passages derive from this chapter of *Laozi*. The *Shǐjì* in *"Huòshī"* (*Huòshī*, "On the Monopolies of Commerce") also contains *"至治之极"* (*zhìdào zhī jí*, "at the utmost limit of good governance"). Though the stele versions lack this sentence, it may be supplemented based on the *Fù* and *Fàn* versions and the citations in *Zhuangzi* and *Shǐjì*.

**【Rhymes】** This chapter, as per *Jiāng Shì*’s rhyming readings, lacks rhyme. *Yáo Wéntián* and *Dèng Tíngzhēn* agree. *Gāo Běn Hàn* renders it as *"至治之极，民各甘其食，美其服，安其俗，乐其业"* (*zhìdào zhī jí, mín gè gān qí shí, měi qí fú, ān qí sú, lè qí yè*), with *"极"* (*jí*), *"食"* (*shí*), *"服"* (*fú*), *"俗"* (*sú*), and *"业"* (*yè*) rhyming—though *"俗"* (*sú*) does not actually rhyme. Further, *"邻国相望"* (*lín guó xiāng wàng*) to *"老死不相往来"* (*lǎo sǐ bù xiāng wànglái*)—*Gāo Běn Hàn* incorrectly changes *"往来"* (*wànglái*) to *"来往"* (*láiwàng*), to harmonize with *"望"* (*wàng*), which is a grave error.

---
**Chapter Eighty-One**
*"True words are not beautiful; beautiful words are not true.
The virtuous do not argue; those who argue are not virtuous.
The wise do not amass knowledge; those who amass knowledge are not wise."*

**Luó Zhènyù** commentary: The *Dunhuang Xīn* version renders *"知"* (*zhī*) as *"智"* (*zhì*).

**Takeshi Uchida** commentary: The *"The virtuous do not argue"* (*shànzhě bù biàn*) and *"those who argue are not virtuous"* (*biànzhě bù shàn*) passages appear after *"The wise do not amass knowledge"* (*zhìzhě bù bó*) and *"those who amass knowledge are not wise"* (*bózhě bù zhì*) in the *Dunhuang* and *Suizhou* versions. **Qiānzhī** commentary: The *Yán* and *Gù* versions align with the *Dunhuang* and *Suizhou* versions.

The *Fù* and *Fàn* versions render *"善者不辩"* (*shànzhě bù biàn*) and *"辩者不善"* (*biànzhě bù shàn*) as *"善言不辩"* (*shàn yán bù biàn*) and *"辩言不善"* (*biàn yán bù shàn*), respectively.

**Yú Zǎo** commentary: This should be read as *"信者不美，美者不信"* (*xìnzhě bù měi, měizhě bù xìn*, "true words are not beautiful, beautiful words are not true"), matching the parallel structure of the following *"善者不辩，辩者不善；知者不博，博者不知"* (*shànzhě bù biàn, biànzhě bù shàn; zhìzhě bù bó, bózhě bù zhì*).

*Heshang Gong*’s commentary on *"信者不美"* (*xìnzhě bù měi*) states: *"True words, as they are in reality. Not beautiful, meaning simple and unadorned."*

chunks.original_text: 」是可证古本正作「信者不美」，无「言」字也。 陶鸿庆曰：案俞氏据河上注，知经文两「言」字皆当作「者」，与下文一律者也。 今按王注云：「实在质也，本在朴也。 」但释「信」与「美」之义，而不及「言」，以其所见本亦作「者」也。 谦之案：俞、陶之说非也。 文心雕龙情采篇曰：「老子疾伪，故称『美言不信』。 」是刘勰所见老子本作「言」字。 河上于此句注云：「滋美之言者，孳孳华词。 不信者，饰伪多空虚也。 」又成玄英开题序诀义疏题此章为「信言」章。 疏云：「信，实也。 美，浮艳也。 言上德之人……所说言教，实而不华，……浮艳之言，……既乖至理，所以不信。 故庄云『犬不以善吠为良，人不以善言为贤』也。 」可证河上本与碑本同。 王注六十二章「美言可以市」句云：「美言之，则可以夺货之贾，故曰『美言可以市』也。 」此章注：「实在质也，本在朴也。 」义亦正同。 虽未及「言」，而言在其中，何由证其所见本必作「者」乎？ 又「善者不辩」二句，焦竑考异曰：「古本作『善言不辩，辩言不善』。 」又庄子齐物论「大辩不言」，语亦同此。 知北游篇「不知深矣，知之浅矣」，与「知者不博」二句语意亦似。 圣人不积，既以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多。 严可均曰：「既以为人」，御注作「与人」。 罗振玉曰：御注、景福二本「为」作「与」。 谦之案：邢玄、庆阳、磻溪、楼正均作「与」。 二「愈」字，邢玄作「逾」，范作「俞」。 「俞」古字，作「逾」误。 碑本五章「愈」亦作「俞」。 又「圣人不积」，严、彭、傅、赵、高并作「无积」，范作「无积」，河上公、王弼作「不积」。 作「无积」是也。 战国策魏策一引老子曰「圣人无积，尽以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多」，「不积」亦作「无积」。 「既以与人」句，庄子田子方篇引同。 「既以为人」句，「既」字可据魏策改为「尽」字，与「既」字为对文。 又「积」有藏义，楚语「无一日之积」，注：「积，储也。 」庄子天道「运而无所积」，释文：「谓积滞不通。 」天下篇称老聃「以有积为不足……无藏也故有余」，无积即无藏也。 天之道，利而不害。 圣人之道，为而不争。

Now, referring to Wáng Bì’s annotation, which states: 'Real and unadorned, rooted in simplicity,' he elucidates the meanings of '信' and '美' without addressing '言', implying his source text also used '者'.*

**Qiānzhī** counters: *"Yú and Táo’s argument is incorrect. In *Wénxīn Diāolóng*’s *Qíngcǎi* chapter, it states: 'Lǎozǐ detests falsity, thus declaring 『méi yán bù xìn』 (美言不信).' This proves Liú Xiè’s *Lǎozǐ* text included the '言' character. Heshang Gong’s annotation here reads: 'Excessively ornate speech, laboring over flowery words—untrue, embellished with deceit and emptiness.' Moreover, in *Chéng Xuànyīng’s* *Kāití Jùyì Yìshū*, this chapter is titled the 'Shìyán' (信言) chapter. The *shū* states: 'Shì (信) means reality; měi (美) means superficial brilliance. The speech of the virtuous—real yet unadorned... Superficial brilliance in speech... contradicts ultimate truth, hence untrue. Thus Zhuangzi says, 『Dogs are not good barkers for being virtuous; people are not virtuous for speaking well.』' This confirms Heshang Gong’s text and the stele edition are identical. Wáng Bì’s annotation on Chapter 62, *"méi yán kěyǐ shì"* (美言可以市), states: 'Ornate speech can deceive merchants, hence "ornate speech can trade."' In this chapter, his annotation reads: 'Real and unadorned, rooted in simplicity.' The meaning is consistent. Though he does not mention '言', its implication is inherent—how can one assert his source text *must* have used '者'?

As for the *"shànzhě bù biàn"* (善者不辩) passage, **Jiāo Jùn** in *Kǎoyì* notes: 'The ancient text reads *"shàn yán bù biàn, biàn yán bù shàn"* (善言不辩，辩言不善).' Similarly, in *Zhuāngzǐ’s* *Qíwùlùn*, it states *"dà biàn bù yán"* (大辩不言), echoing the same sentiment. The *"bù zhī shēn yǐ, zhī zhī qiǎn yǐ"* (不知深矣，知之浅矣) in *Běiyóu Piān* also parallels the *"zhìzhě bù bó"* (知者不博) passage in meaning.

*'Shèngrén bù jī'* (圣人不积): *Yán Kějūn* notes that the *Yùzhù* renders this as *"wú jī"* (无积), while **Luó Zhènyù** observes that the *Yùzhù*, *Jǐngfú*, and other versions use *"yǔ"* (与) instead of *"wéi"* (为). **Qiānzhī** confirms that *Xíng Xuán*, *Qìngyáng*, *Pánxī*, and *Lóuzhèng* all use *"yǔ"* (与). The two *"yù"* (愈) characters are rendered as *"yú"* (逾) by *Xíng Xuán*, while *Fàn* uses *"yú"* (俞)—an ancient character mistakenly written as *"yú"* (逾). The stele edition’s Chapter 5 also uses *"yú"* (俞). Additionally, *"shèngrén bù jī"* (圣人不积) is rendered as *"wú jī"* (无积) in *Yán*, *Péng*, *Fù*, *Zhào*, and *Gāo* versions, while *Heshang Gong* and *Wáng Bì* use *"bù jī"* (不积). The correct form is *"wú jī"* (无积). The *Zhàn guó cè*’s *Wèi cè* quotes Lǎozǐ as saying: *"Shèngrén wú jī, jìn wéi rén jǐ yù yǒu, jì yǐ yǔ rén jǐ yù duō"* (圣人无积，尽以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多), where *"bù jī"* (不积) is also rendered as *"wú jī"* (无积). The *"jìn wéi rén"* (尽以为人) sentence’s *"jìn"* (尽) can be emended to *"jì"* (既) based on *Wèicè*, forming a parallel structure.

Moreover, *"jī"* (积) carries the meaning of 'to hoard.' In *Chǔyǔ*, *"wú yīrì zhī jī"* (无一日之积) is annotated as *"jī"* (积) meaning 'to store.' The Dao of Heaven profits without harming; the Dao of the Sage acts without contention.

Lu Zhenyu remarked: *"The Dunhuang Sima manuscript lacks the lower ‘zhi’ (之) character."* Qian’s annotation: *"The Zhao manuscript reads ‘rén zhī dào’ (人之道), omitting the ‘shèng’ (圣) character."* The **‘rén’ (人)** corresponds to **‘tiān’ (天)**, forming a parallel structure—this is more harmonious in composition (*wén shèng*), yet it does not reflect the original meaning of Laozi.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter, according to Jiang’s rhyme reading, lacks rhyme, while all other versions agree. Only Gao’s Han manuscript rhymes **xìn (信)** with **shàn (善)**, and Takeuchi Yoshio rhymes **jī (积)**, **yǒu (有)**, and **duō (多)**, both of which are incorrect. This chapter actually rhymes **xìn-xìn (信信)**, **shàn-shàn (善善)**, **zhī-zhī (知知)** in a head-to-tail pattern.

Moreover, **zhī (知)**, **jī (积)**, and **duō (多)** share a rhyme, with **zhī (知)** and **jī (积)** belonging to the **Zhī (支)** rhyme category, while **duō (多)** belongs to the **Gē (歌)** category—here, **Gē (歌)** and **Zhī (支)** are interchangeable in rhyme.

The **Jǐnglóng Stele** manuscript contains **57 characters**, while the Dunhuang, Hé, Wáng, Fù, and Fàn manuscripts all match it. The Hé manuscript is titled *“Xiǎnzhí Dìbāshíyī” (显质第八十一)*, the Wáng manuscript *“Bāshíyī Zhāng” (八十一章)*, and the Fàn manuscript *“Xìn yán bù měi Zhāng dì bāshíyī” (信言不美章第八十一)*.

In ancient times, Kong Guangsen composed *Poetic Sound Categories*, stating:

*"Nowadays, poetry prioritizes literary elegance, whereas ancient poetry prioritized song. Song has rhythms of haste and slowness, harmonies of clarity and turbidity—sometimes unfolding in lengthy recitation, sighing and chanting across multiple lines without strict rhyme; sometimes binding sound to tight rhythms, where each sentence rhymes, each character rhymes, yet never tiring of it."*

I hold that the *Five Thousand Words* of *Dao/Way and Virtue/Power* is ancient philosophical poetry. Since it is poetry, it must be singable, recitable—its rhythms of haste and slowness, its harmonies of clarity and turbidity, though not necessarily identical to the *Three Hundred Poems*, yet whether or not it rhymes, it surely adheres to poetic conventions without doubt.

However, in the Song dynasty’s *Wu Qi’s Rhyme Supplement*, it was already lamented that *"Laozi’s Dao/Way and Virtue/Power Classic, composed by Old Master Laozi beneath the Zhou dynasty’s ancestral hall, contains many rhymed passages, yet today they are often mispronounced."* Thus, establishing principles and examples—how can they be neglected? I now compose *Laozi’s Rhyme Patterns*.

**(1)** Times change, sounds diverge—each era has its own phonetic system. Ancient rhymes cannot align with Tang, nor Tang rhymes with today. As Yan Bai’s poem states, *"The sounds of past and present are bound to their times"*—how true this is! Reading the *Five Thousand Words* with modern pronunciation feels discordant, yet applying ancient pronunciation reveals many alignments, with discrepancies often arising from scribal errors. In the past, Deng Tingzhen examined the rhymes in the *Five Thousand Words*, aligning them with the *Book of Changes* and *Book of Poetry*. For instance, in the chapter *"Discerning Virtue/Power"*, *fù (富)*, *zhì (志)*, and *jiǔ (久)* form a single rhyme—*jiǔ* rhyming with *fù* and *zhì* matches the *Book of Poetry*, while the following sentence rhymes with *shòu (寿)*, aligning with the *Book of Changes*. In truth, the *Five Thousand Words* sometimes aligns with the *Book of Poetry*, sometimes diverges, yet with the *Book of Changes*, it is nearly identical. Moreover, since Chu people wrote in Chu dialect with Chu pronunciation, this also marks the beginning of *Sao* rhyme. Let me cite examples where it aligns with the *Book of Changes*:

**(1)** Chapter 5: *"Excessive speech leads to exhaustion; better to guard the center."* *Qióng (穷)* and *zhōng (中)* rhyme.
   - *Book of Changes*’ *Need* commentary: *qióng (穷)*, *zhōng (中)*, *gōng (功)* rhyme.
   - *Obstruction* commentary: *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)*, *gōng (功)*, *bāng (邦)* rhyme.
   - *Misfortune* commentary: *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)* rhyme.
   - *Well* commentary: *qióng (穷)*, *zhōng (中)*, *gōng (功)*, *xiōng (凶)* rhyme.
   - *Progress* commentary: *gōng (功)*, *bāng (邦)*, *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)* rhyme.
   - *Dispersion* commentary: *qióng (穷)*, *tóng (同)*, *zhōng (中)*, *gōng (功)* rhyme.
   - *Restriction* commentary: *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)* rhyme.
   - *Completion* commentary: *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)* rhyme.
   - *Earth* commentary: *zhōng (中)*, *qióng (穷)*, *zhōng (终)* rhyme.

From the above, the *Five Thousand Words* (五千言) shares rhymes with *Book of Changes* (易) and *Chu Ci* (骚). Knowing the **Dao/Way of Sound** (声音之道), it shifts with the times yet aligns with *Book of Changes* and *Chu Ci*, and upon examination, all are not far from **Laozi** (老子). The *Five Thousand Words* (五千言) is indeed one of the two great **philosophical poems** (哲学诗) of ancient China alongside *Book of Changes* (易经); **Laozi** being a native of Chu (楚人), it also harmonizes with the **Chu melodies** (楚声). Though **Laozi** is traditionally placed after **Qu Yuan** (屈) in historical order, the frequency of the particle **"xiē"** (兮) in the text suggests a close affinity with *Chu Ci*’s rhymes—could the *Five Thousand Words* be the **progenitor of Chu melodies** (楚声之元祖)?

**(Part II)** Research on **Laozi**’s ancient rhymes began with **Song dynasty Wu Ji** (宋吴棫). Following **Metaphorical Firewood** (顾炎武) and **Jiang Shenxiu** (江慎修) in the **Qing dynasty**, the most notable works are **Jiang Jinsan**’s (江晋三) *Laozi* rhyme readings, **Yao Wentian**’s (姚文田) *Harmony of Ancient Sounds*, and **Deng Tingzhen**’s (邓廷桢) *Notes from the Double Inkstone Studio* (双砚斋笔记). **Deng**’s work uniquely clarifies the boundaries between the **Yu** (虞) and **Hou** (侯) tonal categories, and the classification of **entering tones** (入声) under various departments, yet it does not delve into a comprehensive study of ancient rhymes.

**Jiang Jinsan** (江晋三) presents a **twenty-department harmony** (廿一部谐声), while **Yao Wentian** (姚文田) organizes **twenty-eight ancient rhyme departments** (古韵廿八部), meticulously cross-referencing each line and word in the *Five Thousand Words* (五千言) to elucidate rhyme principles. Though some omissions exist, their deviations are few. Particularly, **Jiang Jinsan**’s rhyme readings align with **Wang Renxun**’s (王念孙) *Ancient Rhyme Chart* (古韵谱), providing scholars with valuable resources. chunks.original_text: （其三）细绎江氏老子韵读，其大异于姚文田者，在于以五千言用韵之文为准，而发明通韵与合韵之说。 如四十一章谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅同属侯部，姚文田分谷、辱、足一韵（六屋入声），偷、渝、一韵（十三侯平声），邓廷桢同。 江氏则破除此种入声分配之谬，以谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅为一韵。 此犹就同部者言之，若夫异部之通转，则非妙于审音者不能。 如六十七章勇、广、长为阳、东通韵，而姚文田邓廷桢则祇广、长韵。 二章事、教、辞、有、恃为之、宵合韵，而姚文田、邓廷桢则祇辞、有、恃韵。 至如六十四章散、乱、末之祭、元通韵，三十五章味、见、既之脂、元合韵，则非妙达阴阳对转之理者所敢言、所能言矣。 考老子通韵合韵之例，江氏所发明者，以通韵言，如： （一）之、幽通韵（九章、十六章、二十五章、五十二章、三十三章、五十章、五十九章）。 （二）幽、宵通韵（四十一章）。 （三）侯、鱼通韵（二十六章、三十章、三十四章）。 （四）歌、支通韵（十章、二十八章）。 （五）脂、祭通韵（四十五章）。 （六）祭、元通韵（六十四章）。 （七）元、真通韵（三十章）。 （八）文、真通韵（一章、十五章、二十六章）。 （九）真、耕通韵（二十二章、三十二章）。 （十）阳、东通韵（十二章、十六章、二十二章、二十五章、二十六章、六十七章）。 以合韵言，如： （一）之、宵合韵（二章）。 （二）幽、侯合韵（十七章）。 （三）脂、元合韵（三十五章）。 就中「之、幽通韵」「侯、鱼通韵」「脂、祭通韵」「真、耕通韵」「文、真通韵」，皆为同列相比之近旁通转。 惟「之、幽」「侯、鱼」「脂、祭」为阴声与阴声之近旁转，「真、耕」「文、真」「阳、东」则为阳声与阳声之近旁转。 又「之、宵合韵」「幽、侯合韵」为阴声与阴声之近旁合。 次之，「元、真通韵」「幽、宵通韵」为次旁通转，但「元、真」为阳声与阳声之次旁转，「幽、宵」为阴声与阴声之次旁转。 「歌、支通韵」为阴声与阴声之又次旁转，惟「祭、元通韵」为阴阳相对之次通转，「脂、元合韵」为阴阳相对之又次对合。 试本孔广森、章炳麟之说，为列图如上，以资说明。 （其四）老子五千言，其疾徐长短，用韵体制各殊：有通篇用韵者； 有章首用韵，而中间或尾声不拘者； 有间句助语自为唱叹，不在韵例者。 此盖哲学诗之体裁有所谓「自由押韵式」。 就其用韵之格式言之，有与诗经绝同者，如二十八章： 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪； 为天下溪，常德不离，复归于婴儿（歌、支通韵）。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式； 为天下式，常德不忒，复归于无极（之部）。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷； 为天下谷，常德乃足，复归于朴（侯部）。 又如十章： 载营魄抱一，能无离？ 专气致柔，能婴儿？ 涤除玄览，能无疵？ 爱人治国，能无为？ 天门开阖，能为雌？ 明白四达，能无知（歌、支通韵）？ 此一唱三叹，以声论声，即置之三百篇中，亦不知有何分别； 然而终不同者，则三百篇皆吟咏性情之作，而此则以说理竞长。 所谓哲学诗之特点乃在内容，内容有异而形式随之，此所以老子用韵体裁与诗有同有异，而与易则无不同也。

**(Section III)** A meticulous examination of Jiang Shi’s *Laozi* rhyme readings reveals his most significant divergence from Yao Wenti’s approach: Jiang takes the *Five Thousand Words* as a rhymed text and elucidates the principles of **through-rhymes (通韵)** and **combined rhymes (合韵)**. For instance, in Chapter 41, where *gǔ* (谷), *rǔ* (辱), *zú* (足), *tōu* (偷), *yú* (渝), and *yú* (隅) all belong to the *Hóu* (侯) rhyme category, Yao Wenti and Deng Tingzhen split them into two—*gǔ, rǔ, zú* in one (sixth *Wū* entering-tone), and *tōu, yú* in another (thirteenth *Hóu* level-tone). Jiang, however, rejects this erroneous entering-tone division, treating all six as a single rhyme.

This is but one example of harmonizing within the same rhyme class; yet when it comes to **cross-rhyme transformations (通转)** between different classes, only those with exquisite phonetic discernment dare speak of it. For example, in Chapter 67, *yǒng* (勇), *guǎng* (广), and *zhǎng* (长) form a **Yang-Dong through-rhyme**, yet Yao Wenti and Deng Tingzhen only acknowledge *guǎng* and *zhǎng*. In Chapter 2, *shì* (事), *jiào* (教), *cí* (辞), *yǒu* (有), and *shì* (恃) belong to the **Zhī-Xiāo combined rhyme**, but Yao and Deng only recognize *cí, yǒu, shì*. Even more complex are cases like Chapter 64, where *sǎn* (散), *luàn* (乱), and *mò* (末) form a **Zhì-Yuán through-rhyme**, or Chapter 35, where *wèi* (味), *jiàn* (见), and *jì* (既) form a **Zhī-Yuán combined rhyme**—these require mastery of **yin-yang opposing transformations (阴阳对转)** to comprehend.

When examining *Laozi*’s through-rhymes and combined rhymes, Jiang’s discoveries reveal the following patterns:

**Through-Rhymes (通韵):**
1. **Zhī-Yōu** (之、幽) (Chapters 9, 16, 25, 52, 33, 50, 59)
2. **Yōu-Xiāo** (幽、宵) (Chapter 41)
3. **Hóu-Yú** (侯、鱼) (Chapters 26, 30, 34)
4. **Gē-Zhī** (歌、支) (Chapters 10, 28)
5. **Zhī-Zhì** (脂、祭) (Chapter 45)
6. **Zhì-Yuán** (祭、元) (Chapter 64)

Among these, **"Zhī-Yōu," "Hóu-Yú," "Zhī-Zhì," "Zhēn-Gēng," and "Wén-Zhēn"** are instances of **adjacent-class transformations (近旁通转)**. Specifically:
- **"Zhī-Yōu," "Hóu-Yú," "Zhī-Zhì"** are **yin-tone adjacent transformations (阴声近旁转)**.
- **"Zhēn-Gēng," "Wén-Zhēn," "Yáng-Dōng"** are **yang-tone adjacent transformations (阳声近旁转)**.
- **"Zhī-Xiāo," "Yōu-Hóu"** are **yin-tone adjacent combined rhymes (阴声近旁合)**.

Next, **"Yuán-Zhēn" and "Yōu-Xiāo"** are **secondary adjacent transformations (次旁通转)**—**"Yuán-Zhēn"** being **yang-tone secondary (阳声次旁转)**, and **"Yōu-Xiāo"** being **yin-tone secondary (阴声次旁转)**.
**"Gē-Zhī"** is a **further secondary yin-tone transformation (阴声又次旁转)**, while **"Zhì-Yuán"** is a **yin-yang opposing secondary through-rhyme (阴阳相对之次通转)**, and **"Zhī-Yuán"** is a **yin-yang opposing secondary combined rhyme (阴阳相对之又次对合)**.

If we were to illustrate these patterns following Kong Guangsen’s and Zhang Binglin’s theories, a diagram as described above would clarify them.

**(Section IV)** The *Five Thousand Words* of *Laozi* exhibits varied pacing, length, and rhyme structures: some passages employ rhyme throughout; others rhyme only at the chapter’s beginning, while the middle or end remains unrestricted; still others insert interjections or rhetorical phrases that do not conform to rhyme schemes. This reflects what may be called **"free-rhyming"**—a hallmark of **philosophical poetry**.

In terms of rhyme structure, some verses mirror the *Shijing*’s strictness. For example, Chapter 28:
*"Know its masculine, hold to its feminine—*
*Thus you become the valley of the world.*
*Be the valley of the world,*
*Constant virtue never departs,*
*And returns to the infant state."* **(Gē-Zhī through-rhyme)**

*"Know its bright, hold to its dark—*
*Thus you become the model of the world.*
*Be the model of the world,*
*Constant virtue never errs,*
*And returns to the boundless."* **(Zhī rhyme)**

*"Know its honor, hold to its disgrace—*
*Thus you become the valley of the world.*
*Be the valley of the world,*
*Constant virtue attains sufficiency,*
*And returns to the Primordial."* **(Hóu rhyme)**

Or Chapter 10:
*"Nurture the vital essence, embrace the One—*
*How could it ever stray?*
*Concentrate the *qi*, attain softness—*
*How could it ever be infantile?*
*Purify the mystic vision—*
*How could it ever be flawed?*
*Love the people, govern the state—*
*How could it ever act?*
*The Heavenly Gate opens and shuts—*
*How could it ever be feminine?*
*Illuminated, four-way—*
*How could it ever know?"* **(Gē-Zhī through-rhyme)**

Here, the **one-stanza-three-refrains (一唱三叹)** technique—where sound echoes sound—would not seem out of place in the *Three Hundred Poems*. Yet the distinction remains: while the *Shijing* sings of human emotions, *Laozi* competes in **rational exposition**. The defining feature of **philosophical poetry** lies in its **content**; differing substance demands differing form. Thus, while *Laozi*’s rhyme schemes share similarities with poetry, they also diverge—and unlike the *Yijing*, they bear no fundamental difference.

From the examples cited above, there are cases deemed by earlier scholars as lacking rhyme, yet they all naturally conform to rhyme. For instance, in rhyming through repetition, the *Laozi* provides many examples, and there are corroborations found in poetry and the *Yijing*. In poetry, the *Jiangqi* (Ch. 195) follows the *Zong* (Zong rhyme) in each stanza; the *Geqi* (Ch. 202) follows the *Qing* (Qing rhyme) in the first two stanzas; the *Yi* (Ch. 196) follows the *Dian* (Dian rhyme) in its five stanzas; the *Shengmin* (Ch. 203) follows the *Lin* (Lin rhyme) in its three stanzas; the *Zai* (Ch. 204) follows the *Shen* (Shen rhyme) in its four stanzas; the *Qian* (Ch. 205) follows the *Kuang* (Kuang rhyme) in its first two stanzas; the *Heren* (Ch. 197) follows the *Xing* (Xing rhyme) in its five stanzas; the *Qiaoyan* (Ch. 206) follows the *Sheng* (Sheng rhyme) in its two stanzas; the *Hongyan* (Ch. 207), *Yi* (Ch. 196), and *Sangrou* (Ch. 208) all follow the *Ren* (Ren rhyme); the *Mian* (Ch. 198) follows the *Men* (Men rhyme) in its seven stanzas; the *Dang* (Ch. 209) follows the *Shang* (Shang rhyme) in its stanzas beginning from the second, using the character "商" (Shang); the *Dongshan* (Ch. 210) follows the *Shan* (Shan rhyme) in each stanza, using the character "山" (Shan); the *Yu* (Ch. 199) follows the *Yan* (Yan rhyme) in its five stanzas; the *Qiaoyan* (Ch. 206) follows the *Yan* (Yan rhyme) in its five stanzas; the *Binzhi* (Ch. 211) follows the *Yan* (Yan rhyme) in its first stanza; the *Cawei* (Ch. 212) follows the *He* (He rhyme) in its four stanzas; the *Han* (Ch. 213) follows the *He* (He rhyme) in its three stanzas; the *Yi* (Ch. 196) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its ten stanzas; the *Chuche* (Ch. 214) follows the *Zi* (Zi rhyme) in its five stanzas; the *Xiangbo* (Ch. 215) follows the *Zi* (Zi rhyme) in its seven stanzas; the *Nanshan* (Ch. 216) follows the *Zi* (Zi rhyme) in its first, second, fourth, and fifth stanzas.

Other examples include *Lai* (Ch. 217) with *lai* (Lai rhyme), *Guo* (Ch. 218) with *guo* (Guo rhyme), *Shu* (Ch. 219) with *shu* (Shu rhyme), *Nü* (Ch. 220) with *nü* (Nü rhyme), *Di* (Ch. 221) with *di* (Di rhyme), *Zui* (Ch. 222) with *zui* (Zui rhyme), *You* (Ch. 223) with *you* (You rhyme), *Le* (Ch. 224) with *le* (Le rhyme)—repetitive rhymes that are countless in number.

Again, taking the *Yijing* as an example, the *Yi* (Ch. 225) follows the *Yang* (Yang rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Da* (Ch. 226) follows the *Zhang* (Zhang rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Guan* (Ch. 227) follows the *Sheng* (Sheng rhyme) in its sixth line, ninth line, and upper ninth line; the *Jie* (Ch. 228) follows the *Ting* (Ting rhyme) in its initial ninth line and second line; the *Ding* (Ch. 229) follows the *Yuan* (Yuan rhyme) in its sixth line and upper ninth line; the *Bi* (Ch. 230) follows the *Wen* (Wen rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Xun* (Ch. 231) follows the *Rui* (Rui rhyme) in its fifth line; the *Sun* (Ch. 232) follows the *Shi* (Shi rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Xiao* (Ch. 233) follows the *Shi* (Shi rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Lun* (Ch. 234) follows the *Zi* (Zi rhyme) in its sixth line; the *Yi* (Ch. 235) follows the *Hui* (Hui rhyme) in its sixth line and *Kun* (Ch. 236) follows the *Hui* (Hui rhyme) in its upper sixth line; the *Meng* (Ch. 237) follows the *Kou* (Kou rhyme) in its upper ninth line; the *Cui* (Ch. 238) follows the *Ju* (Ju rhyme) in its *Tuan* (Tuan rhyme) passage; the *Lü* (Ch. 239) follows the *Pu* (Pu rhyme) in its second and ninth lines; the *Dayu* (Ch. 240) follows the *Jiu* (Jiu rhyme) in its initial ninth line.

Thus, it is known that within the *Wuyingyan* (Five Thousand Words), rhymes like *Dao* (Dao rhyme), *Ming* (Ming rhyme), *Ren* (Ren rhyme), and even *Gou* (Gou rhyme) are hardly exceptional. Further, in the case of auxiliary rhymes, the *Yi* (Ch. 225) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) and *Yu* (Yu rhyme) in its *Xiang* (Xiang rhyme) passage; the *Ding* (Ch. 229) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) and *You* (You rhyme) in its *Xiang* (Xiang rhyme) passage.

Even if one claims the *Shijing* does not conform to auxiliary rhymes, this is not true. The *Yi* (Ch. 196) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its ten stanzas; the *Zai* (Ch. 204) follows the *You* (You rhyme), *Si* (Si rhyme), and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its four stanzas; the *Xiaozhong* (Ch. 241) follows the *Qi* (Qi rhyme) and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its two stanzas; the *Yuan* (Ch. 242) follows the *Zai* (Zai rhyme), *Qi* (Qi rhyme), *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *Si* (Si rhyme), *Zai* (Zai rhyme), *Qi* (Qi rhyme), *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *Si* (Si rhyme) in its one and two stanzas.

Again, in the *Chuci*, the *Lisha* (Ch. 243) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its "心犹豫而狐疑，怀椒糈而要之" (The heart is hesitant and dubious, holding fragrant rice and seeking it); "命灵氛为余占之，孰信修而慕之" (The spirit of the departed commands the ghost to divine for me, who would believe in virtue and emulate it); the *Tianwen* (Ch. 244) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *Mou* (Mou rhyme), and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme); the *You* (You rhyme), *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), and *Qi* (Qi rhyme); the *Jiuchapter* (Ch. 245) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *You* (You rhyme), and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme); the *Aiying* (Ch. 246) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), the *Chi* (Ch. 247) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) and *Qiou* (Qiu rhyme), the *Simeiren* (Ch. 248) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *Qi* (Qi rhyme), and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme); the *Xiwangri* (Ch. 249) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme), *Yi* (Yi rhyme), *Ci* (Ci rhyme), and *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme); the *Jiubian* (Ch. 250) follows the *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) in its two and four instances.

Thus, it is known that within the *Wuyingyan*, examples of rhymes with two *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) characters (Chapter 74), three *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) characters (Chapter 23, 66, 80), four *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) characters (Chapter 17), and five *Zhi* (Zhi rhyme) characters (Chapter 49) are hardly exceptional.

Since *Laozi* is a Daoist poetic philosophy, its use of rhyme is more free than that of the *Shijing*. Yet even so, it truly conforms to rhyme. If one were to argue that his writing diverges or does not adhere to rhyme, not only would this fail to capture the resonant beauty of the *Wuyingyan*, but it would also be insufficient to discuss the texts of the other masters.

chunks.original_text: （一）本书在选本方面，以唐易州龙兴观道德经碑本为主，次取敦煌写本与遂州碑本参订。 石本于御注、广明、景福以外，更参考楼正、邢玄、庆阳、磻溪、高翿、赵孟俯诸本。 钞本参考柰卷及室町时代钞本。 刻本王本除用明和宇惠本外，更参考道藏本、范应元引王本，与道藏宋张太守汇刻四家注本。 河上本除用宋刊本外，更参考道藏李道纯道德会元所用章句白本。 又如傅、范古本，夏竦古文四声韵所引古老子，及托名王羲之帖本等，均加以批判的选用。 （二）本书在校勘方面，以严可均铁桥金石跋中老子唐本考异所校三百四十九条为主，魏稼孙绩语堂碑录，或正严误，或补严阙，共四十三条，次之。 余如纪昀、毕沅、王昶、吴云之校老子，乃至罗振玉之道德经考异，何士骥之古本道德经校刊，凡与碑本校勘工作有关者，无不尽力搜罗，务求去伪存真，使道德经文字得以接近于本来面目。 （三）本书在训诂方面，所采旧注有王念孙、孙诒让、俞樾、洪颐烜、刘师培、易顺鼎、马叙伦、陶鸿庆、奚侗、蒋锡昌、劳健、高亨、于省吾诸家； 间亦采取日本大田晴轩、武内义雄之说。 案语则随文声叙，或出己见，其中有特重声训之处，说本朱骏声说文通训定声。 （四）本书在音韵方面，以江晋三老子韵读为主，偶有漏失，则以姚文田之古音谐、邓廷桢之双砚斋笔记、李赓芸之炳烛编补之。 若刘师培之老子韵表，高本汉之老子韵考，及奚侗，陈柱之说老子古音，则多臆说，其合者取之，不合者弃之。 （五）本书特重楚方言与老子之关系。 如四十五章「躁胜寒」，据诗汝坟释文「楚人名火曰燥」。 五十五章「终日号而不嗄」，据庄子庚桑楚篇司马彪注「楚人谓唬极无声曰嗄」。 七十章「披褐怀玉」，据淮南子齐俗训注「楚人谓袍为短褐大布」。 此类之例，说详各章，阅者察之。 （六）本书初稿成时，承杨树达先生、任继愈先生校正全书数次，梁启雄、王维诚二先生亦校正其一部分，得益良多。

**(1)** In terms of textual selection, this book primarily relies on the *Laozi* stele from the Tang dynasty’s Longxing Guan in Eizhou, supplemented by Dunhuang manuscripts and the Suizhou stele for cross-verification. For the stone editions, beyond the Imperial Commentary, *Guangming*, and *Jingfu* versions, it also draws on the editions of Lou Zheng, Xing Xuan, Qingyang, Panqi, Gao Yi, and Zhao Mengfu. For the manuscript copies, it references the *Nai* scroll and Sōtō-era manuscripts. For the printed *Wang* edition, besides the *Meiwa* edition by Ue no E, it also consults the Daoist Canon’s *Wang* edition, Fan Yingyuan’s citation of the *Wang* text, and the Song-era *Zhang Taishou* collated edition of the Four Commentaries. For the *He Shang* edition, in addition to the Song-printed version, it incorporates references from Li Daochun’s *Daode Jing Huiyuan*, which uses the plain-text chapter-and-commentary format. Additionally, ancient texts such as the *Fu-Fan* editions, the *Laozi* cited in Xia Jun’s *Guben Sishengyun*, and the falsely attributed Wang Xizhi calligraphic manuscripts are critically evaluated for inclusion.

**(2)** In textual collation, this book primarily follows the 349 variant readings recorded in Yan Kejun’s *Tieqiao Jinshi Po* annotations of the Tang *Laozi*. Wei Jiaosun’s *Jiyutang* stele records either correct Yan’s errors or supplement his omissions, contributing 43 additional readings. Beyond these, it exhaustively gathers the collations of *Laozi* by Ji Yun, Bi Yan, Wang Chang, Wu Yun, as well as Luo Zhenyu’s *Daode Jing Kaoyi* and He Shiji’s *Guben Daode Jing Jiaokan*, ensuring all relevant stele-based corrections are scrutinized to distinguish authenticity from forgery, striving to restore the *Daode Jing* to its original form.

**(3)** In exegesis, this book adopts the interpretations of Wang Renxun, Sun Yiran, Yu Ezhi, Hong Yixian, Liu Shipei, Yi Shunding, Ma Xulun, Tao Hongqing, Xi Dong, Jiang Xichang, Lao Jian, Gao Heng, and Yu Shengwu. It also occasionally incorporates the views of Japanese scholars Ōta Seikan and Takeuchi Yoshio. Marginal annotations are interspersed within the text, sometimes reflecting the author’s own insights, particularly emphasizing phonetic and tonal analysis, drawing on Zhu Jun’s *Shengwen Tongxun Ding Sheng*.

**(4)** In phonology and rhyme, this book primarily follows Jiang Jin’s *Laozi* tonal readings. Where gaps exist, it supplements with Yao Wenti’s *Guyin Xie*, Deng Tingzhen’s *Shuangyan Zhai Biji*, and Li Qianyun’s *Bingzhu Bian*. Liu Shipei’s *Laozi Yunbiao*, Gao Benhan’s *Laozi Yunkao*, as well as Xi Dong and Chen Zhu’s reconstructions of *Laozi*’s ancient pronunciations are largely speculative; only plausible readings are retained, while untenable ones are discarded.

**(5)** This book places particular emphasis on the relationship between Chu dialect and *Laozi*. For instance, in Chapter 45, *“zao sheng han”* (躁勝寒), it cites the *Shiji Fu* annotation that Chu people called fire *“zao”* (燥). In Chapter 55, *“zhong ri hao er bu sha”* (終日號而不嗄), it references Sima Biao’s note in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Gengsang Chu* chapter that Chu people termed extreme exhaustion without sound *“sha”* (嗄). In Chapter 70, *“pi he huai yu”* (披褐懷玉), it draws on the *Huainanzi*’s *Qisú* training annotation that Chu people called a short, coarse robe *“he”* (褐). Such examples are detailed in their respective chapters for the reader’s reference.

**(6)** Upon completion of the initial manuscript, the author benefited greatly from multiple rounds of corrections by Yang Shuda and Ren Jiyu, as well as partial reviews by Liang Qichao and Wang Weicheng.

**(Bibliographical Supplement)**
**(2)** Zhang Xiang’s *Annotations on the Laozi* (as preserved in the Dunhuang Six Dynasties manuscript): For Chapter 3, *“Not daring not to act”* (使心不乱), the annotation reads: *“According to Laozi’s Xiang’er Zhu commentary: In the *Huainanzi*’s ‘Training in the Dao,’ the *Shu Records*’s ‘Biography of Qin Mi,’ the *Kong Cangzi’s Commentary on the I Ching*’s *Gen Hexagram* (艮卦), the *Book of Jin*’s ‘Biography of Wu Yinzhī’ (吴隐之传), and the *Wenxuan*’s ‘Annotations on the *Dongjing Fu*’ (东京赋注), the text reads ‘*Not seeing what is desired*’ (不见可欲) without the character *民* (min). Liu Shipei’s *Laozi Rectified and Supplemented* argues that the Tang dynasty deleted this character due to taboo avoidance, but since the present Six Dynasties manuscript lacks the *民* character, Liu’s claim proves erroneous.”

For *“Empty its heart”* (虚其心), the annotation reads: *“In the Xiang’er Zhu commentary, ‘*虚*’ is written as ‘*○*’ (a blank). Based on the annotation’s text, ‘*Emptying the heart removes its wickedness, and the Dao returns to it*’ (虚去心中凶恶，道来归之), it is clear that the original should also read ‘*虚*’ (empty), and ‘*○*’ is a mistaken character.”*

For Chapter 7, *“With its lack of selfishness, it can fulfill its selfishness”* (以其无私，故能成其私), the annotation reads: *“The Xiang’er Zhu commentary renders this ‘*以其无尸，故能成其尸*’ (With its lack of *shi* [尸], it can fulfill its *shi* [尸]), and annotates: ‘*Those who do not know the Dao of longevity move only as corpses (尸行), not in accordance with the Dao. All their actions are corpse-like (尸行). The Daoist, however, attains immortal longevity by not moving as a corpse (尸行), by separating from the vulgar and differing from the common, thus fulfilling their *shi* (尸) and becoming an immortal sage (仙士).*’ This is the discourse of the *shenxian* (神仙) sect, which may be cross-referenced with the *Hou Hanshu*’s ‘Biography of the Magicians’ (后汉书方术传), and does not belong to the original *Laozi* text.”*

For Chapter 8, *“Now, only...”* (夫唯).

**Chapter 9**
*Hold it and it will overflow.*
谦之案: *"The *Guanzi* ‘White Heart’ chapter states: ‘*Hold it until it is full, and then disaster will come. To have one’s name spread across the land is not as good as letting it fade away.*’ This warning against excess aligns with *Laozi*’s teaching.*

*Above, not dazzling; below, not obscure.*
谦之案: *"‘*皦*’ is rendered as ‘*皎*’ in the *Dunhuang Bing* manuscript. ‘*昧*’ appears as ‘*忽*’ in the *Suizhou* edition, the *Dunhuang* Daoist *Suo Dunxuanjing* manuscript, and the *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu* text. However, ‘*昧*’ (rhyming with *皦*) should not be altered to ‘*忽*’ for metrical reasons.*

**Chapter 20**
*Only the one who affirms and the one who denies.*
谦之案: *"The *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu* renders ‘*阿*’ as ‘*何*’. According to Tang Wenbo, the *Dunhuang Laozi* manuscript (Pelliot Chinese 2329) also reads ‘*何*’. Thus, ‘*何*’ is a corruption of ‘*阿*’.*

*If feasting on the grandest sacrificial meat.*
谦之案: *"The character ‘*享*’ is written as ‘*亨*’ in the *Dunhuang Daoist Suo Dunxuanjing* manuscript and the *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu*, matching the *Jingdian Shifu*. ‘*亨*’ is the original form.*

*Endlessly striving, yet nowhere to return.*
谦之案: *"The *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu* reads ‘*鬿无所归*’, where ‘*鬿*’ is a variant of the *Suizhou* edition’s ‘*魁*’, likely a miswritten form of ‘*儡*’ (due to similar pronunciation).*

*The common folk are dazzled.*
谦之案: *"The *Jingdian Shifu* notes: ‘*昭*’ has a variant reading ‘*照*’. The *Dunhuang Daoist Suo Dunxuanjing* manuscript and *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu* both use ‘*照*’.*

**Chapter 21**
*The vessel of great virtue.*
谦之案: *"Wang Bi’s annotation states: ‘*孔* means *empty*. Only by embracing emptiness as virtue can one act in accordance with the Dao.’ The *Hou Hanshu* annotation on *Feng Kan* further explains: ‘*孔* means *empty*.’ This describes a boundless virtue—an empty heart containing all things. My earlier interpretation of ‘*孔德*’ as ‘*abundant virtue*’ is incomplete; this is the correct understanding.*

**Chapter 24**
*The striving will not endure; the boastful will not prevail.*
谦之案: *"These two lines appear as ‘*喘者不久，跨者不行*’ in the *Dunhuang Daoist Suo Dunxuanjing* manuscript and *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu*, matching the *Guanshu* and *Suizhou* editions. Below, ‘*自伐无功*’ is written as ‘*自饶无功*’, and ‘*余食赘行*’ as ‘*余食啜行*’, also aligning with the *Guanshu* and *Suizhou* editions.*

**Chapter 28**
*For the world, a path trodden by all.*
谦之案: *"The *Laozi Xiang’er Zhu* renders ‘*蹊*’ as ‘*奚*’, matching the *Dunhuang Ding* manuscript.*

**Chapter 35**
*Peaceful and vast, delighting in simplicity, welcoming travelers with ease.*
